div1.p:
1.
HENRY HOLLOW AY (61), was indicted
for stealing 1 bag, 1 coat, and other articles, value 17l., the property of
Thomas Gregory, clerk.

REV. THOMAS GREGORY . I am a clergyman living at Weston Lodge Grove
end, St John's-woodâ€”on Monday, 12th August, I went to the London-bridge terminus of the South-Eastern railwayâ€”it was after 10 o'clock when I got thereâ€”I had a large black leather bag with meâ€”it was one like this (produced)â€”it had no mark on it whateverâ€”I gave a police-constable the key of that bag when be afterwards came to my house, I cannot say the dateâ€”after getting my ticket I took my bag to the place where the luggage is labeled, and requested the porter to put the usual mark upon itâ€”I left it with the porter and went away for a minute or two, and when I returned my bag was gone, and this other bag (produced) was left in its placeâ€”my bag was quite full; this appeared to have nothing in it, comparativelyâ€”I had not packed my bag myself, my daughter's maid packed it for meâ€”this coat and pair of trousers and boots (produced) are mine, and were in my bagâ€”I can also swear positively to these slippers and these collarsâ€”this note paper has my monogram and crest on itâ€”this Church Service has my writing in itâ€”the contents of the bag were worth about 17l.â€”I cannot speak to the bag; it is similar to the one I had.

Prisoner. Q. Before this charge had you known anything dishonourable of me? A. I have not seen you for many years, only once I think during the last ten years; but I could not suppose for a moment that you or any clergy man would be guilty of such a thingâ€”I cannot form any notion of the weight of the bagâ€”I was going out to spend a few days and it contained all sorts of thingsâ€”my bag had one canvas division in the centre, and so has this; but I really cannot say anything about the bagâ€”it strikes, me it is like my bag, more I cannot say.

WILLIAM HARRIS . I am an officer in the employment of the London, Chatham, and Dover Railway, at the Victoria-stationâ€”on 23d August I took the prisoner into custody at that station, and took from him a bag which I believe to be the one producedâ€”I can't be exactly positive of itâ€”I gave it up to Parish.
JOHN PARISH (Policeman, A 280). I received the prisoner in custody on 23d Augustâ€”I received this bag from Harris, and afterwards received this key from Mr. Gregory; it opens the bag.
Prisoner. Q. Did you not find everything correct that I told you as to my lodging and everything else? A. Yes; perfectly correct.

CHARLOTTE GREASBY . I am a servant in the employ of Mr. Gregoryâ€”I packed a bag for him on Monday, 12th Augustâ€”I am in the habit of packing his bag for him when he goes outâ€”this coat, trousers, and boots are part of the things I put into the bagâ€”this is exactly like the bagâ€”it had no division, only a pocket like hisâ€”to the best of my belief this is the bagâ€”it is exactly like itâ€”the collars, the slippers, and the Church Service, I put in the bag.
Prisoner. Q. Was there a canvas division to the bag independent of the pocket? A. Noâ€”I have been in the habit of packing the bag for three years.

HARRIET YOUNG . I am the daughter of Mrs. Young, of 12, Stafford
placeâ€”the prisoner lodged thereâ€”I remember his coming home on 12th August with a bagâ€”it was like this, about the same sizeâ€”he asked me to carry it upstairs for himâ€”I said I could notâ€”it appeared very heavyâ€”it seemed full.

Prisoner. My reason for asking her to carry it upstairs was because I had been ill for some time, and was crippled in my hands and feet. Witness. He said he had the rheumatics, and it was very awkward for him to carry it up.

ANN CAVENDISH . I live at 35, Hendon-street, with my sisterâ€”I am not marriedâ€”I have been in the habit of letting lodgingsâ€”I know the prisonerâ€”in August last he was indebted to me a sum of moneyâ€”on 14th August he brought some clothes and gave them to me to dispose ofâ€”these produced are the articlesâ€”I saw a man at the door give them to Mr. Holloway out of a blue bag, and he brought them to me, and said he had bought them of himâ€”I did not see him buy themâ€”I saw him give the Jew some money, but I do not know what it wasâ€”he brought them upstairs to me, and then from my place he took them over to his lodging; and next morning he brought them over to me and told me that I could have them, for he had bought them for a gentleman and they were too large for him, and if I liked to have them I could, and dispose of them in which way I likedâ€”I took them to a Jew's to sell them; but he offered me so small a sum that I took them to a pawnbroker's, Mr. Chapman's, in the Queen's-road, Pimlico, and there pledged them for 25s.â€”the prisoner had not been in the habit of buying things from persons at the door in this wayâ€”I have known him eight years, and never knew him do anything wrongâ€”I have never said anything before to-day about seeing him buy these things at the doorâ€”I never was asked the question, or any question, only about pledging the clothes.
Prisoner. Q. What day used I to pay you? A. Mostly on Monday; sometimes on Tuesdayâ€”I went to the lodging on a Thursdayâ€”the week would not be owing until the Thursday.
COURT. Q. Was he lodging with you at this time? A. No; he was lodging oppositeâ€”he used to board with me.

Prisoner. Q. Did not I mention to you some days previously that I was going to buy some things for a gentleman? A. You did say so, and that they would not fit himâ€”you said that at the time you brought the things to meâ€”you said the gentleman wanted money, he did not wish for clothesâ€”you did not tell me to pawn themâ€”I told you I had sold them for 1l. 5s.â€”you said you gave a considerable deal more for themâ€”I showed you the ticketâ€”you said you had a great horror of doing this thing, and you would not look at the ticketâ€”the man at the door took the things out of a blue bagâ€”this black bag is yours; I have known you to have it for some time; I cannot say how longâ€”I recollect on Monday, the 12th, your putting a great many papers into itâ€”you said you were going out of townâ€”when you left me you said you were going home to your lodging.

MR. SLEIGH Q. How long have you known the prisoner? A. Eight yearsâ€”I have known him in different places besides Londonâ€”he was a lodger of mine in the country; not at Croydonâ€”we lodged in the same house at Croydonâ€”I knew him when I was living at Deptfordâ€”I can't say whether I saw this bag lying on the table at the police-courtâ€”I saw several bagsâ€”my attention was not in any way called to this bagâ€”I saw it produced, and heard Mr. Gregory say he could not positively swear to itâ€”I did not then say anything about having seen it in the prisoner's possessionâ€”I was never asked.

COURT. Q. How do you know that bag to be the bag which the prisoner has had? A. I feel confident of it, it is so much like the shape of the bagâ€”there is no particular mark upon it; I never noticed a markâ€”I often saw the inside of itâ€”I have packed it for him when he went awayâ€”I have not looked at it nowâ€”I have been speaking from the outsideâ€”the prisoner's bag was quite plain inside, with a little side pocketâ€”I do not remember anything about the inside pocketâ€”(looking at the bag) this is it.

WILLIAM CRISP YERRILL . I am assistant to Mr. Chapman, a pawnbroker, in Queen's-road, Pimlicoâ€”on 14th August the witness Cavendish pawned this coat, trousers, and boots produced, with me for 1l. 5s.â€”I have the ticket here.

COURT to ANN CAVENDISH. Q. On what day of the week was it you pawned these things? A. On the Tuesday I think; I cannot rememberâ€”as near as I can guess, I saw them in the prisoner's possession two or three days before he brought them to me; but I cannot rememberâ€”I saw a person hand them to him, and he paid some money to the personâ€”I really cannot remember how long that was before I pawned themâ€”I cannot remember the day of the week that he brought them to meâ€”he took them over to his lodging the day he bought them; and then, next morning, he brought them to me openly over his arm, and I think, if I am not mistaken, I had them in the house some days, it may have been two or three days, but I cannot tell how longâ€”there was nothing more besides the coat, trousers, and bootsâ€”when he brought them in he laid them on the couch and said he had just bought them.

GEORGE TAIT . I am a porter in the employ of the South-Eastern Railway Company, at the Loudon-bridge terminusâ€”I remember on a Monday in August Mr. Gregory coming to the station at a little past 11 o'clock; he had a black bag with himâ€”it was very much like thisâ€”I could not swear to itâ€”it was only about a second in my possessionâ€”it was left in my chargeâ€”I was labeling some baggage dose by, and my back was turned, and when Mr. Gregory came to me again he asked me for the bag, and I turned and saw it was gone, and this other bag left in its placeâ€”Mr. Gregory's bag was fullâ€”the bag that was left in its place was in much the same state
that it is nowâ€”I cannot say that I saw the prisoner at the station that dayâ€”I hare seen him two or three times.

Prisoner. Q. How long have you been with the Railway Company? A. About eleven yearsâ€”I can't say how often I have seen you; but several timesâ€”there is a good deal of difference between the appearance of the two bags when you come to look at them.

ALLAN D. GILLMORE . I am a constable at the Waterloo-station of the South-Western Railway Companyâ€”on Monday, 19th August, I saw the prisoner in the first-class waiting-room at Waterloo, between 7 and 8 o'clock.
Prisoner. Q. Are you certain you saw me between 7 and 8? A. I am.

MR. SLEIGH. Q. After he was gone did you find a bag? A. No; I saw inspector Bent find it on a stoolâ€”this is it (produced) that was found after 8 o'clock; five or ten minutes after I had seen the prisoner there.
COURT. Q. Do you know whether or not that bag was there before the prisoner came in? A. I do not.

THOMAS BERT . I am an inspector of police at the South Western Rail
way stationâ€”in consequence of some information that was given to me I looked about the waiting-room and found this bag on a seat outside the office; not in the waiting-roomâ€”on opening this bag I found in it the pro
perty which has been produced, with Mr. Gregory's name upon itâ€”the articles were subsequently shown to Mr. Gregory at the Police-courtâ€”the bag was found about three yards from the waiting-room, close to the doorâ€”there were no trains arriving or departing at the time; they were waiting for the mail train at half-past 8, and there was a train at five minutes past 8.

CHARLIES GREENSTREET ADDISON . I am a barristerâ€”this bag is my pro
pertyâ€”I lost it the first Monday in August at the Victoria Stationâ€”I see my initials plainly on the bag; they have been rubbed out, but have since appeared again.

ROBERT BEGBIE . I am an East India merchantâ€”I was at the Waterloo station as a passenger on the evening of the 19th Augustâ€”I arrived at the station about five minutes beforeâ€”I had with me one of Mechi's bagsâ€”I missed itâ€”I looked for it with the porter everywhere but could not find itâ€”I think it was between 8 o'clock and twenty-five minutes pastâ€”a small common leather bag for carrying papers in was left in lieu of my bag, and that was claimed by somebody immediately afterwards.

The prisoner in a long defence, after complaining of the length of time he had been in custody and the treatment received by him in the House of Deten
tion, stated that he should be able to prove that the bag claimed by the pro
secutor was his own, and that he had had it for eleven years; that he had only been at the London Bridge station on two occasions since October, 1860, and those were on 19th or 20th July last, and previously, to see the remains of the great fire: that on being taken into custody he had given his correct name and address, which he should not have done had he been guilty, and that the state of his health was such as to render him physically incapable of carrying away the bag alleged to be stolen.

WILLIAM HOLMES . I have known the prisoner about six yearsâ€”from what I knew of him while he was a resident in my house, I could not sup
pose he would be guilty of the acts he is charged with; he bore a very good characterâ€”he has resided with me at intervals during the last six yearsâ€”I have known him up to March last; that was the last time he left my houseâ€”I have frequently seen him since he left my houseâ€”as far as my know
ledge of him goes he has borne that character up to the present timeâ€”I have not seen the bagâ€”(looking at it)â€”I should scarcely like to swear to

this bag; the size is similar to Mr. Holloway's bag, which I have packed several timesâ€”it had no partition in it; it had a pocket like this; but bags are so much alike I could not swear to itâ€”it is exactly similar to the bag that I have packed for him five or six timesâ€”his bag was a little torn at the hinge; I perceive this is mendedâ€”the tear was more in the lining than the leatherâ€”he had the bag in my house from the first time I knew him; that would be six yearsâ€”I remember his coming to my house in January, 1860; he was then in a very infirm state of healthâ€”I should think he remained in that state for three or four months before Dr. Fuller saw himâ€”he very seldom went outâ€”he remained with me after Dr. Fuller came, until September, principally confined to his roomâ€”he very seldom went out, and only for very short intervalsâ€”he returned to my house on 3d January, 1861â€”he was very unwell at that time, and during the time that he then remained with me he was principally confined to his roomâ€”his eyes were bad and his hands also, and I had to write a great many letters for him because he could not seeâ€”he remained with me until the 13th or 14th Marchâ€”I have seen him occasionally walk about the room with an I umbrella and stickâ€”I remember his losing the use of his hands during the time he was with meâ€”I should say he was incapable of carrying anything or walking away with anything, but he partially recovered before he left me; and he went out on one or two occasions before he left me, but even then he was not able to carry any of his luggage down the stairs, I took it all down for him to the cab, and went with it to the George and Blue Boar, Holbornâ€”I saw him many times while he was there, and I have met him at Storey's Gate, once or twice by appointmentâ€”he was then apparently very infirm in the bands and feet when he walkedâ€”from knowing him infirmities and from his character, I really could not suppose him capable of doing what is laid to his charge; I was astounded when I heard it.

Cross-examined by MR. LAWRENCE. Q. Where do you reside? A. 3, New-street, Dorset-squareâ€”that was where the prisoner lodged with meâ€”the last time he left my house was in March, but I have seen him since then at the George and Blue Boar and at Storey's-gateâ€”I am a booksellerâ€”I have a shopâ€”I was not at the Police-court when the examination took placeâ€”one of the detectives came to my house and acquainted me with the fact that the prisoner was in the House of Detention; that was the firs I heard of this chargeâ€”I believe I was at the Police-court the second time he was examinedâ€”I have packed a bag like this several times for himâ€”I can't say any particular time; when he left my house on various occasions I packed it for himâ€”he always requested me to do it; he considered that I was more capable of packing it than he wasâ€”the last time I packed it was a day or two previous to his leaving my house in March, 1861.

ANN CAVENDISH (re-called). I recollect the 19th of Augustâ€”the prisoner was at home on that day; he was very ill on the sofa and could not move; he had a dreadful pain in the limbsâ€”he said he had occasion to go to the Bank on the Monday, and he was so ill he should defer it till the Tuesday, and he did not go out that dayâ€”I know it was the 19th August that he was so ill, because I went down and spoke to my landlady that day in regard of some rent.

Cross-examined. Q. Where was it that he was at home all day on the 19th? A. At my place; he came over from his lodging about half-past 8 or 9 to breakfastâ€”he was very ill when he came over, and he did not leave the place againâ€”he was not lodging in the same house with me; he came to breakfast with meâ€”he staid till half-past 10 or 11 o'clock at nightâ€”I think he never went out that dayâ€”he used to stay the whole of the day at
my placeâ€”when he used to come in the morning he never used to leave the room till he went over to his lodging in the evening.

Q. Will you undertake to swear that he was in your lodging at 5 o'clock that evening, pray be cautious? A. I think he was; I feel confident of itâ€”I can't say for certain; be has been at born so many days.

2.
HENRY HOLLOWAY was again indicted
for Stealing, on 5th August, a portmanteau, a coat, and other articles, the property of
Charles Green street Addison.

CHARLES GREENSTREET ADDISON . I am a member of the bar, and reside in Alfred-place, Thurlow-squareâ€”on Monday, 5th August, I was at the Pimlico terminus for the purpose of proceeding on the Croydon line, between 9 and 10 in the morningâ€”I had with me a portmanteau produced)â€”there were no porters there, and I took it in my handâ€”I arrived there before the pigeou-hole, at which the tickets are taken, was opened, and I placed my portmanteau on the bench, and walked up and down until the place was openedâ€”whilst I was walking up and down I observed that an elderly person came and sat down on the bench, leaning with his back against my portmanteau, and I observed that once or twice, as I walked up and down, he appeared to be watching me, and he moved as if to see whether I was coming to take the portmanteau, evidently endeavouring to ascertain whether I was the owner of itâ€”when the pigeon-hole was opened 1 wept and got my ticket, and then turned towards the door to see if any friends of mine were going by the trainâ€”on turning back I went to the bench and found that my portmanteau was goneâ€”I then went on to the platform and communicated with some porter or policemanâ€”I told him what had oc
curred, and a search was made about the station, and in a short time the witness, Mrs. Healy, came up to me and made a statementâ€”my portmanteau contained a dress coat and other thingsâ€”I was going to the Croydon Assizesâ€”it was not lookedâ€”my initials were on itâ€”I see them nowâ€”they have been painted out but have made their appearance sinceâ€”it cost me 12l. or 13l. to renew the things I lostâ€”these collars have my name on them.
Prisoner. Q. Can you take on yourself to state that it was me you saw? A. No; I have not said soâ€”I did not observe the person so as to be able to speak to him.

ELIZABETH HEALY . I live at 2, Rutland-terrace, Pimlicoâ€”on Monday morning, 5th August, I was at the Victoria stationâ€”I saw a portmanteau there, and I saw an old gentlemanâ€”I was sitting on the corner of the bench, opposite where they take the tickets for the Crystal Palace, and the old gentleman was on my left-hand aide, on the same Beatâ€”it was outside the waiting-roomâ€”I saw him take up the portmanteau and walk out as if he was going to the trainâ€”it was a portmanteau very like thisâ€”it was about a quarter to 11 o'clock, I think, as nearly as I can recollectâ€”the prisoner was the old gentleman I saw take the portmanteauâ€”I am sure of himâ€”I made a communication to the porter when the owner of the portmanteau came up and made inquiries, and described what I had seen.

COURT. Q. Was the portmanteau taken from the place where you saw Mr. Addison come to look for it? A. Yes, just that very spotâ€”it was all momentarily doneâ€”as I sat down, the old gentleman was in the act of risingâ€”I think there was a train just going to the Crystal Palaceâ€”he took it from the corner of a seatâ€”it was quite close to where he was.

Prisoner. Q. When do you say this occurred? A. On 5th Augustâ€”I said before the Magistrate that I did not know the day, but I have since ound out that it was 5th Augustâ€”I cannot tell when it was that I next saw youâ€”it was when I was called on to go to Westminster to identify you; I do not remember the dayâ€”I know it to be the 5th August, because my landlady had a child died that morningâ€”if I had seen you between 5th August and the 30th, I should have known youâ€”I think it was three or four weeks afterwards that I saw youâ€”I did not have any conversation with any policeman before I identified youâ€”a policeman came to leave the paper for me to appear, but I was not at home, and he left it with my landladyâ€”I think you carried the bag in your left hand, but I did not take that particular noticeâ€”I am sure it was youâ€”I caught a clear glance of your faceâ€”the sun was shining full on youâ€”I said I thought you were between fifty and sixty years of ageâ€”of course I could not judge a person's age momentarilyâ€”it was all done in two minutesâ€”it was not your stature that I noticed, it was your faceâ€”I did not say when you stood at the bar that I considered it was a much shorter man than you.
MR. SLEIGH Q. Have you any doubt whatever that the prisoner is the person you saw take the portmanteau? A. No, I have no doubt.

COURT. Q. Were you sent for to the police-office in order to identify him? A. Tea; I saw him in the Court at the bar, not with other personsâ€”I was asked if that was the man that took the portmanteau, and I said "Yes"â€”I did not exactly know at that time that he was the person charged with it, but I knew that was the business I was there upon.
Prisoner. Q. Was I not pointed out to you by some person as you came into court? A. No; I knew no person in court; they were all strangers to me.

GEORGE TAIT . I am a porter at the South Eastern Railway, London-bridgeâ€”I remember a gentleman coming to that station with a black leather bag about the middle of Augustâ€”I did not remember the day when I was at the police-court, but it was on the 12th Augustâ€”I put it down in a book at homeâ€”the gentleman gave me a carpet bag to look after while he went round the corner, and when he returned the bag was gone, and this one was put in its placeâ€”I tried to find an owner for itâ€”I went to every carriage in the train, first, second, and third class, and looked underneath the seats, but could not see any bag corresponding with the one that was lostâ€”I took this bag to the station-master, and then to the lost property officeâ€”I could not say that I saw the prisoner at the station that dayâ€”I have seen him there two or three times, but I cannot be sure when it was.
Prisoner. Q. What time was the bag left there? A. A little past 11; I should say from a quarter to twenty minutes past.

JOHN SANDERS HOLLOWAY . I am a clerk in the lost-property office at the South Eastern Railwayâ€”I remember a portmanteau being brought to me in August by the last witnessâ€”it was on 12th Augustâ€”it was deposited in my chargeâ€”there is a register label on it in my writingâ€”it remained in my care till 31st August; I then handed it to Carpenterâ€”it was then in the same state as when it was delivered to me.
Prisoner. Q. How long have you been at that station? A. Near upon five yearsâ€”I cannot say that I have seen you thereâ€”I have nothing to do with the passengersâ€”I am employed in the office.

JOHN CARPENTER . I am superintendent of the Brighton Railway Policeâ€”I received from the last witness the portmanteau now producedâ€”it is now in the same state as when he gave it to meâ€”it contains the same articlesâ€”
those articles were produced to Mr. Addison in my presence, and he identified them, and also the portmantean.

Prisoner. Q. You took all my papers from me; have you got the testimonial or the subscription list with respect to the hospital of St. Cross? A. I have not; I believe it is hereâ€”I delivered it over to our solicitors by the Magistrate's orderâ€”they gave a copy to your solicitorâ€”I told the Magistrate it was necessary I should detain. itâ€”I believed that I should have brought forward some cases against you in consequence of it, and I could have done soâ€”I have seen you at the Victoria station on several occasions within the last yearâ€”I stated that I had seen you on several occasions in waiting rooms on different occasions at a table, having a bag open with a large number of papers and documentsâ€”I saw you on two different occasions at the South Eastern Railway at a table looking at docu
ments, and once at the Victoria stationâ€”I cannot fix the dates, except the date of seeing you at the Victoria-station, and that was 10th Augustâ€”I have known you for several yearsâ€”I have seen you repeatedly for the last three years at the different railway-stationsâ€”the last time I saw you at the London-bridge station was about the latter end of July, or the beginning of August.

Prisoner's Defence. I had a witness here who could have proved a complete. alibi as far as 5th August is concerned, but she has left. I was at the Shakespeare Hotel that day at ten minutes past 10 o'clock. I went from there to Mr. Benjamin Bond Cabbellâ€™s, in Chapel-street, Edgeware-road, respecting the amalgamation of a new hospital with that of St. Cross; that gentleman gave me a cheque for 5l., on Scott's house, towards the expense I had been at with respect to St Cross' Hospital I went and purchased a stock of a person in the Edgeware-road, and tendered the cheque there; he did not know Mr. Cabbell, and therefore said he would send the stock I had purchased to the Shakespeare Hotel. He did so, and I came back and paid him; as he has left I have it not in my power to prove this, or I could have proved that by no possibility could I have been at the station at the time stated. I stayed at the hotel from ten minutes past 10 until about ten minutes pact 11, and never went from there. I was extremely lame at the time, and when I came out he assisted me out of the cab into the hotel He could also depose to my general infirmity since April.

GUILTY .â€”There were three other indictments against the prisoner.
Confined Eighteen Months.

3.
ALFRED JOHNSTON (22),
Stealing 9 Cashmere wrappers, value 13s. 6d. the property of
John Bundock, having been before convicted of felony; to which he

PLEADED GUILTY .â€”
Confined Nine Months.

4.
WILLIAM BRITTER (18)
, Feloniously forging and uttering a request for the delivery of 2 printed books, with intent to defraud
Joshua Whitehead Butterworth; to which he

PLEADED GUILTY .â€”
Confined Twelve Months.

5.
JOHN WILSON (59)
, Stealing a metal pot value 1s., the property of
Charles Dixon; also one other metal pot; to which he

PLEADED GUILTY .â€”
Confined Nine Months.

6.
WILLIAM MAURICE (30)
, Embezzling the sums of 25l., 206l. 7s. 6d., and 15l. 6s., also 20l. and 29l. 11s., 11d., which he had received on account of
George Penson his master; to all which he

PLEADED GUILTY .â€”
Four Years' Penal Servitude.
The prosecutor stated the amount of the prisoner's defalcations to be 310l.

7.
GEORGE HART (32)
, Feloniously forging and uttering an under-taking for the payment of 4l., with intent to defraud.

WILLIAM CLARK . I live at 39, Giffard-street, Kingsland-roadâ€”I am clerk and manager to Mr. John Jacobs, of Fiusbury-place, Southâ€”he advances money on loanâ€”I recollect this proposal coming, I think about 10th Septemberâ€”I afterwards saw the prisoner upon itâ€”I think he came the office on 17th Septemberâ€”I asked him his name and likewise the (name of his security; he said, a Jabez Goody nâ€”he came with a party who he represented as Jabez Goodyâ€”a clerk wrote out the guarantee, and I myself gate him the moneyâ€”I had not seen Jabez Goody before; I had made inquiry about himâ€”the prisoner had previously been there and said that Mr. Goody could not come up then, but he would on the Thursday eveningâ€”the prisoner was the applicant for the loanâ€”he signed this paper in my presenceâ€”I made inquiries as to Good's responsibility at 17 1/2 Clarence-street, Waterloo-town, Bethnal Greenâ€”I afterwards communicated to the prisoner that I had made inquiries about Goody; that was before I paid him the moneyâ€”I cannot tell the dateâ€”the next time I saw him was on 17th, about half-past 8 o'clock in the eveningâ€”he then had the other person with himâ€”I asked the prisoner his own nameâ€”he said, "George Hart"â€”I then asked the name of his security, and he said, "John Goody"â€”he pointed out the man with him as Jabez Goodyâ€”I then asked the clerk to make out the guarantee and the I.O.U., and after it was signed, I paid him the moneyâ€”this is the guarantee (produced)â€”it is signed "J. Goody" this was signed by the party who the prisoner brought, in his presenceâ€”I paid the prisoner 3l. 10s.â€”the money was to be lent at ten per cent, to repaid in instalments of 2s. a week-8s. was deducted for interest, and 2s. for book, rules and guarantee.

Prisoner. Q. When I took you the form, in consequence of some delay on your part in inquiring, did not Mr. Goody call at your office to know the cause of your delay? A. Yes; I think he didâ€”I mean the real Mr. Goodyâ€”I might have told him that the money could be obtained on the Tuesday night followingâ€”I cannot tax my memory whether I had then been to his houseâ€”I did go to his house, and saw his wifeâ€”I was satisfied from what she said that Mr. Goody had left word that he would be your securityâ€”I am sure you represented the party you brought on 17th to be Mr. Goodyâ€”Mr. Goody did not sign any paper the day he calledâ€”I believe you repaid two weeks money, 4s. and 7d., fineâ€”I did not receive any letter from you after that, stating that you were ill and would call and pay the moneyâ€”Mr. Jacobs told me that you had called on the Monday to pay the money, and that he had refused itâ€”you called on the Tuesday and were given in charge.

JABEZ GOODY . I live at 17 1/2, Clarence-street, Anglesea-street, Waterloo
town, Bethnal-greenâ€”I know the prisonerâ€”he came to ask me to become his securityâ€”I should say that was four months before 10th Septemberâ€”I would not swear to the dateâ€”it was either the latter end of June, or the beginning of Julyâ€”I told him I had already been surety for a loan and had been sued in the county court for the arrears, and I did not think any office would take my security, and I should not like to go up and offer myself and be rejectedâ€”I neither said that I would or that I would notâ€”the name of J. Goody on this guarrantee is not my writingâ€”I did not authorize anybody to sign my nameâ€”the prisoner called on me at my place of business about a fortnight after the loan was obtainedâ€”he

told me he had got the moneyâ€”I said, "What money?"â€”he said, "The loan wâ€”I said, "How did you get it?"â€”he said he had taken a person to represent himself to be me and to sign my name, and he did not think there was any harm in it, and I do not think that he did know there was any particular harm in it at the timeâ€”I told him that I should never acknowledge the signature, and he must take the responsibility on his own shoulders, and that if I was applied to I should decided say it was not my guar
antee, and that it was a false signature.

Prisoner. Q. When I first asked you to be my security, did not you promise that you would if they would accept you? A. No; I did not promise youâ€”I did not know that you were going to take in the form of applicationâ€”when I came home one day I found that a person had called, and I went up to the office that nightâ€”I believe I saw Mr. Clarkâ€”I told him my name was Goodyâ€”he said he was busy, and to let it stand over till the Thursdayâ€”this was on Tuesdayâ€”I asked him what application you had made, and he said, "To the amount of 4l"â€”I said, "Do not let him have it until you see" againâ€”you did not tell me, about a fortnight afterwards, that you were going to take the form in that night, nor did I promise to go to the office with youâ€”I did not ask you to wait another week that I might have my house in better order when they called to make the inquiryâ€”I did not tell you that I had, got a fire-glass and a carpet in pledge, and that I was going to get them out that week, and the place would look in better order when they calledâ€”I never had a fire-glass, and never had snob a thing in pledge.

CHARLES BAKER . I am a detective officer of the Cityâ€”I was called to 3, Finsbury-place, South, and took the prisoner into custodyâ€”he wished to make some statement; I said, "You are not forted to make any statement without you please; whatever you do may be given in evidence against youâ€”he said he was Tory sorry for what he had done; he did not know there was any harm in it; that he had got a person from a public-house opposite, to sign the name of Jabez Goodyâ€”I asked him if be knew the manâ€”he said he was a stranger to himâ€”he had never seen him before in this lifeâ€”(The guarantee was here put in and read).

Prisoner's Defence. If I have done wrong in this matter, I have done it entirely in ignorance; when I applied to Mr. Goody to become my security, he gave me a positive answer that he would do so; I told him I was going to apply for 4l. In consequence of some delay I called once or twice to know whether they had been there to make inquiry, and he said they had not; be thought they were a set of swindlers. He promised to go with me and get the money; I made two payments and was then taken ill I sent a letter stating the reason. I called on the Monday and they refused to take the money, saying the matter had gone too far, and I was to call on the Tuesday. I went on the Tuesday, and they then gave me into custody. I did not do it with the slightest intention of defrauding. Mr. Jacobs.

GUILTY .â€”Recommended to mercy by the Jury and pro
secutor.â€”
Confined Six Months.

8.
JAMES EVANS (23)
, Feloniously wounding
Sarah Mullens, with intent to do her grievous bodily harm.

SARAH MULLENS . I live at 14, Pye-street, Westminsterâ€”I have been living with the prisoner as his wife for twelve monthsâ€”I left him in consequence of going to the hospital for an accident I met with at Charing Crossâ€”I came out a week before this occurredâ€”I saw the prisoner when I came

outâ€”he promised to meet me at half-past 8 o'clock on the evening in questionâ€”I neglected to meet himâ€”I met with a friend and got drinkingâ€”I was rather intoxicated, and I went home to go to bedâ€”somebody who lodged in the house knocked at the door and asked for a lightâ€”that was about half-past 1 or 2 o'clock, I think, but I cannot say exactlyâ€”my room is the back parlourâ€”I thought I heard the prisoner's footsteps, and I said, "Here is Jim coming, come in"â€”I thought be would strike me, seeing me drinking with this manâ€”the man had a bottle of gin in his pocketâ€”I said to him, "Come in," and blew the candle outâ€”I had been drinking with him from half-past 8 in the evening, till that timeâ€”it was the same person that knocked at the door for the lightâ€”I told him to come in and fasten the doorâ€”the prisoner asked me to open itâ€”I did not take any noticeâ€”he said, "Sarah; I know you are indoors; if you don't open it, I'll burst it open"â€”he did burst it open, and ran over to the fire-place, and took up something and struck me in the armâ€”he also struck me on my headâ€”I cannot tell whether I struck him or notâ€”I ran away as well as I couldâ€”I did not see any knifeâ€”there was a short-bladed knife in the room which I had used in having my supperâ€”I cannot say whether I left that on the bed, or where it wasâ€”I was taken to the infirmary.

Prisoner. Q. When I knocked at the door, was not the man in bed with I you? A. Yes; he wasâ€”I was in my chemiseâ€”you had cautioned me against that man that very morning, and told me to have nothing to say to himâ€”the man said that if you put your head inside the door he would open it with the pokerâ€”I cannot say whether I struck youâ€”I was frightened that you would beat me, but I do not know what happened after you struck meâ€”you said to me, "Is this what you mean?" and then struck me with something from the fire-placeâ€”I told you that I had been drinking with this man all night, and that he had paid the landlord a week's rent for me, and that I had got drunk with him.

JOHN LAVIES . I am surgeon of St. Margaret's workhouseâ€”I saw the prosecutrix there on the Thursday afternoonâ€”she was exceedingly exhausted, apparently from loss of bloodâ€”she had a wound on the left side of her headâ€”it had been bound up by the medical man at the hospital, and I did not disturb it that day; she also had a wound about an inch and a half in length on the right arm, and a small wound on the left arm, also a very large graze on the left arm as if from a fight; and she was bruised consi
derably about the back and lower part of the personâ€”the wound on the arm was an incised wound, and that on the ear alsoâ€”it must have been done by some sharp instrumentâ€”after she had been in the hospital two or three days she lost a very large quantity of blood from the lower part of her personâ€”that was partly the result of the bruisingâ€”the incised wound was not a deep wound, nor that on the ear eitherâ€”part of the ear was cut completely through.

MARY ANN MULLENS . I am the prosecutrix's sisterâ€”about a quarter-past 3 o'clock on this morning, the prisoner knocked at my door and said he wanted to speak to meâ€”he told me he had been home, that my sister was at home, and that there was somebody there that had a poker in his hand, and he wrenched the poker out of his handâ€”I asked if he had struck her with itâ€”he said, "You will see her to-morrow morning, and she is a perfect object."

Q. Did not I say she would have something to show you, tat I could not help it after finding out what I did? A. Yes; you said you had found her in bed with one of the lodgersâ€”you did not say you had beat her for it.

JAMES WHITE (Policeman, B 45). I was near Pye-street on this nightâ€”I saw the prosecutrix come out of the house with nothing on but her chemise, bleeding from a wound in her armâ€”I took her to the hospitalâ€”they did not consider the case bad enough for her to remain thereâ€”I advised her to go home, but she would not for fear of the prisonerâ€”I then took her to the workhouseâ€”she became very ill thereâ€”I apprehended the prisoner three days afterwards in Union-street, Boroughâ€”he was concealed under a bedâ€”I told him to come out, and said I was a constable, and wanted him on a charge of cutting and woundingâ€”he said, "I did not stab her, but I knocked her about, and I am b----sorry I did not give her more."
Prisoner. Q. Did not I say I was sorry I did not catch the man and give him more? A. No; you said nothing about the man.

p.hi: The prisoner in his defence, stated that the man had threatened him with the poker, and that he wrenched it out of hit hand and beat the prosecutrix, and threw her on the bed, but did not use any knife.

div1.p:
9.
EBENEZER PRICE JONES (35)
, Unlawfully obtaining goods on credit within three months of his bankruptcy, under the false colour and pretence of dealing in the ordinary course of trade; also, for removing, con
cealing, and embezzling certain quantities of goods with intent to defraud his creditors; also, for concealing certain books relating to his personal estate, with a like intent; to which he

PLEADED GUILTY .â€”

p.hi:
There were two other indictments for not surrendering to the Court of Bank

div1.p:
10.
EDWARD MALANDER (38)
, Stealing 10 gas burners and 15 gas branches, the property of
Francis Wyatt Truscott and others, and after
wards burglariously breaking out of the said dwelling-house; to which he

PLEADED GUILTY .â€”
Confined Six Months.

11.
GEORGE ERNEST SMITH (28)
, Feloniously marrying
Elizabeth Susannah Witherden, his wife being then alive; to which he

PLEADED GUILTY â€”
Confined Eighteen Months.

12.
JOHN CARPENTER (20)
, Stealing a watch, value 10l. the pro
perty of
George McArthur, from his person, having been before convicted of felony; to which he

PLEADED GUILTY .**â€”
Four Years' Penal Servitude.

div0.p: PRESENTâ€”Mr. Ald. CARTER; Mr. Ald. MECHI; and Mr. COMMON SERJEANT.

div1.p:
13.
WILLIAM JOHNSON (32), and
JOSEPH BEAN (24)
, Stealing 1681bs. of lead, of
Richard Marshall Phillips and others, in a barge, in a port.

JOHN WILLIAM CORTY . I am in the employ of Phillips and Company, lightermenâ€”on Saturday week I took the barge Star to the ship Ellen, and moored her off the Custom-house Quayâ€”I took 655 pigs of lead from the

Ellen and put them into the Starâ€”I stowed them in fives; they were thirteen rows high, with fifty in each, and. five overâ€”I dropped her down fifty or sixty yards, to where we moon our craft, and went ashore a very little after five, leaving no one on the bargeâ€”I returned to the barge at ten minutes or a quarter past five, with George Burke and Vorleyâ€”I saw man on the pile of lead, and the moment he saw me he sprang over into his boatâ€”I ran forward and said, "Hollo! what do you want?"â€”he said, "I have got nothing! I have got nothing!"â€”I sprang into the barge, and missed three pigs off the foremost pile against the bulkâ€”headâ€”I sang out, "Police"â€”I saw one man in the skiff and another in the bargeâ€”I believe the prisoners are the men.

Cross-examined by MR. RIBTON. Q. Was there anybody with you when on counted the pigs? A. No; but I had to sign the mate's book for itâ€”he is not hereâ€”he delivered them to me, and the tide surveyor is supposed to count themâ€”I had been apprenticed to a lighterman, named Cannaway, two years or betterâ€”there are no books here; my signature is enoughâ€”it took me about three hours and a half to load the pigsâ€”I cannot make a mistake in the number, because I put them five each way and ten high, that is fiftyâ€”I have never made a mistake in counting lead or anything else that I am aware ofâ€”if I make a mistake I must pay for it, and that makes me carefulâ€”there were five over, which were stowed by themselves.
MR. KEMP. Q. Were the piles all the same height? A. Yesâ€”when I delivered them two were deficient.

GEORGE BURKE . I am in the service of Messrs. Phillips and Companyâ€”on the evening of last Saturday week I went with Wyatt, Corty, and Vorley to the Ellenâ€”when we got there I saw the prisoner Bean on the gunwale of the barge, and Johnson in their boatâ€”Bean was easing a pig of lead down to Johnsonâ€”I jumped out of our boat on to the barge gunwale, walked on the cabin top, and shouted out, "Police"â€”no police were nearâ€”I said to my companions, "Stop them, Charley"â€”the prisoners could hear what I saidâ€”my companions rowed after them, and Wyatt got hold of a bit of rope attached to their boat and turned it, and we made the best of our way to the shoreâ€”when they had got hold of the rope I heard one of the prisoners say to the other, "Throw them overboard," and Bean immediately did soâ€”Johnson, who was rowing, got up from his sculls and assisted in throwing the lead overboardâ€”I saw the lead, and saw and heard the splashâ€”it was thrown overboard from the prisoner's boat.

Cross-examined by MR. RIBTON. Q. How far were you from the boat they were in, when you first saw anything of them? A. I should say it was as far or a little farther than from me to that door. (About thirty-five yards)â€”that was when I saw the lead being thrown overâ€”there was a heavy splash in the waterâ€”it was between 5 and 6 o'clockâ€”when I saw the man stand
ing on the gunwale of the barge I was about five or six yards from the boatâ€”I am sure it was Bean who was on the gunwaleâ€”I do not know that some of the other witnesses say it was Johnsonâ€”I heard the witnesses at the police-court, but I did not hear them say thatâ€”I knew Bean beforeâ€”a pig of lead weighs very nearly a hundredweightâ€”directly he gave the pig of lead to Johnson I said, "Holloa, there!" and he jumped into the boat and shoved away from the barge, and then they went offâ€”I could swear that there were two pigs of lead thrown into the waterâ€”I cannot say what depth the river is there, but it is further out than low water markâ€”it is off the Custom-house Quay, a tidy bit below London-bridgeâ€”attempts have been made to pick the lead upâ€”they have not been foundâ€”the police boat has searched several
timesâ€”they began to search on the same eveningâ€”the lead could not have floated away.
MR. KEMP. Q. Is the river very muddy there? A. There is a great deal of dirt and muckâ€”when I first saw the man on the gunwale, our boat was on the other side of the barge, alongside of it.

CHARLES WYATT . On the evening of last Saturday week, I accompanied Burke, Vorley, and Corty to the Ellenâ€”I saw Bean handing a pig of lead to Johnson over the bargeâ€”Bean was on the gunwale of the bargeâ€”Johnson was in their skiff on the other side of the bargeâ€”when I saw them put the lead into the barge I let our boat drift astern and caught hold of their boat, and then Bean hit me on the head with one of the scullsâ€”I caught hold of a piece of rope in their boat and made it fast to our boat, and one of our men towed them ashore; while doing so I beard the prisoners say, "Let's throw them overboard;" and then I saw them throw two pigs of lead overboardâ€”I was then about two or three yards from them in our skiff, and they were in theirsâ€”the boats were then tied togetherâ€”I am quite sure they are the menâ€”I knew them before by sight.

Cross-examined by MR. RIBTON. Q. Were you with Burke? A. Yes; in the boatâ€”he got aboard the barge, and I stopped in the boatâ€”I saw the man on the gunwale of the barge, handing the pig of lead overâ€”there was no one but Bean and Johnson in their boatâ€”the man that rowed them ashore had not got in.

GEORGE THOMAS VORLEY . On the evening of last Saturday week I went with Carter, Burke, and Wyatt in a boat to the Ellenâ€”when I got to the barge I saw the two prisoners in their skiffâ€”I cannot say what they were doing; my eyes were not on themâ€”they were trying to row away from usâ€”our boat was then fastened to their'sâ€”I did not hear either of them say anythingâ€”I saw Johnson heave the lead overboardâ€”the other was sitting on the foremost thwart, he had been pullingâ€”he ceased pullingâ€”I was close to them when the lead was thrown overboard; sufficiently close to see what it was.

Cross-examined by MR. GMTT. Q. What time was this? A. Between 5 and 6 o'clockâ€”it was darkâ€”I sat on the fore thwart of our boat, facing their boat; about as far as I am from you nowâ€”I had no light, but we could make them out; it was not so dark as all thatâ€”I could see at that distance in the darkâ€”I saw Johnson ease the lead overboardâ€”if a thing is of any size I could see it at that distance in the darkâ€”it has not been found since that I am aware ofâ€”I should think it would not move down the riverâ€”two were thrown over.
MR. KEMP. Q. How much do the pigs weigh? A. Some are one hundredweight and a half, some one hundredweight and three-quarters.

WILLIAM BATHO . I am foreman to Messrs. Kitter and Marshall, of Rood
aneâ€”between 5 and 6 o'clock on Saturday evening I was at Costom-house Quayâ€”I saw the prisonersâ€”one was in a boat, an a the other one stepped out of a boat into a decked bargeâ€”I do not know the name of the bargeâ€”I saw Johnson making his escapeâ€”he said, "I am not going away; I thought somebody was overboardâ€”I went and looked at him in the boatâ€”he said, "Let us stow the boat, she belongs to a poor man; we don't want to detain the boat"â€”he said nothing more to me; nothing about knowing where to find themâ€”they were not rowing the boat thenâ€”they had come on shore, by two hands towing themâ€”I gave them in custodyâ€”there were two others with themâ€”I did not allow them to go were they wishedâ€”they stepped into the boat, and, instead of taking them where they wanted to go, I rowed them

to the policeâ€”the ship Ellen was my master's; the Star was hiredâ€”the property was not my master's; it was a merchant'sâ€”I did not count the pigs of lead when they were taken out, nor was I present when they were countedâ€”a pig of lead is about eighteen inches long and four or five inches broad, round at the topâ€”to the best of my belief the value of a pig is about 30s.

Cross-examined by MR. GENT. Q. Are these pigs very large? A. No; they would make a splash if thrown into the waterâ€”a pig weighs under a hundredweightâ€”a man could easily lift one with two handsâ€”it was a very dark nightâ€”it was between 5 and 6 o'clockâ€”they said they thought there was a row, and that there was some one overboard.

JURY to JOHN WILLIAM CORTY. Q. Was the barge between the two boats? A. Yes; when I returned to the Star, our boat was inside and their's outsideâ€”the barge was about three feet above the water, but the witnesses could see what was going on on the other side of her, because our boat was a foot above the water.
GUILTY .
BEAN was further charged with having been before convicted in October, 1850; to which he

PLEADED GUILTY.â€”
Confined Nine Months each.

14.
GEORGE RYAN (23)
, Stealing 46 yards of flannel, the property of
Robert Wickerman and others; to which he

PLEADED GUILTY .â€”
Confined Six Months.

15.
EDWIN PULLEN (29)
, Embezzling the sums of 4l. 6s. 1d., 14s. 9 1/2 d.; and 10s. 4 1/2 d.; also, the sums of 2l. 12s. 7d., 3l. 2s. 10d. the property of
John Mixer, his master; to both which he

PLEADED GUILTY .â€”
Confined Nine Months.

16.
JOHN FITZGIBBON (32)
, Stealing 24 files, the property of
Thomas Morgan.

THOMAS MORGAN . I am a civil engineer of 4, Lothburyâ€”I have em
ployed the prisoner as a porterâ€”on Wednesday, 6th November, about 12 o'clock, I employed him to remove some property to Moorgate-street, among which there was twenty-four dozen filesâ€”I paid him for his day's-work, and on the next day I missed four dozen of the filesâ€”I returned to the office in Lothbury, and found two dozen in a desk where they ought not to have beenâ€”I had not placed them thereâ€”I afterwards saw the prisoner and said, "Where are the two dozen files?" holding the other two dozen in my handâ€”he said, I know nothing of themâ€”I gave him in custodyâ€”they are worth 1l. 13s.

Cross-examined by MR. POLAND. Q. Were you moving all your property? A. Yesâ€”there was no confusion, the prisoner did it allâ€”he was engaged to do it as quick as he could, and it took him about an hour and a halfâ€”I was in and out during the timeâ€”I had no persons in my employmentâ€”the prisoner hung the key up in a neighbour's office, when we were in and outâ€”I saw him when he had done; my friend paid himâ€”my friend did not assist in the removal; he is not hereâ€”I did not pay the prisoner myself, because I had not agreed to pay himâ€”after the removal was over, the place at Lothbury was locked up, and the key was left in the next door office, which was always locked up, and nobody could get in; there was always a man at the top of the stairsâ€”I had employed the prisoner four or five times before, and always found him honestâ€”he has formerly been in the Armyâ€”

I supposed him to belong to the Society of Commissionairesâ€”I was present before the Magistrate when the prisoner made a statement, on the day after he was given in custodyâ€”he said that he had left the files at a baker's shopâ€”he did not say that he went back to the shop and got the files, and then found that the office was shutâ€”he said that he left them at the baker's shop, and we should perhaps find them thereâ€”they were pro
duced at that time before the Magistrate.
MR. HORRY. Q. Were the files in the desk part of the property he had to remove? A. Yes; but they were not in that desk.

RICHARD SMITH , (City-policeman, 133). On the afternoon of November 7th, the prisoner was given into my custody, charged with stealing two dozen filesâ€”when Mr. Morgan accused him, he said, "I know nothing about it"â€”I took him to the stationâ€”I asked him where he lived, he said, 5, Alfred-place, Kent-roadâ€”I went there and found that there were four number fives, and that he did not live at either of themâ€”I returned and told him I could not find itâ€”he said, "You will find it No. 5, Alfred-street, Park-road, Peckham"â€”the one place is a long distance from the otherâ€”I went to 5, Alfred-street, Park-road, Peckham, to a room on the ground floor, and his wife brought me one dozen files, fastened up as they are now (produced)â€”I got eight other files from a shelf in the cupboard.

Cross-examined. Q. Was the place where you found the files about thirty yards from the Old Kent-road? A. Much more than that, some eight or nine minutes walk; not near Camberwellâ€”I do not know anything of the Kent-roadâ€”I do not know that Park-road runs out of the Old Kent-road into Peckhamâ€”I could not find the place, and the prisoner gave me a more specific directionâ€”I mean that it is eight or nine minutes walk from Alfred-street, Kent-road, to Alfred-street, Peckhamâ€”I do not know that part, though I know my way to itâ€”the prisoner said that he had left the files at a baker's shop, but did not say that he afterwards got them from there, but could not deliver them as the office was closed; but his wife said so, and that when he left home in the morning he forgot to take them with himâ€”he wears two medals on his breastâ€”I did not take them awayâ€”I took some pawnbroker's tickets, but found nothing against himâ€”I was in uniformâ€”the prisoner did not tell me before I went to the lodging that I, should find the things thereâ€”he did not tell me that I might go and search; but I told him I should do soâ€”it was after that he gave me the right addressâ€”he told me that they were at the baker's shop in Coleman-street, and I went there and found he had left some there and taken them away again.
The prisoner's statement before the Magistrate was here read as follows: "Your Worship, I am as innocent as you are of the charge."
NOT GUILTY .

div0.p:
PRESENTâ€”SIR
FRANCIS GRAHAM MOON , Bart. Ald.; Mr. RECORDER; Mr. Ald. MECHI; Mr. Ald. HALE; and Mr. Ald. DAKIN

div1.p:
17.
ROBERT WATSON (61)
, Stealing 1 cape, value 15s. the pro
perty of
Joseph Bennett; I coat, the property of
Edward Isaac Blumenthal; I coat, the property of
Augustus Windham; and 1 coat, the property of
William George Dunsford; having been before convicted of felony; to which he

PLEADED GUILTY .**â€”
Four Years' Penal Servitude ,

18.
JOHN AYLING (15)
, Stealing 1 10l. note, and 1 5l. note, the property of
Charles Edward Thomas, his master.

CHARLES EDWARD THOMAS . I am an oil merchant in Barking church-yardâ€”the prisoner was in my employment as an errand boy, and was em
ployed about the shopâ€”on 28th October, I left town for a few daysâ€”in a drawer behind the counter I left, among other things, a 10l. note and a 5l. noteâ€”this is the 5l. note (produced)â€”I know it by my signatureâ€”on my return on 1st November, I found both the notes missingâ€”from inquiries I made I found that a 5l. note had been changed at Mr. Bentley's, a neigh
boursâ€”immediately I missed the notes I spoke to the prisoner, and he disowned all knowledge of themâ€”he said he knew nothing about it; he had never seen any note; what good were the notes to him; he could not change themâ€”I then told him that he must know something of them, for no one else would hare gone to the drawer to take them outâ€”the drawer was unlockedâ€”it was a goods drawer behind the counterâ€”it is not likely any one would go to it unless they had seen me place the money away; which the prisoner did, some fortnight beforeâ€”he disowned all knowledge until the next day, Saturdayâ€”I then asked him to tell me what he bad done with the notesâ€”he said he bad never seen the notes; what good were they to himâ€”I challenged him with it three or four times; at last he owned that he had changed the 5l. note at Mr. Bentley'sâ€”I then asked him what he had done with the moneyâ€”he said he bad given it to a sailor to mindâ€”I said that tale would not doâ€”he then made two or threerother statements, that he had bought a purse and put the money into it, and had lost it on Tower-hillâ€”at last he acknowledged that 4l. 10s. was hid in the cellar at his own houseâ€”I went there with him, and found four sovereigns and two halves on a beam in the cellarâ€”I then asked if he had buried the 10l. note thereâ€”he said, no he had not seen itâ€”I gave him until the Monday to tell me where the note was, and he then said, "The dog brought the note down to me in the cellar, and I burnt it over the gas"â€”he then said he had hid it in the dust-hole, and after we had half-emptied that, he said he did not know anything of the note at allâ€”I gave him into custodyâ€”the 10l. note has not been found.

Prisoner. He did not tell me anything at all about the 10l. note, only the 5l. Witness. I told him I had lost two notes, and asked him to ac
count for them, feeling sure that no one else could have taken themâ€”there was no one else there but him and my wifeâ€”the notes were wrapped up together.
RICHARD ADYE BAILT . I am a clerk in the Bank of Englandâ€”I produce the 5l. note from the Bank.

JOHN BENTLEY . I am a cheesemonger, and live at 35, Great Tower-streetâ€”I know the prisoner by his living at Mr. Thomas'sâ€”on 31st October, he brought me this 5l. note, and asked if I would oblige Mr. Thomas with changeâ€”I gave him 2l. 10s. in gold, and 2l. 10s. in silverâ€”I paid the note into Messrs. Hankey's on the Saturday following.
Prisoner. You gave me four sovereigns and two halves, you did not give me any silver. Witness. I am sure I gave him silver.
Prisoner's Defence. On the Thursday morning as I was sweeping the shop out, I found a piece of paper; I did not know what it was. My mistress told

me to make haste and sweep behind the counter, and she must have gone to the drawer and taken the 5l. note out and put it on the floor to see if I was a thief; I put it in my pocket, and when my mistress sent me for some butter, I asked Mr. Bentley to give me change, and I put the money down in the cellar, so that if Mr. Thomas had asked me anything about it I should have given it to him; if not, I should have kept it; he asked me about the 5l. note, but never said a word about the 10l. note until the Saturday; he then said, "Are you going to deliver me up that 10l. note"I said I did not know anything about a 10l. note; I told him about the 5l. note, and took him to the cellar and gave him the money.

GUILTY .â€”Recommended to mercy by the Jury in consequence of the loose manner in which the prosecutor kept his money.
Judgment Respited.

19.
EMMA WADE (36)
, Stealing a purse containing 2l. 10s. 7d. the property of
John Williams, from his person.

JOHN WILLIAMS . I live at 13, Swan-lane, Upper Thames-streetâ€”on Saturday, 3d November, a little after 12 o'clock, I was walking down Swan-lane, I did not see the prisonerâ€”I heard a person come behind me, and she pat her left arm round my neck, and put her right-hand into my pocket, without any previous conversationâ€”she took my port-monnaie with one sovereign, three half-sovereigns, a fourpenny piece, and a threepenny pieceâ€”it was the prisonerâ€”she then walked awayâ€”I did not know she had taken my purse at that timeâ€”I walked to my door and then found I had lost my purse I instantly followed her to the top of Swan-lane, and gave her in the custody of a policemanâ€”she was taken to the station and searchedâ€”this is my purse (produced).

Prisoner. Q. Did not you commence talking to me when you came out of the public-house, and say if I came down the steps with you, you would give me something to drink? A. No; I had not seen you beforeâ€”I did not give you a fourpenny piece, and say that was all I hadâ€”you did not pick up the purse, and I claim it as mineâ€”I never claimed my puree till the Inspector showed it to me.

ANN ALFORD . I am searcher of female prisoners at Bow-lane police-stationâ€”the prisoner was brought there on this Saturday nightâ€”I took her to the searching-room, and she pulled out a purse from her bosom, which contained one sovereign, three half-sovereigns, a fourpenny piece, and a threepenny piece; I also found on her, three other purses, a pair of scissors, a knife, another fourpenny piece, 3 1/2 d. in copper, and a pair of spectacles.

THOMAS EAVES (City-policeman, 465). The prosecutor gave the prisoner into my charge for stealing his purseâ€”the prisoner said all the money she had got about her was 3 1/4 d.
GUILTY .â€”
Confined Nine Months.

20.
JOHN HURRY (45)
, Stealing 3s. 1 1/2 d. the property of
Samuel Ellis, his master; to which he

PLEADED GUILTY .â€”
Confined Nine Months.

21.
ALGERNON SYDNEY LUMBY (40), was indicted
for stealing 100l. the property of the
Eastern Counties Railway Company, his masters.
MR. SERJEANT BALLANTINE with MR. TINDAL ATKIKINSON conducted the Prosecution.

WILLIAM HATCHY SPROULE . I am chief clerk in the booking-office of the Eastern Counties Railway Companyâ€”in February, 1860, the prisoner was in the employment of the Eastern Counties Companyâ€”his duties were to count the money at the different stations.
MR. METCALFE. Q. Was there any written agreement with him? A. I do not know; I never saw any.

MR. ATKINSON. Q. Was it also a portion of his duty, when monies were collected, to take them to the bank? A. Yes; the money was sent up from the various stations in cash-boxesâ€”I was a party to sending the money to the bank when it was readyâ€”on 15th February, 1860, the prisoner brought a statement in writing, naming the various coins, in cheques, notes, gold, silver, &c.â€”that statement contains an account of the monies, the subject of this indictmentâ€”it is in his handwritingâ€”it relates to a sum of money which he had in his hands to convey to the bankâ€”the money I had was added to that, and a statement was made out of the total sum I entrusted him withâ€”this (produced) is it; it is in my handwriting; it is 2,510l. 16s. 9d.â€”it consisted of cheques, 1,263l. 6s. 8d. notes, 165l.; gold, 733l. 10s.; and silver, 349l. 0s. 1d.; total, 2,510l. 16s. 9d.â€”when the book was made up, it was handed to the prisoner with the moneyâ€”I can state of my own knowledge that that was done on 15th Februaryâ€”he then leftâ€”he never returned after thatâ€”I am not aware whether any search was made for the bookâ€”it was found upon his desk under some papers, I think the same afternoonâ€”when the book went to the bank it was the duty of the bank clork to initial it as being correct.

Cross-examined by MR. METCALFE. Q. Where do you get the items to enter in this book? A. From this rough bookâ€”I call this little book the banker's receipt-bookâ€”I make entries in the rough-bookâ€”I got the items partly from the cheques I received myself, and the other part from the Statements you have in your handâ€”the money the prisoner had to take to the bank consisted not only of what he had received at the different stations, but also what I had received at the principal stationâ€”I make up the aggregate, and enter it into the book and pay it over to himâ€”I keep separate in this rough-book what I receive and what he receives; you will see there a large sum of 1,200l. I think, and a smaller sum of 15l. under
neath, that is the quantity received by Lumby; and then on the left-hand you will perceive the letters C, and S, C being the notes received by me, and 8 the notes received by the prisoner, and both added together will be the total amount of notes sent, entered in the banker's bookâ€”you can trace each entry from that book, I thinkâ€”1,247l. in cheques was received by me that day; under that is the notes received by me and him added together, and then the gold and silverâ€”the word "stations" means the cheques received by himâ€”this is all in my handwritingâ€”I do not know whether I made a mistake originally in adding up this amountâ€”it is merely a rough-book, not an official bookâ€”there appear to be some alterationsâ€”I copy from this into the little book that the prisoner takes to the bankâ€”I do not receive the actual coin that he bringsâ€”I do not count it at allâ€”the banker counts itâ€”no one on the prisoner's behalf, except himself would count itâ€”the amounts coming from the different stations would be counted by the station masters, and checked by the prisoner, so that I can ascertain whether this does pro
perly represent the amounts received from the different stations that dayâ€”this 1,133l., 17s. 3d. is the aggregate of the money received by him from the different stations that dayâ€”I could, by inquiry, ascertain whether he has given a correct account of the money received by him; but that is not my provinceâ€”I can scarcely say how many stations are included in that accountâ€”it represents nearly all the stations, except the banking stations, such as Norwich and Cambridge, and large stations of that sort; they pay direct to the local banksâ€”the district stations round Cam
bridge

do not pay to the Cambridge bank, they send up to usâ€”the prisoner had to check all those sumsâ€”each box is checked at the station, and then checked again by the prisonerâ€”they should be counted over by himâ€”it comes up in small parcels, and must be counted by him before it goes to the bankâ€”we have a sort of invoice or note sent up from each stationâ€”it is the duty of the prisoner to check the amount with the ticket so sent upâ€”he had other duties to perform also; he had to obtain money from the bank in order to send to the different stations to pay salaries and wagesâ€”that would come to a good dealâ€”he had to go down to Stratfordâ€”he had about 3,000l. a week to pay thereâ€”he had to obtain the money in gold and silver and pay it himselfâ€”I believe there are about 1,500 men employed thereâ€”he had also to attend at the Brick-lane station every fort
night, and pay the wages thereâ€”there are about 700 men thereâ€”that would come to about 1,200l. a weekâ€”the result of all the business would be that about 20,000l. a week would be passing through his bandsâ€”he had to keep account of all the sums he paid and receivedâ€”he had the pay lists signed or checked off as having been paidâ€”if he made a mistake he would lose the moneyâ€”if he paid a man too much, or accidentally gave him a sovereign instead of a shilling, he would be the loser; or if he took any bad coin at any of the stationsâ€”it was his duty to examine every bit of coin that came into his handsâ€”I recollect one of the clerks at Brick-lane being deficient in his cash; he overpaid, I think, about 5l.â€”I may occasionally have made mistakes in my calculations; we are all liable to mistakesâ€”this book is manly a rough book, and must check itself before the banker's book is made up, because the two sums added together must make one total; and if we make a mistake in detail it comes outâ€”nobody checks that book, it it merely a rough book.

Q. How do you find out mistakes? A. I have a total say of 1,000l., and the prisoner 500l., that ought to make 1,500l. if it is 1,510l. I go through it againâ€”a mistake of that sort must be detectedâ€”if I carried out the mistake in the other book, then the banker would check the amountâ€”if I made a mistake in the rough book, and carried out the mistake in the little book, the prisoner would not be the loser.
COURT. Q. Does he see that you are right before be goes to the banker's with the book? A. Yes.

MR. METCALFE. Q. When? A. At the time; and he also sees the money that I make upâ€”the cheques are called over to him by meâ€”he counts over the money that I give to himâ€”I make the entry from the ticket that he gives meâ€”that ticket is not checked by anybodyâ€”I make an entry from the ticket, and he goes to the bank with his money and mineâ€”after I have made out the aggregate in my rough book, the prisoner makes out a ticket for the bank in the way that anybody that has a banker makes it out; so many cheques, so much gold, and so much silverâ€”the prisoner makes it out after I have made out the aggregate in my rough bookâ€”he makes out in my presence what is called the banker's docket.

Q. Do you or any of the clerks change money before it goes to the bank, supposing you want change for a 50l. or 100l. note, do you put in the note and take out the gold? A. No; it is handed to the prisoner to cash, the same as you would to any other personâ€”I never take it myself, I hand it to the prisonerâ€”it has never been done when the money has been made up or after the book has been made up; it cannot be doneâ€”I am quite sure that has not been done cither by me or anybody in the officeâ€”gold has never been given in change for notes after the money-bags have been made

up, or silverâ€”I never recollect on any occasion that being doneâ€”none of the directors could have sent for change and change been given out of those bags after the money had been made up for the bank, and entered in that bookâ€”before the money is made up for the bank an alteration may take place, but after it is made up no alteration ever takes placeâ€”I never recollect such a thing being done while we were making up the moneyâ€”to the best of my knowledge it has never been done while the prisoner has been counting his moneyâ€”no doubt change has frequently been given before it has been made up in bulkâ€”it is not usual to change 100l. in silver for 100l. in goldâ€”itâ€”is generally change of a note or chequeâ€”we generally provide from the bank a sufficient quantity of silver to pay the wagesâ€”change for a cheque or a note has been given, but no other change has been necessaryâ€”it has never been done in the prisoner's absence to my knowledgeâ€”I was cashier at that timeâ€”I am now in the booking office; that is not so respon
sible a position as cashierâ€”I went from the the booking office to the cashier's and then went back to the booking-officeâ€”the clerks are required to insure in the Guarantee Society, not every one of themâ€”I do notâ€”I am an exceptionâ€”I give securityâ€”I believe it is now compulsory upon all the clerks to insure in the Guarantee Society.

MR. SERJEANT BALLANTINE. Q. How often does it occur that this transac
tion of taking money to the bank takes place? A. Daily, in the afternoonâ€”when I was the head cashier it would be the prisoner's duty to come and bring his documents and whatever money he had collectedâ€”the whole had to be taken to the bankâ€”before that was done the prisoner separated the money into the different divisions, in my presence, or during the time I was in the officeâ€”it was part of my duty to take his statement and to enter it in the book; and then the ticket was given in accordance with itâ€”I had 50l. salary as chief cashierâ€”he was under meâ€”he had 160l.â€”I never knew him complain of having received a false note, or of having had to make up any money deficiencyâ€”he never appeared again after that day, when he went to the bankersâ€”it would have been his duty to come back to the office again, and he did not.

MR. METCALFE. Q. About that time was there a station-master at Blackwell who was accused by the company of being abort in his accounts? A. Somewhere about that timeâ€”I think it was at that timeâ€”he was a station-master who had to remit a portion of these very monies.

MR. SERJEANT BALLANTINE. Q. But as I understand whether the station-master at Blackwall or anywhere else had been guilty of defalcations it was the-money brought into your office that had to be accounted for to the banker? A. Yes; and that only.

EDWARD JOHN LITTLETON . In February last I was cashier at the Union Bank, the Eastern Counties Railway Company bank at that establishmentâ€”I know the prisoner; he was in the daily habit of bringing money to the bank for the Railway Companyâ€”he also brought a book with him which we call the banker's receipt-bookâ€”I have not the books necessary to refresh my memory from the bankâ€”I do not recollect his coming on 15th Februaryâ€”it is so long ago that I do not remember the particular dayâ€”my initials are not to the entry in this book on 15th Februaryâ€”they are on every day about that time, with that exception, in relation to the sums of money received from the Companyâ€”there are several entries after that day, the next dayâ€”I can tell you how much money the prisoner brought in on 15th February, on reference to that book; otherwise it is a question of memory with me.
COURT. Q. Is there any entry of yours in that book? A. I have made a marginal note on the next day.
MR. METCALFE. Q. When did you make that note? A. Next day when the book was brought to me to sign, not when the prisoner brought the money.

MR. SERJEANT BALLANTINE. Q. Do you recollect the prisoner bringing the book the following day? A. No, he did not come, and I then made a memorandumâ€”I am able to say on looking at that memorandum how much money the prisoner brought on the preceding day.

COURT. Q. Did you at that time remember the exact amount he had brought? A. I referred to my books; finding a deficiency of 100l. by referring to my books and to the docket, I could tell the amount he brought to meâ€”I had no other meansâ€”I presume the books are at the bank; they are not in my custodyâ€”I did not make an entry in the pass book of the money I receivedâ€”that was done by another party.

p.hi: The Court was of opinion that in the absence of the books, there was no case to go to the Jury.

div1.p: NOT GUILTY .

22.
ALGERNON SIDNEY LUMBY was again indicted
for embezzling and stealing the sums of 23l. 15s. on 28th January, and 28l. 10s., on 11th February, received on account of the
Eastern Counties Railway Company, his masters.

JOHN CHARLES PHIPPS . I am cashier at the Brick-lane goods station of the Eastern Counties Railwayâ€”I have been cashier there for upwards of six yearsâ€”I know the prisonerâ€”in February 1860, he was in the service of the Companyâ€”his duty was to receive monies at the cashier's office at the Bishopsgate stationâ€”on 28th January, I paid some monies to the prisonerâ€”I produce his receipt for the amount paid that dayâ€”(Read: "Eastern Counties Railway, received from J. C. Phipps, on account of Brick-lane station, Friday, January 28th, five cheques, 17l. 12s. 9d., gold, 1l. 10s., silver, 101l. 10s., copper, 5l. 5s. total 175l. 17s. 9d., signed, A. Lumby")â€”that was the amount of the remittance from that stationâ€”I have another receipt of 11th Februaryâ€”(This being read, was for 219l. 18s. 6d. signed, A. Lumby.

Cross-examined by MR. METCALFE. Q. Although they appear to be paid on Friday, were they not paid by you on the Saturday? A. Yes; I personally paid the money and received the receipt myselfâ€”the prisoner counted all the money when he took it, except the silverâ€”I am not certain whether he counted the silver at the timeâ€”the coppers would be done up in 5s. packetsâ€”I am not aware whether there was any loose copperâ€”I made up the money myself, counted it all, and placed it in the bags myselfâ€”the prisoner had to pay the wages at the Brick-lane station every fortnight, on the Friday or Saturdayâ€”I am not sure whether the 11th and 27th were days on which he paid the wagesâ€”I do not recollectâ€”he had to pay a great deal of silver away when he paid the wagesâ€”I do not recollect the amount he had to payâ€”it was several hundred poundsâ€”I have sometimes reserved the silver for him at his request, to deliver to him when he came down to Brick-lane to pay the wages, and have got his receipt for the whole amountâ€”I do not know that on those occasions the silver was entered in this book instead of the account bookâ€”I have not got the wages account book hereâ€”I have nothing to do with itâ€”I have frequently reserved the silver for him on pay daysâ€”I am not positive whether I did so or not on these two particular daysâ€”I myself took up a ticket of the actual amount I sent to the stationâ€”if the
ticket was produced, it would show the actual amount that was paid into prisoner's handsâ€”I do not know where that ticket is.

MR. SERJEANT BALLANTINE. Q. It would be in the possession of the prisoner, would it not? A. I left it with himâ€”this is the receipt he gave meâ€”I leave a copy of it with the moneyâ€”it was at the cashier's office at the Bishopsgate-station that I paid him over these two sums of moneyâ€”it would be some time in the forenoonâ€”I have known him to come down to Brick-lane to pay the wages about one or two o'clockâ€”I cannot say exactly the hour at which he received these sums of money from me; as near as I can recollect it would be about 11 or 12â€”I did not pay him over the money the purpose of the wagesâ€”I believe he got it from the cashier at Shoreditchâ€”the silver was given to him in a bagâ€”I believe it was his duty to ascertain that the amount was correctâ€”as I said before, he did not always count the silver in my presence, but he did the notes, the gold, and the chequesâ€”I have no doubt whatever that the silver I handed over to him on these occasions, was as much as be gave me the receipt for.

COURT. Q. You said that at his request you sometimes reserved the silver for him? A. Yes; he did not give me anything in lies of it, when I reserved itâ€”if it was the day for paying the wages he has said to me,"Phipps, I shall require your silver at Brick-lane, so you need not trouble to bring it up"â€”that was with a view to change it for gold as I understood himâ€”he gave me the receipt in this case the same day, at Bishopsgate, before he received the silver, and in the event of their being anything wrong, it would be made right afterwardsâ€”he gave me the receipt for what I said was the amount of the silver, the bag being labeled according to the amount on the receiptâ€”he did not receive it at that timeâ€”he received it when he came down to Brick-laneâ€”at the time he gave me the receipt, he had no means of ascertaining whether my account was correct or not so, far as the silver was concerned; he gave me the receipt assuming my account to be correctâ€”after that he came down to Brick-lane, and then he compared the amount of silver with the accountâ€”I labeled the bag with the same amount as was represented on the receipt, and I carefully counted it over beforehand.

WILLIAM HATCHY SPROULE . It was the prisoner's duty to receive money from the different stations, including Brick-laneâ€”having received the monies from the Brick-lane station, it would be his duty to enter the amount in a book called the "Stations remittance book"â€”this is it (produced)â€”on Saturday, 28th January, he entered, as having received from the Brick-lane station, 152l. 2s. 9d.â€”I find entered under the head of 10th February, 308l. 10s. 8d., and 191l. 8s. 5d.â€”the 308l. 10s. 8d. is from another accountâ€”the 191l. 8s. 5d. is the Brick-lane amountâ€”it was not his duty to enter in any other bookâ€”the books of the company were not made up from this bookâ€”a statement was made from this bookâ€”it was the foundation of all the accounts, and the amounts entered in that book, are the only amounts claimed at the hands of the prisoner.
COURT. Q. Does that account show in what coin it was? A. The total shows only the total, not the different divisions at that particular station.
MR. SERJEANT BALLANTINE. Q. Assuming a deficiency on the first day of 23l. 15s., and on the second day of 28l. 10s., has he accounted for either of them? A. No.

Cross-examined. Q. Not to you? A. No; he had to pay the wages at Brick-lane station, but he received a chequeâ€”I have not the cheque that he received on either of those daysâ€”he had to pay wages to a large amount at Brick-laneâ€”Saturday was pay day; it was every fortnight, every other
