Saturdayâ€”I do not know whether the 28th of January was a pay day at Brick-laneâ€”I cannot tell whether 11th February was pay-dayâ€”I do not know anything of the silver or a portion of it being retained at Brick-lane station in order to pay the wagesâ€”I know that it was soâ€”if that was done, the prisoner gave a receipt for the whole amount without seeing the silver, and then went and paid it away in wagesâ€”there was a wages book kept at Brick-laneâ€”I do not think I should be able to tell from the wages book how much he received from the bank and how much from Brick-lane to pay the wagesâ€”if he entered in the station's remittance book he would be responsible for so much being paid into the bank.
COURT. Q. Did he receive a less amount in consequence of the silver being retained for wages? A. That I cannot say.

MR. METCALFE. Q. Did not he, to your knowledge, receive a smaller amount, that is an amount, minus the silver at Brick-lane, to pay the wages with? A. But he would have credit for that sum in the cheque that he would receive to get cashedâ€”he received the whole amount from the bank that he had to pay the wages withâ€”he received at the bank the proper amount to pay the wages with, minus the silver he was to receive at Brick-lane; but then he took the wages down that much lessâ€”I cannot say how much he receivedâ€”he would not enter so much less in the remittance bookâ€”he must enter the total remittance in the book, and give a receipt for itâ€”he would have in his possession the cheque to pay the wages with, or the value of it in silver and gold; and he would put to that the money he took at the bank, and go down to Brick-lane with that amount in silverâ€”the cheque is drawn by the directors, and cashed by the prisonerâ€”the cheque is drawn for wages all over the lineâ€”when money is sent from Brick-lane station a ticket is sent with itâ€”that is filed in our officeâ€”I have not got it hereâ€”for anything I know it is on the file nowâ€”there would be a ticket on each of these days, which would show the actual amount paid to the prisonerâ€”it would show the particulars of the sum paidâ€”a counterpart of the ticket is retained at the office as a receipt for the moneyâ€”they are made out in duplicateâ€”I do not think the ticket filed at the office would represent the amount paid to the prisoner, deducting the silver retained at Brick-laneâ€”I do not remember seeing thatâ€”I will not swear that it is not soâ€”I have not looked for the ticketâ€”what I look at is this book in the prisoner's writingâ€”the ticket is checked with this book by one of the clerks in my officeâ€”I cannot recollect his name nowâ€”it was one person's particular dutyâ€”it would be his duty to point out to me any variance if there was anyâ€”he went through it while the prisoner was gone to the bankâ€”this 308l. applies to Brick-lane, both on the same dayâ€”there is only one tick against it; there ought to be two, if it applied to bothâ€”I have not tried to ascertain who checked thatâ€”besides the wages account book there are pay-sheets of the wagesâ€”they are filled up at the accountant's office.

MR. SERJEANT BALLANTINE. Q. When you were before the Magistrate was any intimation given to you that any question would arise about the wages? A. No; I have never before heard any suggestion that this money not accounted for, as having been paid to the prisoner, was paid over in wagesâ€”there is a separate cheque for the Brick-lane wagesâ€”the names of all the labourers and employes are put down upon the pay-sheet, with the amounts to be paid to them, and a cheque is made out in accordance with thatâ€”it is not a crossed cheque; it enables the prisoner to receive the money over the counterâ€”the silver has occasionally been reserved; that was to save the prisoner carrying it down to Brick-laneâ€”when he had silver from the cheque

that he had already cashed at the bank, to pay in in its stead, it was to save the trouble of carrying the silver to Brick-lane and backâ€”he would take the amount from the cheque that he had already cashed, and put it into the station's remittance; for instance, we will say that 20l. was retained at Brick-lane, he would take 20l. from the amount of the cheque to pay at Brick-lane, and place it in the station's remittance, leaving the amount at Brick-lane for the purpose of the wagesâ€”I think I have an entry which shows in what coin he was paid on these two particular days at the bankâ€”this book will show it; it is the prisoner's entryâ€”it shows the whole amount he was paid, but it does not specify the amount in specie that he received from Brick-lane.

WILLIAM HENRY KENT . I am superintendent of police, in the service of the Eastern Counties Railway Companyâ€”in February, 1860, I sought after the prisoner for the purpose of apprehending himâ€”I made diligent search for himâ€”I did not find him till 5th October, 1861â€”he was then at Scar
borough, in Yorkshire, at the St. George's concert-room, acting as musical director, under the name of John Staplesâ€”I brought him up to Londonâ€”I told him I wanted him to come with me, and he said, "Very well"â€”I did not say what forâ€”he knew I belonged to the company.

Cross-examined. Q. Do you really mean to say that you searched for him? A. Yes; after 22d February I searched for him, before Mr. Love's election was over, everydayâ€”I was told to use every exertion to find out his where
abouts I think I was first told that on 17thâ€”it was about the 100l.â€”that was what I went down to Yorkshire forâ€”I told him that subsequentlyâ€”I did not tell him anything about this case; I knew nothing of itâ€”this was a subsequent charge; I knew of nothing but the 100l.
MR. SERJEANT BALLANTINE. Q. Was any restriction at all put upon you in the search you were directed to make? A. None whatever; I was only directed to take him upon the 100l.

GEORGE FERN . I am chief clerk in the Audit-officeâ€”after the prisoner left the company's service I was directed to investigate his accounts with respect to the monies which he received and should have accounted forâ€”I drew certain conclusions from going through the accountsâ€”I have not the books here from which I drew those conclusions; they would fill the Court if the whole of them were hereâ€”I have only drawn my conclusions from the examination of the books.

COURT to JOHN PHIPPS. Q. You say that occasionally you were in the habit of taking a receipt from the prisoner when you did not produce the silver at the time. A. Yes; I was also in the habit of making out a ticket and leaving it with himâ€”that was not to charge me; it was merely a copy of it, to certify in writing the amount of the moneyâ€”I cannot say whether he brought down that ticket to Brick-lane and compared it with mineâ€”I took his receipt; the silver had nothing to do with the wagesâ€”at the time I handed him over the silver I did not show him the receipt againâ€”he would sometimes take the coppers and pay them away for wages, but that had nothing to do with the money he received for wagesâ€”I did not carry up the coppers to Bishopsgate on pay-day; I reserved them at Brick-lane, at his request, on some occasionsâ€”at his request I reserved the bag of silver, as he would want to change it for gold for his own convenience in paying the wagesâ€”that has been done on several occasionsâ€”he has said that he wanted to change it for gold for his own convenience in paying the wages.

MR. SPROULE (re-examined). The cheque for the payment of the wages was cashed on the Thursday, and the prisoner would have the money in his hands from Thursday to Saturdayâ€”he got it cashedâ€”not in my presenceâ€”
I know he brought the cash back; he did so on every occasionâ€”it would be done on the Friday morning very early; immediately the bank opened.

The prisoner received a good character.â€”
NOT GUILTY .

23.
WILLIAM DORRELL (43)
, Feloniously setting fire to two stacks of straw, the property of
Henry Rydon.

EDWARD KIDD (policeman). On the morning of 7th November, I was on duty in Stoke Newington, and going down the Green-lanes I saw a fireâ€”I met the prisoner, and asked him where the fire wasâ€”he said, "Just below here"â€”I said, "What is it?"â€”he said, "Two stacks of hay, close to each other"â€”perceiving particles of hay and straw hanging about his hair and whiskers, I said, "You have been sleeping in the hay"â€”he said, "Yes; I have, Sir"â€”I said, "Have you got anything about you?"â€”he said, "No"â€”another constable then came running up, proceeding in the direction of the fire, and having heard what I said, he said to the prisoner, "Have you any matches?"â€”he replied, "No"â€”we searched him, and found a box of matches on him, and a knife, and a little bagâ€”I said, "I am suspicious that you have set fire to this straw, and I shall take you to the station on suspicion"â€”he then said, "I will tell you the truth; I did do it"â€”on the way to the station I asked him where he got the matches from, and he said he bought them for a farthingâ€”at the station the charge was read over to him by the sergeant, and he was cautioned in the usual wayâ€”he said it was a bad job.
Prisoner. I deny confessing it; I likewise deny that I denied having any lights. Witness. I am quite positive he did confess it in the presence of two other constablesâ€”I knew nothing of him before.

JOSEPH JOHNSON (Policeman). I was on duty in King Henry's-walk, near where the fire wasâ€”I was going towards the fire and saw Kidd questioning the prisoner as to where the fire was, and about his sleeping under the stacksâ€”the prisoner said he knew nothing at all about itâ€”I said, "Have you got any matches about you?"â€”he said, "No; I have not"â€”I said, "I must see"â€”I put my hand in his pocket, and pulled out this box of matchesâ€”I asked him what was the reason that he set it on fireâ€”he said, "Well I did do it; but don't hurt me"â€”he had previously stated to the other constable that he did set it on fireâ€”I went on to the fire, and found it was two stacks of straw belonging to Mr. Rydon; they were burnt.
Prisoner. This witness gives the same evidence as the other; I deny it; I say the same as I did at first; I deny that I confessed it.

EDWARD WEBB . I was foreman to Mr. Rydonâ€”these were his stacks of strawâ€”I was woke up by the alarm of fire, and found them burningâ€”we were not able to do anything to save themâ€”they were of the value or 300l.

Prisoner's Defence. All I have got to say is, I was searching for a lodging, and I went and lay between the two hay-stacks for a lodging; a policeman came up and turned me away; a few minutes after that the fire broke out at one corner of the hay-stack; I went away, and went down the lane, and the policeman took me into custody; that is all I have to say.

ST. GEORGE SEYMOUR . I am the prisoner's brother-in-lawâ€”I have known him personally for four years, but I am acquainted with the last twenty years of his lifeâ€”it has been for some time our opinion that he is not quite rightâ€”that is likewise the opinion of medical men; but their testimony only goes to this, that it is a monomania, of which we can produce abundant evidenceâ€”they do not feel authorised to say that it goes to the extent of lunacyâ€”about eight months ago I took the necessary steps to confine him in a lunatic asylum, but on account of its not going further than mono
mania,

was obliged to relinquish itâ€”he had lived with me up to that timeâ€”he left me on account of treatment which I could not put up withâ€”he took 7l. 14s. with him, in his pocket, and we hoped that he would make his way home again when that was gone, but we heard no more of him till the policeman came to inform us of thisâ€”he has many delusions; constantly blaming us for giving him false moneyâ€”he has never earned a penny for the last twenty yearsâ€”he has been kept by his familyâ€”I believe there is no doubt that he is labouring under a delusion of some kind.

JOHN ROWLAND GIBSON . I am surgeon of Newgateâ€”the prisoner has been in this prison between two and three weeksâ€”my attention has been a good deal directed to himâ€”I am decidedly of opinion that he is of un
sound mindâ€”he entertains delusions as to propertyâ€”I am not able to say that he does not know right from wrong, but it is difficult to say, when delusion exists, how far it may influence the conductâ€”there is very decided unsoundness of mind.

JOHN WEST . I know the prisoner by seeing him in the neighbourhood of my premises, about the sheds and straw stacks, and I have warned him away several times, and threatened to give him in the custody of the police if I found him lounging about thereâ€”I thought there was something wrong about him mentallyâ€”he seemed half-wittedâ€”I think it was the Sunday morning previous to the fire, that I had last seen himâ€”he seemed very filthy, and had extraordinarily dirty habits, lying about and sleeping in the shedsâ€”he has called at my house late of an evening and asked for a glass of boiling water; he said he could not drink it cold.

rs.hi: Ordered to be detained during Her majesty's pleasure.

div1.p:
24.
JAMES DENNY (18)
, Stealing 4 reams of paper, the pro
perty of
George Henry Farrington.

GEORGE HENRY FARRINGTON . I am a wholesale stationer of 15, Godli
man-streetâ€”on 19th November, between 2 and half-past 2 in the afternoon, I was in the back part of my warehouse, and saw the prisoner in the front part; he had a bundle of my paper in his handâ€”I came towards him, and asked him what he was going to do with itâ€”he said, "Oh! nothing, nothing; I am going to put it straight"â€”he made an attempt to get away, and my man came forward and assisted me to hold him till the constable cameâ€”this (produced) is the bundle of paperâ€”it contains four reams, and weighs about sixty poundsâ€”he had it in his arms and he would have taken it away had I not seized himâ€”he was going towards the door with it.

Prisoner. It's no such thing; I had not moved two yards, nor two inches. Witness. It stood on a pile of four others, and he had removed it from the top of the pile, and had turned half-way round with it in his arms.

WILLIAM WILKINS (City-policeman,313). The prisoner was given into my custodyâ€”I searched him at the station, and found on him 4d. in copper, a knife, pencil, an old book, and a flint-stone, and this bag in which the paper now is.
Prisoner's Defence. I had no intention of stealing the goods; I had not removed them an inch.
GUILTY .

p.hi: The prisoner was further charged with having been before convicted at the Westminster Session, by the name of James Minchin, July, 1859, when he was imprisoned Two Years; to which he

div1.p:
PLEADED GUILTY.**â€”
Four Years Penal Servitude.

25.
JOHN MANSFIELD, (19)
, Robbery, with Violence, on
Harriet Millbank, and stealing a purse, and 1s., the property of
Thomas Millbank.

HARRIET MILLBANK . I am the wife of Thomas Millbank, a coachman, of 4, Cobham-row, clerkenwellâ€”on Saturday night, 2d November, between 11 and 12 o'clock, I was coming down Laystall-street on to Mount-pleasantâ€”just as I reached a public-house door I was met by the prisonerâ€”he hit me in the chest and knocked me downâ€”he held me down by my left-arm and wrenched my purse out of my right-bandâ€”I cried outâ€”I got up and saw him running awayâ€”I kept my eye on him, and in a short time found him in charge of a constableâ€”the constable produced a purse to me, it was the one I lostâ€”this is itâ€”it had money in to the amount of 1s. and three half-pence.

Prisoner. She was coming out of the public-house and fell down, and dropped the purse out of her hand, and I picked it up. witness I was not coming out of the public-houseâ€”I had not been inâ€”I did not tumble downâ€”I had no glass in my handâ€”the prisoner knocked me down.

THOMAS FURLONG (Policeman, G 27). I was on duty in Laystall-street on this nightâ€”I heard the prosecutrix say, "That man has got my purse"â€”I saw the prisoner come from the placeâ€”I crossed over the way and saw him try to pass the purse to another manâ€”I seized hold of him, and took it out of his bandâ€”this is it.
Prisoner's Defence. I did not do it with any intent; I had no occasion to do it; I was going to work on the Monday.
GUILTY .
The prisoner was further charged with having been before convicted at the Middlesex Sessions, in May, 1860; to which he

PLEADED GUILTY.*â€”
Confined Twelve Months.

26.
CHARLES LUCAS (33)
, Burglariously entering the dwelling-house of
James Absell, and stealing I hat, a coat, and other articles, his goods.

JAMES ABSELL . I am an upholsterer of 10, Cambridge-road, Hackney-roadâ€”on Sunday night, 20th November, about a quarter to 11, I went to bedâ€”I fastened up all the doors and windowsâ€”something aroused me in the night, about half-past 3, but I did not get up till 7 in the morning, when I went down to let my man in, who worked in my shopâ€”I did not then discover that the house had been enteredâ€”I went up stain to dress myself, and then came down about 7 or quarter-pastâ€”I found the back kitchen window open, and my parlour in a state or confusionâ€”the ground was covered with papers, and clothes, and work boxes, burst open and all about the floorâ€”I missed a coat, a hat, a pair of boots, a silk handkerchief, a pair of gloves, and a pair of spectacles, worth about 2l. 10s.â€”this (pro
duced) is the hat I lostâ€”I am sure it is my hat, and that it was safe that night, with the handkerchief and gloves in itâ€”I saw the prisoner about the Thursday before the burglary, at the side of my premisesâ€”my private door is about forty or fifty yards from the road; and I saw him at the shop doorâ€”I saw him again on the Sunday, the day of the burglaryâ€”he was then at the corner, by the shop doorâ€”I was going to chapel at the timeâ€”he was standing there, and another man was on the opposite side, standing in the same wayâ€”I did not see the other man on the Thursday.

Prisoner. Q. What time on the second night was it that you say you saw me by your door? A. About twenty-five minutes past 6â€”as soon as I saw you I went round the corner and saw the other man, and I then returned indoors and staid at home; I turned the gas full on, pulled off the coat I was going to chapel in, and read till supper time, and did not go out again till ten minutes past 9â€”I went to bed at about twenty minutes to

11; something roused me about half-past 3â€”I think it must haye been the work-box dropping oat of your handâ€”I have a cough, and as soon as any
thing arouses me, the cough bursts out; but I did not get up thenâ€”I know the bat, by its being the one I have been in the habit of wearingâ€”it fits me (putting it on)â€”there is no particular mark on it, except that I had altered the band, which I had round it, in consequence of the death of a relativeâ€”I know it is my hat.
JOHN KEOGH (Policeman, N 174). I took the prisoner into custody on 24th Octoberâ€”I found this hat on himâ€”he was wearing it when I took him to the station.

WILLIAM WISEMAN (Police-inspector, M). On 24th October, the prisoner was brought to the station wearing this hatâ€”I asked him where he got it, and how long he had had itâ€”he said he had had it for about sixteen months, and that he had purchased it at Manchester.
Prisoner. Q. What trade did I tell you I followed? A. You said you travelled about the country.

PETER DEWITT (Policeman, M 92). On 24th October, I took this boot off the prisoner's foot at the station, and went to the prosecutor's house and compared it with some marks upon a chair in the back parlourâ€”the chair was covered with Morocco, and the mark upon it was the mark of a muddy bootâ€”there was a plain mark on the chair till you got to a certain part, that was the tip of the boot, and there there was a peculiar lump of mudâ€”I found that the size of the mark corresponded with the bootâ€”I took it into the street and wetted it, and then placed it alongside the mark on the chair, and it made a similar mark, till it came to that portion where the small piece of mud had dropped, and that corresponded also.

GUILTY .â€”
Confined Righteen Months.

div0.p: PRESENTâ€”Mr. Ald. HALS; Mr. Ald. PHILLIPS; and Mr. COMMON SERJEANT.

div1.p:
27.
WILLIAM LEGRAVE (31)
, Feloniously uttering counterfeit coin, after two previous convictions; to which he

PLEADED GUILTY .**â€”
Four Year Penal Servitude.

28.
ROBERT CLIFFORD (71)
, Unlawfully having counterfeit coin in his possession, with intent to utter it; to which he

PLEADED GUILTY .â€”
Four Year Penal Servitude.

29.
ABRAHAM ATKINS (27), was indicted
for a like offence; to which he

PLEADED GUILTY .â€”
Confined Two Years.

p.hi: The officer stated that the prisoner got his living by selling counterfeit coin in the streets.

div1.p:
30.
JOHN PAINE (18)
, Unlawfully uttering counterfeit coin; to which he

PLEADED GUILTY .â€”
Confined Twelve Month.

31.
ROBERT RIDLEY (20), was indicted
for a like offence; to which he

PLEADED GUILTY .â€”
Confined Twelve Months.

32.
WILLIAM DIXON (25), and
EDWARD PALMER (20), were indicted for
a like offence.

EMMA MARY HORSFPOOL . I am single, and live with my father, a baker, in High-street, Poplarâ€”on 7th November, Palmer came, and asked for a penny leaf; he tendered a shilling, which I put on the edge of the till, and gave him sixpence and five pence, in coppersâ€”I afterwards gave the shilling to my fatherâ€”I had not lost sight of it.

Cross-examined by MR. RIBTON. Q. Did you pot it in the till? A. Not right in, bat on the edgeâ€”I did not close the till againâ€”I laid it there till my father cameâ€”there were other shillings there, but not where that waftâ€”I had no suspicion of it being bad, but I did not know that it was goodâ€”I generally lay money on the edge of the till, in case there is any Iâ€”my father came in ten minutes afterâ€”I had not removed it in the time, or received any other money; nor had any one elseâ€”the till did not remain openâ€”it will close, and a shilling will still remain on the edge.
COURT. Q. Is the cup round, told the till square, so that there is a triangle? A. Yes.

JOHN HORSPOOL . I am the father of the last witnessâ€”on 7th November, my daughter gave me a shillingâ€”it was on the division of the till; between the cupsâ€”I do not allow money to be put into the till, until it is shown to me or my wifeâ€”I took it up not two minutes after the man went out; found it was bad, put it in my pocket by itself and afterwards gave it to Nicholl.

Cross-examined. Q. Tour daughter has said that you were out, and came in in ten minutes? A. I was talking to a gentleman in the shop; she has made some mistakeâ€”I was not eight minutes after the prisoner was goneâ€”I put the shilling in my waistcoat pocket, and gave it to the policeman, a quarter of an hour or twenty minutes afterwards.
MR. CRAWFORD. Q. Were you inside or outside the counter? A. Inside; talking to a gentleman.

SUSAN GEE . I live with Mrs. Cox, who keeps an eating-house at Black
heathâ€”on 7th November, Palmer came there for one pennyworth of pud
ding, and gave me a shillingâ€”I gave him 11d. change, and he leftâ€”I pot it in the till; there were two or three sixpences there, but no other shillingâ€”soon after he had gone, Wyhes came in, and I took out the shilling, found it was bad, and put it at the back, where there was no other money; I afterwards gave it to Nichollâ€”our house is about three minutes from Mr. Horspool's.
Cross-examined. Q. Are you sure there was no shilling in the till? A. No; only two or three sixpences.

HENRY WYHES . I live with my father, in High-street, Poplarâ€”on 7th, November, about five minutes past 12 o'clock, I was coming from Bruns
wick-pier down Bruns-wick-street, and saw the prisoners talking together opposite Mrs. Cox'sâ€”Dixon said to Palmer, "Go on, they are busy now," no nodded towards Mrs. Cox's eating-houseâ€”Palmer pulled a shilling from his waistcoat pocket, rubbed it with his thumb and finger, went across the road, and got a pennyworth of plum pudding at Cox'sâ€”Dijon walked to
wards Robin Hood-lane where he stopped, and Palmer came out of the shop and they walked on togetherâ€”I went into the eating-house and said some
thing to Miss Gee, she pulled the till open and pulled out a shillingâ€”I then left and went after the prisonersâ€”I found them still going on together, and

followed them to the East India-road and pointed them out to a constableâ€”we followed them and saw them stand talking about three minutesâ€”Palmer then went into Kennedy's, the tobacconistsâ€”Dixon walked up and down outside, and was taken in custody.

Cross-examined. Q. Do you know Susan Gee? A. Yes; I have been often there for puddingâ€”I did not have some that dayâ€”Palmer was eating the pudding when he came outâ€”he did not give Dixon any of it; they were about five feet from one another.
MR. CRAWFORD. Q. Was your father in the police force? A. Yes.

MOSES NICHOLL (Policeman, K 97). On 7th November, Wybes pointed out the prisoners to me in the East India-road, about two hundred yards from High-streetâ€”they stood still about five minutes, separated, one went over the crossing where it was swept, and the other walked about twelve yards upâ€”Palmer went into the tobacconist's, and I went up to Dixon, and said, "I shall take you in custody for being concerned with the other"â€”he said that I was quite wrong, he was an umbrella maker, and was looking for his livingâ€”I took them to the station, and received this shilling (produced) from Kennedy, another from Horspool, and one from Susan Geeâ€”I searched the prisoners, on Dixon I found eight sixpences, four fourpenny pieces, four threepenny pieces, and 3s. 3 1/2 d. in coppers, a small loaf, a small piece of cheese, two small skins of blacking, and two small ease combsâ€”I was present when Palmer was searchedâ€”there was found on him three sixpences, and 4 1/2 d. in copper good money, and half an ounce of tobacco.

ALXXADDER KENNEDY . I am a tobacconist of Virginia-road, Blackwallâ€”on 7th November Palmer came in for some tobacco, and gave me a shillingâ€”I gave him the changeâ€”he asked me if I had an old umbrella to dispose ofâ€”I said that I had not, and he leftâ€”some time afterwards a policeman came and made inquiriesâ€”I looked into my till and found three or four shillings, one of which was bad, and I gave it to the policemanâ€”this is it (produced)â€”I do not know whether it is the one the prisoner gave me.
WILLIAM WEBSTER . These two coins are bad. The prisoners received good characters.

GUILTY .â€”
Confined Nine Months each ,

33.
JOHN RALPH GOODWIN (19)
, Embezzling 1l. part of the sum of 2l. 5s. the property of the
Board of Trade, his masters; to which he

PLEADED GUILTY .â€”
Confined Six Months.

34.
JOHN LEE(18),
JOHN CHARLES HOWARD (19), and
JOHN CHRISTMAS (18)
, Unlawfully uttering counterfeit coin.

SARAH ANN COOPER . My husband keeps the Hanbury-arms, Wigmore-street, Hoxtomâ€”on Saturday, 24th October, Howard came and asked for half a pint of fourpenny ale, which came to 1d.â€”he gave me a bad sixpence; I bent it, and my husband broke it in halfâ€”Howard said that he was not aware it was bad, he had taken it in change for some tobacco, and if my husband would return it he had no doubt he could get a good one for itâ€”he tendered me a good sixpenoe, and I gave him 5d. changeâ€”a youth named Mills was in the shop; he could see what passedâ€”Howard walked rather slowly and heavily; he hat a wooden leg.

DAVID MILLS . On 24th October I was at the Hanbury-awnsâ€”Howard came in and tendered a sixpence to the landlady; she said that it was badâ€”when he left the shop I followed himâ€”he had a wooden legâ€”he whistled, went a little way, and two people joined himâ€”Christmas is one of them;

he had on a Scotch cap, and the other a turbanâ€”they walked to the middle of Harvey-street, and then Howard left the and went into the Roebuck beer-shop, kept by Mr. Andrews; the others went about twenty-five yards to the rightâ€”I waited till Howard came out, and ran into the house and spoke to the landlordâ€”Howard had joined the other twoâ€”I then came out and followed the threeâ€”a few carts passed and a few people, and I lost sight of the one I cannot recogniseâ€”I followed the other two to the Earl of Aberdeen, where Christmas left and walked towards the Roebuck, but I cannot say whether he went inâ€”I saw him come back soon afterwards and join Howardâ€”they spoke together, but I was not near enough to hearâ€”after that Howard threw something over a house or over the roadâ€”they walked on, I followed them, and gave them in charge.
Howard. You have mistaken me altogether. Christmas. You are quite mistaken. Witness. I know you were togetherâ€”I pointed you both out to a policeman, and saw him catch hold of you.

ARTHUR ANDREWS . I keep the Rovers beer-shop, in Hyde's-placeâ€”on 24th October, Howard came in and asked for half a pint of beer, and gave me a shillingâ€”I gave him change, put the shilling in the till, and he leftâ€”Mills came in and spoke to me almost immediately, and I looked in my till and found the shilling was badâ€”I put it on the counter, and afterwards gave it to the policemanâ€”Lee came in five or ten minutes afterwards, and asked for half a pint of ale or porter, and gave me sixpenceâ€”I noticed that it was bad, and told him soâ€”I said, "You have given me enough; do not give me any moreâ€”he threatened to have me prosecuted for taking away his characterâ€”he drank the beer, but did not give me any good moneyâ€”I gave him in charge with the bad sixpence and shillingâ€”he had on a round hat.
Howard. Q. You said at the police-court that you did not know who gave you the shilling? A. I do not know; there were other shillings in the till.

MR. COOK. Q. When you looked in the till, in consequence of the boy speaking to you, was the bad shilling uppermost or under most? A. It laid on the topâ€”I believe it to be the shilling paid to me by Howardâ€”there were eight or nine shillings at the bottom of the till.
JOHH WELLER (Policeman, N 403). Lee was given into my custody at the Roebuckâ€”I found on him 1s. 9l. 2d., in coppers, and a good sixpenceâ€”I produce this counterfeit sixpence.

THOMAS MAJOR , (Policeman N 120). Mills gave me informationâ€”I had a constable in plain clothes with me, and laid hold of Howardâ€”twenty-five pence in copper was found on himâ€”he had a Scotch cap on, and Christmas a turbanâ€”2d. was found on Christmasâ€”I saw Lee at the station; he was wearing a pork-pie cap.
THOMAS REEVE , (Policeman N 202). I took Christmas about half-past 10 o'clockâ€”I have known Howard four or five yearsâ€”I have frequently seen all the prisoners in company.
WILLIAM WEBSTER . This shilling and sixpence are bad.
Lee's Defence. I changed half-a-crown in Hoxton, and a gentleman gave me a shilling. I did not know what I was putting down, and put down a sixpence. I have never seen the other prisoners before.
Howard's Defence. I sold a quarter of a hundred herrings at a penny each, and that was the money found on me with which I had to get my stock next day.

LEE and CHRISTMAS
Confined Four. Months each . HOWARD**
Confined Twelve Months.

35.
HENRY GREEN (46), was indicted
for a like offence.

ELIZABETH BRYANT . I live with my father at the Grown public-house in New Oxford-streetâ€”on 7th October the prisoner came for a pint of porter and a screw of tobaccoâ€”it came to three-halfpenceâ€”he gave me a bad florinâ€”I told him it was badâ€”he asked me if I should know him againâ€”I said, "Yesâ€”I took the beer and tobacco back again, and broke the florin in twoâ€”I did not give him one part of itâ€”I gave one half to the constable on the 14thâ€”the prisoner must have removed the other half off the counter.

JOHH FBNWICK . I keep the Angel and Crown, Bloomsburyâ€”on 11th October the prisoner came between 6 and 7 o'clock, asked for a glass of six ale, and gave me a shillingâ€”I bent it, and told him it was badâ€”I threw it over the counter, saying, "This won't do for me"â€”he said, "I will give you a shilling that is not mine," and then he pulled out a good sixpenceâ€”I said, "I have a good mind to give You in custody at once"â€”he was insulting to me, and I said, "Well, you had better go away, or else I will lock you up"â€”he went, and I followed him with a friendâ€”I asked one of my cus
tomers to follow him, and returned home.

THOMAS HOWE . I keep the Bull'sâ€”head, High-street, Bloomsbury, which it about half a mile, I should think, from the Angel and Crownâ€”the prisoner came to my house on 14th Octoberâ€”he asked for a glass of six aleâ€”my water served him, but I took the moneyâ€”he gave me a shillingâ€”I tried it, and bent it double with the detectorâ€”at that moment I saw a man pointing, and I said to the prisoner, "I am afraid you have been guilty of this somewhere else"â€”the man came inâ€”I said, "Do you know anything of this man?" he said, "Yes; I have followed him from Gloucester-street, from a public-house"â€”the prisoner heard thatâ€”he polled out sixpence which I refused to take, and I took away the aleâ€”I sent for a constable, and gave him in charge.

JAMES BRADFORD (Policeman, E 77). I took the prisoner, and received this counterfeit shilling (produced) from Mr. Howeâ€”I also received a piece of a florin from Miss Bryantâ€”I searched the prisoner and found on him a sixpence, a halfpenny, a cigar tube, and a German silver watch-chain.
WILLIAM WEBSTER . This florin and shilling are bad.
The prisoner's statement before the Magistrate was here read as follows: "I took the shilling and afterwards passed it, as I thought I had a right to do. I never saw the woman before.

Prisoner's Defence. I received the shilling in change at the Great Northern Station, where I had been drinking with a friend. I have an affection of the brain, and am always worse when I am in liquor. I do not recollect giving the money on the 9th and 14th. With regard to the florin I never saw the woman before, and was net in her house that night; having been out to tea and spent the whole evening with my wife and child. I never use tobacco. This is one of the greatest cases of mistaken identity known.

MARY PLEASANCE . I live at 292, High Holbornâ€”my husband is a bakerâ€”I know the prisonerâ€”on 7th October, Monday I believe, the prisoner had both tea and supper with me and my son-in-law and daughterâ€”he stopped with me from about 4 o'clock till 12â€”I did not notice the time particularlyâ€”when he left, we accompanied him to the bottom of Tottenham-court-road and got a conveyance to take him and his wife and child homeâ€”he has worked with my son at painting, paper-hanging, and glassing, during the fortnight before he was taken.
Cross-examined by MR. COOK. Q. Where has he been working? A. With my

son, at Mr. Thompson's, in Oxford-street, and from one house to the other they have drank tea at my house beforeâ€”I heard the week before last that he was taken up on this chargeâ€”I came here of my own accord to-day; no one has sent for meâ€”I went in to see the prisoner yesterday and told him I should come to-dayâ€”I have plenty of persons to prove he was at my house that eveningâ€”Mr. Holmes had tea with usâ€”I invited a few friendsâ€”I do not sell tea and coffeeâ€”I never knew the prisoner to be in any trouble.

COURT. Q. How far is your house from Mr. Bryant's? A. No great distanceâ€”I know Miss Bryant, and I believe she knows meâ€”the prisoner is a teetotaler and so is his landlordâ€”it was not a teetotal party, or else his landlord would have come and spoken for himâ€”between five and six years ago he had brain feverâ€”he never smoked in his life. to my knowledge.

COURT to ELIZABETH BRYANT. Q. What time was he at your house? A. Between 6 and 7â€”I am sure it was on Mondayâ€”my attention was called to it on the following Monday, the 14thâ€”I am sure of the prisonerâ€”I had never seen him before, but he asked me if I should know him again, when he was in the shop.

The prisoner received a good character.â€”
GUILTY .â€”
Confined Nine Months.

div0.p:
PRESENTâ€”The Right Hon. the LORD MAYOR, M.P.; Mr. BARON BRAMWELL; SIR
JAMES DUKE , Bart. Ald., M.P.; SIR
FRANCIS GRAHAM MOON , Bart. Ald.; Mr. Ald. CARTER; MR. Ald. DAKIN; and Mr. COMMON SERJEANT.

div1.p:
36.
RICHARD REEVES (18), was indicted
for the wilful murder of
Mary Ann Reeves; he was also charged on the coroner's inquisition with the like offence.

MARY REEVES . I am the wife of Thomas Reeves, a basket-maker of 10, Drury-courtâ€”I had a daughter called Mary Ann Reevesâ€”I last saw her alive on 15th November, between 9 and 10 o'clock in the morningâ€”I did not see her again that dayâ€”when I last saw her she was in the first-floor back roomâ€”I left her along with her poor brother (the prisoner)â€”the prisoner is the son of my husband by a former wifeâ€”I have had the care of him ever since he was seven years of ageâ€”I went out about half-past 9 that morning with my husband; he wanted to get shaved, and I went out with himâ€”I came back just about 10 o'clockâ€”I was not away more than a quarter of an hourâ€”I enquired for her, but could not find her or hear of herâ€”I asked the prisoner if he knew where she was, and he said no, he did notâ€”I saw him again a little after 1 o'clockâ€”he came running upstairs and said, "Mother have you found her yet"â€”I said, "No my boy, where am I to go to find herâ€”it was about 2 o'clock that I last saw himâ€”I did not see the body of the deceased till late in the evening.

Cross-examined by MR. SLEIGH. Q. I believe he was always a very mild kindly disposed boy? A. Oh yes! he was always a good boyâ€”his father has been twice under restraint for being insaneâ€”his uncle I believe died at Hanwellâ€”his father has been twice out of his mind; once he was in St. Bartholomew's Hospital, in the lunatic wardâ€”I am not aware that there was any other relation of the prisoner that was insaneâ€”I do not know that his aunt wasâ€”I know nothing about his grandfather; I do not know that it wan the cane with him.

MR. CLERK. Q. How long have you been married to Reeves? A. I was married in 1852â€”it is since my marriage that he has been in the hospitalâ€”it was two years last September he was in St. Bartholomew'sâ€”it was for delirium tremensâ€”unfortunately he has been in the habit of drinking a good dealâ€”the other time that he was under restraint was twelve months last Augustâ€”he had the same thing the matter with him then, delirium trmensâ€”he was then taken to the Strand unionâ€”he was only there from the Monday to the Thursdayâ€”I knew the uncle that died at Hanwellâ€”I have seen him, but I did not see him when he was out of his mindâ€”he was subject to fits, and I believe he died quite out of his mind at Hanwellâ€”I never saw him at Hanwellâ€”my husband told me he was at Hanwellâ€”I do not know how long it is since he died; it was since my marriageâ€”I knew him before he was taken to Hanwellâ€”I used to see him when he came outâ€”he was allowed outâ€”I do not know whether he had been a sober man; he must have been, because he was in the Union for years on account of having fitsâ€”he had fits, and had been in the union for years, and then he was taken to Hanwell.

ELLEN JAMES . I live at 10, Drury-court, in the same house as the Reeves'sâ€”my husband is a stage carpenter at Govent-garden theatreâ€”on Fridays the 15th of this month, I was at home about 9 o'clockâ€”I came down about three or four minutes to 9 to go and get some milk, and the deceased child ran out to me and said, "Mrs. James, shall I go and get your milk?"â€”I said, "No Polly, I am halfway down the stairs, and I will go and get it myself dear"â€”I did not see her again after thatâ€”sometime after that I heard that poor boy (the prisoner) calling to herâ€”he was in the passage at the foot of the stairsâ€”he called, "Polly, Polly"â€”she replied in a rough way that she had in speakings "What is it you want Dick?"â€”he said, "Polly, bring me the key of the back placeâ€”she spoke again, "I do not know where it is Dickâ€”he said, "It is on the table against the window, "perhaps a minute elapsed before she answered againâ€”she then said, "All right Dick," and I heard her go down stairs, and I never beard any more of her un till she was put into my armsâ€”it was about twenty-five minutes past 9 when I heard her go down stairsâ€”a lad named Lynes afterwards came to the houseâ€”I went with him to the cellarâ€”I saw the trap-door of the cellar openedâ€”that was about five or ten minutes after 2, as nigh as possibleâ€”it is in a back place where they generally worked, in the same yard where the back place is, where they generally worked at the basket-making.

COURT. Q. Is it an open yard or a covered shed? A. A covered shed, and enclosedâ€”they had had coals in a few weeks ago, and where the lodgers used to go down, they had some wood-work, so that they could not go down to it that way, they were obliged to go through the back placeâ€”there are no steps to go down to it, only a slideâ€”it was not the coal-cellar of all the lodgers as well as the Reeves's; the Reeves's had it entirely to themselves, but we had to go into the cellar for waterâ€”it was blocked up from the lodgers, so that they could not get in that way to itâ€”they were obliged to go in through the back place where they worked.

MR. CLERK. Q. Is there a door to the coal-cellar besides the entrance to it by the trap door? A. Yes, there used to be, but it vas blocked and nailed upâ€”the only entrance was through the trap-door, at that timeâ€”in order to get to the cellar, you have to open the trap-door and slide downâ€”there are no steps to go downâ€”the coals are a few feet below the trap-door, immediately under itâ€”when the trap-door was opened, I did not see the body of the child lying there, Mrs. Griffith didâ€”she had a candle in her hand and she exclaimed, "Oh my God! it is Pollyâ€”she was taken out
and laid on the sofaâ€”full twenty minutes elapsed before the doctor and the policeman came.

JOHN LYNES . I live at 7, Drury-courtâ€”I knew the little girl Mary Ann Reevesâ€”I last saw her alive on the morning of the 15th, about 9 o'clockâ€”I saw the prisoner in the course of the day, about ten minutes to 2â€”a lad named William Corney was with meâ€”the prisoner came up to us in Drury-courtâ€”he said, "Jack, do you mind taking a walk with me to find my sister Polly?"â€”I said, "I do not mind"â€”I and Corney and the prisoner went down the Strand, and when we got to Folgate opposite St. Clements' church, he turned round and said to me, "It is no use you looking after my sister Polly, go back and tell my father if he wants my sister Polly, he Will find her in the coal-cellar; I have strangled her"â€”I and Corney ran backâ€”we left the prisoner there; be went on towards the city.
COURT. Q. Did you not say anything to him when he told you this? A. No.

MR. BEASLEY. Q. When you went back did you see the father? A. Yes; he was tipsy at the time, going pastâ€”I asked him to come with meâ€”he went with me to the passage, And then I told him what the prisoner had saidâ€”he and I went togetherâ€”we saw Mrs. Griffiths on the stairs, with a candle and pail in her handâ€”I went to the cellar and got inâ€”I jumped down through the trap-doorâ€”I could not get in through the door, only through the trapâ€”nobody went in with meâ€”Corney stood at the top with Mrs. Griffith and Mrs. Jamesâ€”when I got down into the cellar I found the body about two yards from the trapdoorâ€”it was all on a heap, on the side, with some coals lying on her cheekâ€”the body was lying on the coalsâ€”I took it up, and handed it to Mrs. Griffith and Mrs. James through the trapâ€”I noticed a rope or clothes' line tied round the neckâ€”it was round it at the timeâ€”the first part of it was tightâ€”I did not notice it.

COURT. Q. Do you mean the front part? A. Yes; that was tightâ€”this is the line (produced)â€”I did not notice how it was tiedâ€”after handing up the body I and Corney went off to King's College Hospital for a surgeon.

JOHH GRIFFITHS . I live at 10, Drury-court, in the first floor front-roomâ€”I was at home about 2 o'clock in the dayâ€”I heard of the body of the deceased being foundâ€”I went to the room where it was lying; it was on the sofa in the shopâ€”I saw there was a rope round her neckâ€”I undid itâ€”I gave it tip to the doctorâ€”it was drawn taut on first, and then put round againâ€”it was very toutâ€”I could not at first get my finger in between the rope and the neck, until I had worked it in a little way first, and then I got it loose and got it off in that wayâ€”my wife went up stairs to get a knife to cut it, but I undid it without.
COURT. Q. How was it tied? A. You may call it a slip knot, tied over, and then drawn tautâ€”the tie was under the right ear.

CHARLES HENRY ALLFREY . I am house physician at King's College Hospitalâ€”I was called to the house 10, Drury-court, on the 15th November, about five minutes past 2â€”I found the dead body of a female childâ€”it had been dead probably not many hoursâ€”there was still a little warmth about the trunkâ€”I observed a deep mark or furrow round the neckâ€”it was in a horizontal positionâ€”from the examinations I made, then and Afterwards, I found it had died of strangulation from the ligature of the cord,â€”from the position of the mark I should say she had not died from suspen
sionâ€”I examined the handsâ€”there were no marks whatever on them of the rope, as if she had pulled it tight herself.
COURT. Q. Was it possible that she could have strangled herself in the

way you saw? A. I think not; the mark was as if the rope had been drawn very much tighter than she could have drawn it without making marks on the fingersâ€”I think it is possible that a person might fasten a rope round her own neck in such a way as to take away life.

JEMIMA KADGE . I know the prisonerâ€”I remember seeing him on the morning of 15th Novemberâ€”he came up to me as I was standing with my sisterâ€”he told me he had strangled his sisterâ€”I said, "Dick; I can't believe you"â€”he said, "I have done it;" and with that he asked me where Elizabeth Rogers wasâ€”I said she was upstairs, I believedâ€”he asked me if 1 would go up and call herâ€”I went up and she came down, and he called her three or four yards from the doorâ€”he said, "Has Jemima told you any
thing?"â€”she said "No"â€”he then said to her, "Liz, I have strangled my sister;" with that I was going to take some washing to a person in Endelf-street, and he said, "I am going up that wayâ€”I asked Rogers to go with me, and she didâ€”I left her and the prisoner outside while I went inâ€”the prisoner said to me, "I will see you about 6 o'clock in the eveningâ€”I saw him again about five minutes past 2, at the top of Ship-yardâ€”he said, "I have sent two young chaps down to my mother's to tell them where Polly is;" with that I left himâ€”I do not know where he went toâ€”I went in
doors to my work.

Cross-examined. Q. When he said this to you, how did he appear; the Mime as he does now, or in what state? A. He was in a very good temper when be spoke to me about itâ€”he bad a smile on his countenanceâ€”I do not know whether he and the deceased used to play in the coal-cellar.

CHARLES GERMANUS VENUS (Policeman, F 96). On 15th November I had instructions to apprehend the prisonerâ€”about a quarter to 5 I found him in Carey-street, reclining on a post at the corner of Serle's-placeâ€”I went up to him and said, "I want youâ€”he stepped forward from the gutter on to the kerb, and said, "I know what for; I did it"â€”I Immediately said, "You are charged with the murder of your sister; be cautious what you say; what you say I shall use in evidenceâ€”he directly said, "I did it; she aggravated me to it"â€”I then took him to the station.
Cross-examined. Q. In what state did he appear to be when he made this statement to you? A. Perfectly calm; he had the same indifferent look that he has now, quite cool and collected.

GUILTY .â€”Strongly recommended to mercy by the Jury on account of his youth, and the bad example set him at home.â€”
DEATH .

37.
BENJAMIN TAYLOR (38)
, Feloniously and knowingly uttering a forged 10l. Bank of England note, with intent to defraud.

WILLIAM CROUCH . I keep the Queen's Head public-house, 12, Lower White cross-street, Cityâ€”on Tuesday or Wednesday, 16th October, about 9 o'clock in the evening, the prisoner came into my houseâ€”he beckoned me out of the bar-parlour, and asked if I would give him change of a 10l. note (I had previously given him change for a 5l. note)â€”he handed me the noteâ€”I said to him, "Is your name on the note, Taylor?"â€”he said, "No; I will put it"â€”I gave him the pen and ink, and he wrote it in my presence, "B. Taylorâ€”I saw him write itâ€”this (produced) is the note, and this is his signatureâ€”I gave him change for it, and put the note in my cash-boxâ€”on the Sunday previous to this, the 13th October, the prisoner Came into my house, about five or six minutes after 1 o'clock, and asked me to give him change of a 5l. noteâ€”I did soâ€”this (produced) is the noteâ€”I know it by my

own signatureâ€”I signed it with his name and my own, "B. Taylor, White
cross-street," before I put it into the cash-boxâ€”I can swear this is the noteâ€”I paid both the notes away to Messrs. Sager and Company, the distillers, with others, on the Friday following; and on the Tuesday following, the 22d, one of their clerks brought them back branded, "forged"â€”I then went over to the prisoner's houseâ€”I saw his man at the door, and he fetched him down stairsâ€”I said, "Taylor, it is very awkward, those two notes I changed for you last week are returned to me as forgedâ€”he said, "Oh! that can't be," or something of that kindâ€”I paid, "You had better step over the way, for the clerk is there that brought themâ€”he immediately came over, along with Be, into my parlour where the clerk was, and the notes were lying on the tableâ€”I said, "Taylor; there are the notes"â€”he looked at them and said, "I changed two notes, but those are not the notes that I changedâ€”I said, What do you mean by that; here is the 5l. note that I wrote your name and address on myself; that is the one I changed on Sunday, and here is the 10l. note with your own handwriting?"â€”he said, "Oh, no! that there is not, because I can't writeâ€”I then said to the clerk, "Will you be kind enough to put your hat on, I don't intend-to be the loser by these notes; I will go to the station-house," and he and I went immediately, leaving the prisoner in my houseâ€”in a short time we came backâ€”the prisoner had then left my house, and was going down the streetâ€”an officer went after him, overtook him about one hundred yards from my house, and brought him back.

Cross-examined by MR. METCALFE. Q. You have known him some time, have you not? A. Yes; ever since he has lived opposite, three or four yearsâ€”I have changed cheques for him on different occasions, small cheques, never above 2l. or 3l.â€”he has been carrying on business there as a metal dealer for about four years.

CHARLES BAKER . I am a detective officer of the City of Londonâ€”I was sent for to Mr. Crouch's on 22d Octoberâ€”the prisoner was pointed out to me going from his house towards White cross-street prisonâ€”I followed and overtook himâ€”I said, "Taylor; you have passed two notes at Mr. Crouch's public-houseâ€”he said, "Yes; I did nâ€”I said, "They are forged; you must go back with me to Mr. Crouch's"â€”he went back with me, and I showed him the notesâ€”he said they were not the notes he had passed to Mr. Crouchâ€”I asked him if they were not the notes, where he got the two notes that ho did passâ€”he said, "I received them from my metal dealer about three weeks ago"â€”I asked biro what his metal dealer's name wasâ€”he said, "I don't knowâ€”I asked where he livedâ€”he said, "I don't knowâ€”I asked how long he had dealt with himâ€”he said, "About three or four years; he comes round every weekâ€”I asked what sort of a hone he had gotâ€”he said, "It is a large black horse, and a very large cart"â€”I then asked if he had sold as much as 15l. worth of metal to a metal dealer, whether he did not give a receiptâ€”he said, "No; I did notâ€”I asked if that was all he had got to sayâ€”he said, "Yes"â€”I then took him into custody.

Cross-examined. Q. Did he tell you he should be able to find the man for you, because be came round every week? A. Yesâ€”I took him to the station, and he has been in custody ever sinceâ€”I believe bail was applied for on the ground that he might have an opportunity of finding the man, and it was refused.

MR. MATTHEWS. Q. Has the shop been open since he has been in cus
tody? A. It is still openâ€”to the best of my belief his brother attends to itâ€”the prisoner is married and has three or four childrenâ€”they live at the house.

EDWARD KNIGHT (City Police-inspector). I know the prisoner's hand
writing; I have seen him writeâ€”the signature on this note is in the character of his writingâ€”I have his signature in this receipt-book (pro
ducing it)â€”I saw him write thatâ€”it is one of my books.
JOSEPH BUMSTBAD . I am inspector of notes at the Bank of England; these notes are both forged in all respects.

GUILTY .â€”
Five Years' Penal Servitude.

38.
BENJAMIN YALE (44), was indicted
for feloniously killing and slaying
Eliza Garritt; he was also charged on the Coroner's Inquisition with the wilful murder of the said Eliza Garritt.
NOT GUILTY .

p.hi: The particulars of this and the following case were not of a nature for publication.

div1.p:
39.
ANNIE YALE (39)
, Feloniously administering to
Ann' Home, on. 6th October, a certain noxious drug, with intent to procure her mis
carriage.
NOT GUILTY .

40.
ANNIE VALE was again indicted
for a similar offence on 26th September.

No evidenceâ€”
NOT GUILTY .

div0.p:
NEW COURT.â€”Wednesday, November 27th, 1861. PRESENTâ€”Mr. JUSTICE BYLES; Sir
JAMES DUKE BART M.P. Ald.; and Mr. Ald. SIDNEY.

div1.p:
41.
SAMUEL THOMAS GILLARD (28),
Stealing, whilst employed in the Post-office, a post-letter, containing 1 sovereign, the property of
Her Majesty's Postmaster-General; to which he

PLEADED GUILTY .â€”
Three Years' Penal Servitude.

42.
JOHN PERKINS (55)
, Stealing two 1001. Bank of England notes the property of
Her Majesty's Postmaster-general. Second Count, feloniously receiving the same.

EDWIN BROWN . I am a clerk in the Lincoln and Lindsay Banking Company at Louth in Lincolnshireâ€”I made up a parcel for Prescott and Co. and put into it Bank of England notes, country notes, bills, and cheques, to the amount of 1,361l. 0s. 6d.â€”among them were these two 100l. Bank of England notes, marked G.Z. 80008, and G. Z. 62205, dated 19th May, 1860â€”I put a letter with the notes and cheques into an envelope, and directed it to Messrs. Prescott, Grote, and Co. bankers, Londonâ€”I sealed the envelope with wax, and posted it at 5 o'clock, as Louth, in time for the delivery that eveningâ€”in consequence of receiving no notice of it, I tele
graphed on Friday morning.

THOMAS SYMONDS . I am the postmaster at Louthâ€”a letter polled there at 5 o'clock on any day, would be dispatched for London at 8.45 the same evening, and would arrive in London in the course of the next morningâ€”I despatched the bag on 27th Februaryâ€”all the London letters were put into it.

ALFRED BAILY . I am a letter carrier in the General Part-officeâ€”on the morning of 25th February, I delivered letters in Threadneedle-streetâ€”I delivered some to Messrs. Prescott, the bankersâ€”I delivered all those that came into my hands on 28th February.
JULIAN HILL . I am manager to Messrs. Prescottâ€”on the morning of 28th February, no letter arrived there, containing remittances from the bankers at Louth.

CHARLES VANVILLE . I am waiter at the Hotel, de Paris, at Calaisâ€”I know the prisoner very wellâ€”he came there on the night of 3d March, but I did not see him till about 10 o'clock the next morning, when he was coming down stairs from the sleeping apartments to the coffee-roomâ€”(I went to bed at 11 o'clock on the 3dâ€”it was not my turn to sit up that nightâ€”he was not in the house at that time)â€”I said, "Good morning, Sir"â€”he said, "I am going to change some money after breakfast"â€”I gave him his bill about half-past 11â€”it was five francs; which he paid meâ€”he had a parcel with himâ€”he left at five minutes to 12â€”he had no luggage but the parcelâ€”a few days afterwards I saw Monsieur Bellar, the banker, so that my attention was called to the prisonerâ€”the prisoner comes to the hotel once every year, so that I know him well.

Cross-examined by MR. SLEIGH. Q. I suppose it is a common thing at your hotel, for people to go to the neighbouring money changer? A. Yes; there were perhaps a dozen people at the hotelâ€”I have been there five yearsâ€”the prisoner came from the mail; but I was in bed at the time.
MR. CLERK Q. Did he come alone? A. Yes; there were two or three people with him at breakfast, but nobody went out with him from the hotel.

CHARLES EUGENE WASCAT . I am cashier to Monsieur Bellar, the banker, at Calaisâ€”I was at the bank on the morning of 4th Marchâ€”the prisoner came there between 10 and 11 o'clock, I think, and asked me to change two notes of the Bank of England, of 100l. eachâ€”I took the numbers of the notesâ€”this book, with the entry, is not in my writingâ€”is was written by a clerkâ€”I wrote the name on the notes and gave it to a clerkâ€”these (produced) are the notes that the prisoner brought meâ€”I asked him for his name and address, and wrote down what he gave meâ€”I wrote down "Ellen, Hotel de Paris"â€”he gave his address as Hotel de Parisâ€”I have spelt Ellen with an E, because in French that is Aâ€”I put it down by the soundâ€”I gave him change for the two notes in French money, and he left the bankâ€”I afterwards, on the same day, sent the two notes in halves to the London and Westminster Bank, our correspondentsâ€”there was nobody with the prisoner.
Cross-examined. Q. Did you indorse those notes at the time you received them from the prisoner? A. Yes.

MICHEL FRANCOIS VATTKL (Through an interpreter). I am the special com
missaire de police, at Calaisâ€”the mail packet from Dover arrived there on 4th March, at half-past 3 in the morning, and as the passengers landed I took down their names on a piece of paperâ€”fifteen passengers disembarked, the name of one of whom I took down as Thomas Alien.

p.hi: objected to Out evidence unless the witness could identify the prisoner as the person; but
considered that that would be a question for the jury.

div1.p:
MICHAEL HAYDON . I am one of the detective officers of the City of Londonâ€”on 22d October, I took the prisoner in Old-street, St. Luke'sâ€”I told him I charged him with having stolen, on 28th February, a banker's parcel, con
taining

Bark of England notes, country notes, cheques, and bills to the amount of 1,360l.â€”I addressed him by the name of Douglasâ€”he said my name is not Douglas, and never was; my name is Perkinsâ€”I took him to the station at Bow-lane, and told him that I had traced two 100l. notes, and had ascertained that he had changed them at a money changers in Calais, four days after the robberyâ€”he made no replyâ€”he gave his address 14, High-street, Cheltenhamâ€”I have been there, and there is no No. 14 in the High-street.

SAMUEL ROBERT GOODMAN . I am the chief clerk at the Mansion-houseâ€”I was on duty at the time the depositions of the witnesses were taken before the Lord Mayor, in the prisoner's presenceâ€”after the evidence of Haydon, the prisoner was asked whether he wished to put any question to Haydonâ€”he said no, but he wished to make a statementâ€”he was told that that was not the usual time to make a statement, but whatever he said would be taken down, and might be used against himâ€”he then made a statementâ€”I took it down and read it over to him afterwardsâ€”he did not sign itâ€”this is it (reading: "I was in Calais some months since, waiting for a train to go on further. In the square a gentlemanly man entered into conversation with me, and asked me if I could tell him the best money changers there; I said I believed there was a banker down that street, who was one of the most respectable persons there, and I would go with him there if he thought proper. When we came near the money changers, he said, 'Perhaps you can get a better exchange than I can; will you oblige me?' I said, I have no objection;' he then handed me two 100l. notes, but whether these are them or not I do not know. I went and got the exchange and brought it to him at the door. From there I went to Lisle and did my business, and came back to Cologne and did my business; that is all I have to say.")

RICHARD ADYE BAILY . I am a clerk in the Bank of Englandâ€”I pro
duce two notes which were paid in on 6th March, by the London and Westminster Bank.
COURT. Q. Have the Bank of England been obliged to pay these notes? A. Yes; there are no other notes of that date and number.

MR. LEWIS contended that there was no evidence of the prisoner's having stolen the notes, or of his having received them in England, and that if he received them at Calais it was not within the jurisdiction of this Court. MR. METCALFE submitted that the parcel mutt have been stolen in England, and that tiff prisoner being in possession of the notes so soon afterwards, the inference was that he stole the parcel; and further, that he must have been in England to steel it, as he did not arrive in Calais until the morning of the 4th. The COURT considered that it was a case for the Jury.
He was further charged with having been before convicted at this Court in 1848, in the name of John Clark; to which he

PLEADED GUILTY.â€”
Judgment respited.

43.
SAMUEL RAW (20)
, Stealing, whilst employed in the Post-office, a letter containing a half-sovereign, the property of
Her Majesty's Post
Master-General.

HENRY SPARY . I am gas-fitter, living at Arles ford in Hampshireâ€”I deal with Messrs. Cummings and Bone, of Tottenham Court-roadâ€”on 30th October, I wrote them a letter enclosing a half-sovereign, which I fitted into one of my business cards, and gave it to Elizabeth Hockley to post,
about half-past 7 o'clockâ€”there is a day mail from Arlesford at 8 o'clockâ€”these fragments (produced) are parts of the envelope, letter, and card.
ELIZABETH HOCKLEY . I received the letter from Mr. Spray and posted it between 7 and 8 that morning.

ANN KEENE . I am the post-mistress of Arlesfordâ€”a letter posted there before 8 o'clock would leave for London by the morning deliveryâ€”I find on these fragments the whole of the post-mark of the morning of 3d October.

WILLIAM BENNING . I am a sorter at the southern district of the Post-officeâ€”on 3d October I received the mail-bag from Arlesfordâ€”a letter from Arlesford for the western district would be forwarded by me for delivery.
JOHN BUCKNELL . I am charge-taker at the western district officeâ€”on 3d October I received the mail-hag soon after 1 o'clock in the day.

WILLIAM COWLETT HOWLETT . I am one of the inspectors of letter
carrier at the western district officeâ€”the prisoner was a sorter and letter carrier thereâ€”his walk on 3d October was the Tottenham Court-road district, and some of the adjoining streetsâ€”a letter arriving by the mail
bag from Arlesford shortly after 1 o'clock, should be delivered by the prisoner about twenty minutes or half-past 2â€”according to his own showing in this book (produced) he left the office for that delivery at a quarter to 2â€”this is in his writing.

Cross-examined by MR. SLEIGH. Q. How many carriers are there on that walk? A. Fiveâ€”the prisoner went out at a quarter to 2â€”the next indication in the book is his writing at 5 o'clock, when he returned to the officeâ€”the entry is that he terminated his delivery at fifty-five minutes past 2â€”the place in Tottenham Court-road where the lads say that they saw him, is barely half-way through his walkâ€”the office is in Vere-streetâ€”he would not get to the commencement of his walk till 2 o'clock or five minutes pastâ€”he commences his round at Rathbone-place, and passes through Greek-street and Stephen-street, which is a thoroughfare into Tottenham Court-road, and when he comes there, he can go into Stephen-street againâ€”whether he would deliver in Stephen-street before Tottenham Court-road, would depend upon his own judgmentâ€”there are places where he is required to be at certain timesâ€”if according to the directions on his letter he thought it prudent to go into one street before another, he would be allowed to do so.
MR. METCALFE. Q. You say there are several letter-carriers, are there several at that hour of the day? A. No; only the prisonerâ€”the delivery takes him about fifty-five minutes.
GEORGE PETERS BONE . I am a glass-manufacturer of 22 Tottenham Court-roadâ€”I received no letter from Mr. Spary in October.

EDWARD VIAN . I am an errand boy, in the employment of Mr. Allwright, a cheesemonger, of 45, Rathbone-placeâ€”my mother lives at 16, Tottenham Court-roadâ€”the prisoner has been the postman of our district for some timeâ€”on Wednesday, 30th October, I was standing with two boys, Frederick Mills and Henry Rowe, in Stephen-street, and saw the prisoner coming along Tottenham Court-road towards us, at half-past 2 or a quarter to 3â€”before he got to ns he tore some paper upâ€”he was then from eight to ten doors from usâ€”he threw so me in the gutter, and some on the pavement, and some money with itâ€”he then stooped and picked up the money and put it in his pocketâ€”I saw the shine of it as he threw it downâ€”he then came close to us where we were standing, and as he passed us he drew out a half-sovereign from his right-hand waistcoat-pocket and looked at itâ€”I could see it in his hand, it was a half-sovereignâ€”we afterwards went and

picked up the pieces of paper, and some yellow paper, and pieces of cardâ€”we picked up all that we could seeâ€”I gave them to Frederick Mills, who took them to his mother, and then he brought them out and I took them to my mother and showed them to herâ€”I have a brother a letter-carrier on the Pimlico districtâ€”my mother gave him the pieces of paper next dayâ€”I can readâ€”I showed him the pieces of paper and card againâ€”these (produced) are them.

Cross-examined. Q. When did you see them again? A. Next dayâ€”I read them the first dayâ€”I tried to put the card togetherâ€”the person I saw in the street was dressed as a letter-carrierâ€”I cannot tell you whether he had an Inverness cape onâ€”he passed us on the same side of the streetâ€”I knew his faceâ€”I had only spoken to him once; that is about a month or five weeks ago, and about a fortnight before he threw the paper downâ€”besides the paper he had a letter-bag in his hand, but no letters that I know ofâ€”this was in Stephen-streetâ€”he was not delivering letters because he came straight alongâ€”I did not watch him any further after he passed usâ€”he bad a hat on.

MR. CLERK Q. Used the prisoner to deliver letters at your master's shop? A. Tee; my master often receives lettersâ€”a letter for my brother-in-law was once sent to our houseâ€”he lives at Pimlico, and it was sent back, and I told the prisoner soâ€”that was the only time I spoke to him, but I saw him twice a day.

FREDERICK WILLIAM MILLS . I shall be eleven years old next birthday, and live with my father and mother in Stephen-street, Tottenham Court-roadâ€”I have seen the prisoner delivering letters about Stephen-street but only once a day, because I go to schoolâ€”I usually see him at half-past 8 or quarter to 9â€”on Wednesday, 30th October, about half-past 2,1 was in Stephen-street with Vian and Rowe, and while we were standing together we saw the prisoner coming along Stephen-street towards Tottenham Court-roadâ€”he tore up some paper and threw it down in the road, and then stopped and picked it up, and as he came to us he took some gold out of his pocketâ€”I could not see whether it was a half-sovereign or a sovereignâ€”I helped to pick up the pieces of paper I had seen him throw down in the gutter, and took them to my motherâ€”she gave me back the same pieces, and I gave them to the boy Vian.

Cross-examined. Q. How do you say he was coming? A. Towards Tottenham Court-roodâ€”Stephen-street runs into Tottenham Court-roadâ€”I was taken to see the prisoner in custody on Fridayâ€”I think it was about a week afterwardsâ€”the police, or some persons from the Post-office, came for meâ€”they told me they wanted me to come and see whether the person in custody was the person who had thrown away the paperâ€”they took me to where he was, and the Post-office solicitor asked me if that was the personâ€”he was then in the dock, before the Magistrate, in his uniform as he is nowâ€”I cannot tell you whether the person who threw away the paper had an Inverness cape onâ€”he had his bag in his band and the half-sovereignâ€”I cannot say whether he had any letters deliveringâ€”he had none after he tore the paper upâ€”I did not talk this over with the other two little boys afterwardsâ€”they live in my neighbourhoodâ€”we spoke to each other about it directly lie had done it, and we spoke about it the day after.
MR. CLERK. Q. Do you recollect what day of the week you went to the police-court, Bow-street? A. Friday, and I saw the prisoner on Wednesday.
HENRY ROWE . I am eleven years old, and live with my father and

mother, in Tress-street, Tottenham Court-roadâ€”on the afternoon of 30th October, I was in Stephen-street, and saw the prisoner thereâ€”I had known him by sight about three weeksâ€”I had seen him round Stephen-street and Greek-street delivering lettersâ€”he has delivered letters about five times at my parents' houseâ€”on 30th October, about half-past 2 o'clock, I saw him tear up some paper and threw it away, and some money, and then he stooped and picked it upâ€”he went on past us and I helped the other boys to pick up the paperâ€”I am sure the prisoner is the man.

Cross-examined. Had he an Inverness cape on, whoever he was? A. No; he had notâ€”I know what that is; it is a cape like mineâ€”I had a talk with Mills and Vian about it next day, but did not see the prisoner till I was taken to the police-courtâ€”I know other letter carriers about there, by sight, delivering lettersâ€”I never spoke to the prisoner that I know of.

Francis Merchant, High Constable of Brathan, Herts; Benjamin Jones, Steward of the East India College, Hayleybury; Henry Perkins, coach
builder of Ware; and Charles Kitchen, a tailor, of 5l., South Moulton-street, gave the prisoner a good character.â€”
GUILTY .â€”Recommended to mercy by the Jury on account of his youth and character.

44.
MARY ANN SMITH (20)
, Feloniously killing and slaying her male infant, upon which

MR. LILLEY, for the Prosecution, offered no evidence,â€”
NOT GUILTY .

45.
ELLEN SMITH (32)
, Feloniously casting over
Richard Chapman a certain corrosive fluid, with intent to maim and disable him. Second Count, to disfigure him. Third Count, to do him some grievous bodily harm. She
PLEADED GUILTY to the Third Count.â€”
Three Years' Penal Servitude.

div0.p: PRESENT.â€”Mr. Ald CARTER; Mr. Ald. DAKIN; and Mr. COMMON SERJEANT.

div1.p:
46.
GEORGE SMITH (27) was indicted
for bigamy; to which he

PLEADED GUILTY .â€”
Confined Six Months.

47.
JOHN UNDERWOOD JOSSLYN (32)
Embezzling and stealing the sums of. 2l. 3s., 3l. 9s., and 5l., which he had received on account of
Henry Walker, his master.

HENRY WALKER . I carry on business in Gresham-street, and have also a factory at Alcester, in Warwickshireâ€”I have been obliged to reside at the factory for the greater part of the time, in consequence of ill healthâ€”I have been laid up in London for eight or ten weeks when I have been obliged to come upâ€”I am a needle manufacturerâ€”the prisoner has been in my serviceâ€”in the first instance he was engaged out of doors as town traveller, at 25s. a week, his own propositionâ€”he entered my service about April, 1858â€”in the beginning of July, the same year, I took him indoorsâ€”I paid him then 35s. a week, my propositionâ€”I increased it to 40s. at the following Christmasâ€”I also gave him a bonus the first Christmasâ€”the word "partnership" was never mentioned between ourselves in any matter of

businessâ€”the first intimation of that was when I received Mr. Clark's letterâ€”the prisoner entered his salary every week after 1st Julyâ€”he was to open all letters and reply to them; to receive all monies and to account for them, or get the work done by those under him; he was responsible for themâ€”all monies received on account of my business were to be paid in to my bankersâ€”he had no authority to indorse draftsâ€”he had authority to sign country cheques for paying in, and to draw bills on customers; but not to indorse themâ€”if a customer in the country sends to us that they have a payment to make at Barclay's, we send to Barclay's for the cheque, the cheque is brought into the warehouse, and he signs it by prosecutionâ€”he had authority to do thatâ€”he had no authority to indorse drafts or billsâ€”he has made application to me on the subject more than once.
MR. MONTAGUE CHAMBERS . Q. By letter or word of mouth? A. In both waysâ€”I think we have letters in Court in which that application was made.

MR. ROBINSON. Q. What did you tell him by word of mouth? A. I refused it, certainlyâ€”he wished to have the power of indorsing any draft, and I refusedâ€”he said, "Give me authority to indorse drafts and cheques to order"â€”I refused that authorityâ€”I said, "No; I will not give that privilege to any personâ€”I came up to Loudon in June last, to take posses
sion of the stock books, and see what was going onâ€”I was then in better health, and I came to attend to my businessâ€”I told Josslyn that I had come to look into my businessâ€”he said nothing particular; I just came to the place, and attended to the businessâ€”we had conversations subsequentlyâ€”when I Had looked at the books I found entries in the "Accounts received book," which are falsely made.

MR. CHAMBERS. Q. Are those all in Woollard's handwriting? A. No; in Josslyn's handwriting, those I am now speaking ofâ€”we call this book the "Cash accounts received," meaning what he has received from customers for goods soldâ€”ready money would come here; and remittances from cus
tomers; everything paid for goods sold.

MR. ROBINSON. Q. Each day is headed, and the receipt for that day are put down in that book? A. Just soâ€”I called Josslyn's attention to the entries of 4th July, 1861, and demanded an explanationâ€”they are entries from various country customers, and they are supposed to be amounts received by Hitchman, the travellerâ€”he had been that ground in April and May, and he had another journey subsequently; that is entered before thisâ€”it would be Josslyn's duty to see that Hitchman gave in an account when ha came from a journeyâ€”I asked, Josslyn how that was, and he referred me to Hitchman for an explanation; after that answer we partedâ€”there are some entries here that give false datesâ€”the post-marks are by Woollard; that is, the postings of the ledger.

COURT. Q. Do you mean merely that the references at the side are in Woollard's handwriting, or the posting itself if in Woollard's handwriting? A. The postings themselves, I apprehend, are in Woollard's handwriting.

MR. CHAMBERS. Q. I understand you to say that when you referred to the ledger, you found the entries in the ledger were in Woollard's hand
writing? A. I believe so, but I would not swear it without looking again at the ledger; it is not at all by that assistance that I am enabled to say that they are wrong.

MR. ROBINSON. Q. How do you mean that they are false? A. They are false in this instance first of all, from being entered on 4th July, when the journey was taken subsequentlyâ€”here is one entry, "Parsons, Colchester, amount received 5l. 18s., 6s.; 7d. discount"â€”this is entered on 4th July, in Josslyn's writing. (The ledger was here handed to the witness).
MR. CHAMBERS. Q. Is that in the ledger, in Woollard's handwriting? A. Yesâ€”the whole of the ledger is not in Woollard's writingâ€”this credit that I have referred to is.

MR. ROBINSON. Q. Did you have any conversation with Josslyn respecting that entry? A. respecting the whole of itâ€”I did not refer to the entry in the ledger, in his presenceâ€”I had this book open before meâ€”I said, "I want to know what these entries areâ€”he said he must refer me to Mr. Hitchman; Hitchman referred me to Josslynâ€”on the face of it, it is an account received by a traveller on the journey he has beenâ€”the first matter wrong in it is this, it is entered on 4th July, and the monies were received in Aprilâ€”the entries are here, and Josslyn's private marks are over them, showing when they were receivedâ€”this book purports to show when they were receivedâ€”there is a private entry over Parsons of Colchester, showing that it was paid on 26th April.

COURT. Q. But it comes under the head of 4th July? A. Yes; (reading) "Parsons, Colchester, 5l. 18s" over it are the figures "26," and above that is "April"â€”on looking at that I understand it to mean that the money was received on 26th Aprilâ€”I had an explanation also from Woollard about it.

MR. ROBIHSON. Q. Would it be the duty of Josslyn to receive those monies from Hitchman, or to account for not having received them? A. Yes; it wouldâ€”at the end of the journey the course would be to balance the journey's cash, to settle between themâ€”Josslyn has told me that Hitch
man was behindhandâ€”129l. 17s. 3d. is the amount of all these sums on 4th July, and not paid inâ€”I could get no explanation from Josslyn.
COURT. Q. What do you mean, not paid in? A. When Hitchman comes up, what money he has not sent up by post he should pay in.

MR. ROBINSON. Q. The first column takes the amounts of traveller's receipts? A. Yes; and the third column the payments in to meâ€”there was some explanation of the stock accounts that were wrongâ€”he could not explain itâ€”I discharged himâ€”he left in reference to these very mattersâ€”that was the final conversation we hadâ€”I know that Mr. Clark is the gentleman who is now defending himâ€”I received a letter from Mr. Clark in Augustâ€”I had a customer of the name of Mrs. Halford, at Warwickâ€”this letter from her has been, found amongst the documentsâ€”I found it amongst the papers in Josslya's possession, when I went to take possessionâ€”(MR. CHAMBERS objected to this letter being read until he had cross-examined as to where it was found, and about its being in Josslyn's possession. THE COURT considered that it must of course be shown to have come from the hand of the prisoner, but would admit it if it was pressed. MR. ROBINSON stated that he should prove it to be in Mrs. Halford's writing).â€”The indorsement per prosecution is Josslyn'sâ€”(read: "Warwick and Warwickshire Bank, three days after date, pay to Mr. H. Walker or order, 2l. 3s. value received, 19th September, 1860, indorsed p. p. H. Walkerâ€”that is the prisoner's handwritingâ€”he had no authority whatever to indorse that docu
mentâ€”this (produced) is a book for letters receivedâ€”if you will give me the date of the letter you have there I will refer to itâ€”at 20th September there should be an entry of the name of Halford, and the sum of 2l. 3s. against itâ€”the name of Halford, Warwick, is here on 20th September, and no money givenâ€”when he received that money it would be his duty to eater it in this bookâ€”in the cash received book there is no entry on 20th September of the name of Halford nor on any day before or afterâ€”there is no account whatever in the book for 2l. 3s. from Mrs. Halfordâ€”it was his duty to tend down to me accounts with the amount of monies paid inâ€”that
