would inform me of the name of the customer from whom the money was receivedâ€”this (produced) is the ticket.

MR. CHAMBERS. Q. Was it A weekly or daily ticket, or how? A. Made out as occasion would requireâ€”the cash was always balanced in the general cash-book at the end of the weekâ€”his instructions were that when he had 20l. he should pay in, or when he had more than 20l.

MR. ROBINSON. Q. That book contains an account day by day of the monies received by him? A. Yesâ€”(The bankers ticket being read, consisted of various items) those amount to 51l. 3s. 5d.â€”the bankers have received that moneyâ€”I cannot tell at all how the various monies have been paid, what cash or notes; at a distance of 150 miles it is impossible to tellâ€”I am looking at the cash received in that weekâ€”the whole six days added together amount to 79l. 7s. 8d.â€”they are added and cast up in Josslyn's handwriting, for every dayâ€”they are cast up daily, and transferred to that book daily there is a weekly casting up of that book, and a weekly casting up from this bookâ€”the whole amount received is 79l. 7s. 8d.â€”there are two bills which make up that amountâ€”he accounts in this cash-book for having received that sum from various persons, and 2l. 3s. is not included in that accountâ€”the amount of receipts on the 17th, is 15l. 4s. 2d.â€”that is made up of amounts received from several personsâ€”(The witness here read several amounts from the ledger)â€”that altogether makes 79l. 7s. 8dâ€”in the general cash-book I find all those accounts carried oat correctly as I have read them just nowâ€”on this side, is represented the amounts that he received during the past weekâ€”in order to discharge himself of that sum, he first of all sends me the two bills, for 17l. 11s. 9d. and 10l. 12s. 6d.â€”the banker's ticket is 51l. 3s. 5d.â€”adding those three together, they make up the sum of 79l. 7s. 8.

COURT. Q. He sends you two bills making up the balance? A. Yes; it was his duty to enter it in the ledger to Mrs. Halford's account, to give her credit for it, or to have it done by a clerk under himâ€”the credit entries in this ledger are in Josslyn's handwriting; the debit posting are Woollard'sâ€”the casting up on the debit side is Josslyn's, and the casting is wrongâ€”the debit side shows cast up, 7l. 1s.â€”the credit side is cast up 4l. 4s. 2d., and the debit side is also made 4l. 4s. 2d. by Josslynâ€”there are several entrier that have been mala sinceâ€”as it is now put, it would appear to balance, and it is ruled off as though it were balanced.

COURT. Q. Are the credits rightly added? A. One is not added, the other is; but if you cast it up, the credits would amount to the same sumâ€”the amounts are 4l. 2s., and 2s. 2d. discount, and the debit side is cast so as to show 4l. 4s. 2d.
MR. ROBINSON. Q. You know nothing about that 13s. 10d. I suppose? A. Nothing whateverâ€”of these papers (produced), this is in Webb's writing, and this I presume to be Mrs. Halford's.

MR. CHAMBERS. Q. What do you call being in Josslyn's possession, were they open drawers, or was there a desk, or what was there? A. He had a desk with drawersâ€”the drawers were locked when I went to themâ€”he unlocked them and looked through his papers to see if there was any private matter that he wished to take awayâ€”his duty was to keep the desk lockedâ€”I cannot tell you whether they were always kept lookedâ€”when I went to his desk it was net openâ€”the key was handed to meâ€”the desk was locked up, and I opened it with the key and took possession of all the papers I found thereâ€”that letter was not in Mr. Josslyn's desk; it was with a parcel tied up, in the warehouse, Webb's letters and ordersâ€”Josslyn might either tie

them himself or put some one else to do it, as he pleasedâ€”his duty was to do the work, or get it done by persons about himâ€”(a letter from Webb to the prisoner was here read stating that the account of his journey had duly reached him, and that he (the prisoner) had not credited Noon, of Leamington, last journey with cash 30s. Hart, of Warwick, 1l. 3s. 6d., debtor 1s., 1l. 4s. 6d.; and that Halford, of Warwick, had sent up to the bank 2l. 3s. and paid him 13s. 10d which amounted to 2l. 16s. 10d.â€”"Warwick, February 27th, 1861, to Mr. H. Walker; Sir, I hare returned your statement, not owing you for either of the items; on September 19th, I sent you a draft for 2l. 3s.; I paid Mr. Webb 13s. 10d., February 6th, 1861, ditto 4l. 2s. I owe you for the last order to Mr. Webb; send me the statement, I will remit you the amount and close my account with you, Yours respectfully, E. Halford)â€”Mrs. Pfeil is a customer of mineâ€”there is no entry in the cash received book on 9th December, 1860, to 5l. received from Mrs. Pfeilâ€”this letter is in Josslyn's handwritingâ€”(Read: "47, Gresham-street, London, December 10th, 1860, Mrs. Pfeil, Madam, I have placed to credit your remittance of 5l., for which I am obliged; waiting your further favours. I am, yours respectfully, for H. Walker, Josslyn")â€”there is no credit to Mrs. Pfeil on that day in the cash-bookâ€”there is no entry of 5l. at or near that dateâ€”at April 16th, 1861; I have an entry in the cash-book to Mrs. Pfeil, of 5l.â€”there is no entry there of a receipt of 51. from a Mr. Emmensâ€”(another ledger (M) was here handed to the witness).

MR. CHAMBERS. Q. Whose account is that that you are looking at? A. Ledger M is where the account begins, and it is transferred to other B. ledgers in the course of businessâ€”it is carried on to another folio here in C. ledger M, and one in the other ledger O.
MR. ROBINSON. Q. Have you told us there is no entry of the 5l.? A. There is no entryâ€”there is an entry on 16th April, of 5l., the same folio at the cash-book.

MA. CHAMBERS . Q. Are they both in Josslyn's handwriting, in the cash received book, is that Josslyn's hand-writing? A. Yes; in the ledger it is posted by Woollardâ€”Josslyn's writing is the original entryâ€”that brings the account into my houseâ€”all subsequent transactions are minor; that is my opinion.

MR. ROBINSON. Q. Had you employed Messrs. Ashley and Tee to collect certain debts of yours? A. Yes; and I had given Josslyn directions with respect to them; that any accounts that were due which he could not recover in a reasonable time, they were to recoverâ€”I have the book of that Messrs. Ashley and Tee were to collectâ€”I instructed Josslyn to out a ledger for themâ€”this (produced) is the book in which he was to make out the accounts I wished them to collectâ€”Gelding's account is transferred hereâ€”I find no entry here of a sum of 3l. 9s. to the credit of Goldingâ€”there is a debitâ€”if he had received 3l. 9s. from Messrs Ashley and Tee on my account from Golding, it should have first come into the accounts received, and then hereâ€”it is not in the accounts received Mrs. Pfeil's account begins September 10th; on that day there is no account of her payment, in the cash received bookâ€”the 5l. does not appearâ€”there is no credit whatever for any sum at or near that dateâ€”there is precisely the same condition with regard to Goldingâ€”there is no entry there whatever in the creditâ€”the signature to this paper is in Josslyn's handwriting; the other part is notâ€”(Read: "Walker v. Golding, received 15th October, 1861, of Messrs. Ashley and Tee, the sum of 3l. 9s. debt herein, signed for Walker by Josslyn")â€”a post-office order for that amount is paid inâ€”this

paper gives an account of the money paidâ€”it begins, "P.O.O.," post-office orderâ€”this is the banker's ticket issued by one of their clerksâ€”in the cash receipt book on 15th October, there is no such entry as that of Goldingâ€”on that day in October or subsequently, at the end of the week, he gave an account of all monies received in that time; there is no entry of Golding's name at all, nor the amount of 3l. 9s.

MR. CHAMBERS. Q. At the end of the week, did not he send you that slip of paper that had passed through the bankers? A. Yes; be pays in the money order to the bankâ€”he does not debit himself with the cash.

MR. ROBINSON. Q. How much does he admit having received at the end of that week, take the general cash-book and the cash received book? A. He takes 70l. 6s. 10d., but this week is balanced two weeks together, and the two weeks will require to be added together; and he has received by his own writing 10l. more; 10l. less one week, 10l. more the next; that balances the bookâ€”the account here corresponds with the account in the cash received bookâ€”that 70l. odd is accounted for in various namesâ€”on the 15th there are a number of itemsâ€”I am referring to those in Josslyn's handwritingâ€”on 15th October, there is (reading various names and accounts), that is one day, amounting to 43l. 10s.

Cross-examined by MR. CHAMBERS (with MR. LILLEY). Q. Tell me how long the prisoner had actually been employed by you before you quarreled? A. I must have my book if you want a very exact dateâ€”three years and three monthsâ€”he was employed as my town traveller till the end of June, 1858â€”I was not my own manager at that time; a person of the name of Vernell wasâ€”he went abroad; to New Zealand, I thinkâ€”I had no dispute whatever with himâ€”I have had. many cases of embezzlementâ€”I have charged four; they have all pleaded guiltyâ€”I have had about ten or eleven previously who have been dishonestâ€”one brought an action against me for slander; an attorney's actionâ€”he recovered 5l.; damages were laid at 1,000l.â€”that must be three years and three-quarters, or about four years agoâ€”that was before Mr. Josslyn came into my employmentâ€”Mr. Vernell recommended Mr. Josslyn to meâ€”he became my manager in July, 1858â€”I had an esta
blishment at Alcesterâ€”the establishment in London was at 47, Gresham-street, Cityâ€”I can only, by referring to my book, tell what other persons were in my employ at the establishment at Gresham-street at the time I took him into my employâ€”I had a Miss Hill in the warehouse, and a Miss Caw
thorne; I could tell you in a minute from my bookâ€”there were probably two more clerks; I think one was named Staff and the other was an errand boyâ€”I sell needles at Gresham-street, wholesale onlyâ€”that is our rule, but we have customers apply to us retail sometimesâ€”any retail customer that could not get my goods would be supplied without hesitationâ€”if you were to come in and say, "I cannot get your goods anywhere in the neighbour
hood, "I should allow you to buy a packet of needlesâ€”the smallest packet we sell is, I should say, of one hundred needlesâ€”that would cost a shillingâ€”I also supply the retail shops in London and in the countryâ€”I give credit to the retail shops in London, and to the customers in the countryâ€”I cannot tell you the number of accounts that were open in my books between the years 1858 and 1860â€”I should think very likely there were as many as between 1,500 and 2,000 open accounts, at one time and anotherâ€”it is quite possibleâ€”those accounts were not all open at one timeâ€”there could not have been more than 1,500 open accounts on my books at the time he and I quarrelled; you may find that number of namesâ€”there is very little doubt that there were 1,500 names or more in the ledgersâ€”my customers some
times

order things by letter, and sometimes otherwise; sometimes through the traveller, and sometimes by callingâ€”I do not call it a quarrel that we hadâ€”I had two travellers out in the country at the time Mr. Josslyn left my serviceâ€”we have had two out constantly between 1858 and 1861â€”he has given commissions to other people who are not strictly travellers; commis
sion travellers; I suppose about four or perhaps five, besides my regular travellersâ€”the commission travellers transmitted orders as well as moneyâ€”it was the duty of the travellers in the country to write letters from day to day as to what orders they had received, as well as what money they had receivedâ€”it was the duty of Mr. Josslyn to open all the letters that came to my warehouse at Gresham-street, to see what orders were in them, and to see what monies were paid and transmittedâ€”it is quite possible that he would find an order in one letter for so many different sorts of needlesâ€”it would be his duty to give the order out to be put up by other personsâ€”at one time it would have been Miss Cawthorue's duty, at another time Miss Hill's dutyâ€”it would have been his duty to see that the orders were executedâ€”I cannot say how many petty orders might come on an average in a day from the country for him to look to their being executedâ€”if the traveller transmitted monies or cheques, the prisoner would have to account for them in his bookâ€”the travellers would send up what sums they had in hand, and he would credit themâ€”they would send it up by cheque, or notes, or any way that would be convenient to themâ€”the traveller might send up a bill of exchange sometimes if he chose; there would be no reason why he should notâ€”if he had a bill sent by the customer he would, send it upâ€”credit would be given to our customersâ€”if they accept bills they come into the ordinary cash-book.

Q. Supposing one of your customers could not pay, and he said, "I will accept a bill for, we will say, 10l. at three months or so on," would that be sent up to the prisoner? A. The proper course would be for it to be drawn at the warehouse; it would not be sent upâ€”it would be drawn at the ware-house, sent down for acceptance, and then returned to the warehouseâ€”that was also the manager's duty; it was a very light one, probably two or three hills a week to drawâ€”they would not average two or three a weekâ€”when 1 say two or three a week I put it at the utmost limitâ€”it would be his duty also to exercise his judgment as to whether he could give that credit.

Q. You say sometimes the traveller would write and say, "I will have a cheque for you at Thompson and Company's," or something of that sort; "Miss Tomkins has directed her banker, Barclay's, to pay you 1l. 16s.; you will find a cheque there?" A. That might occur, but it would be a very rare thingâ€”I gave him no power to indorse chequesâ€”I have given a power of a limited character, which I can explainâ€”the power is this; he is to sign cheques by procuration to pay in, but not to indorseâ€”I wrote to my banker, in all probability, at the early part of the engagement, when he came inâ€”my bankers are Puget, Bainbridge's, and Companyâ€”one of their clerks is here.

Q. It is a clerk who knows how often he has signed your name by pro
curation? A. The clerk has come for another purposeâ€”unless this clerk knows how often from 1858 to 1861 he signed my name by procuration, I cannot tell youâ€”the cheques to which I allow him to sign my name by pro
curation are cheques to be paid in, country chequesâ€”the course of business is this: a country customer writes to Gresham-street and says, "Call at Barclay's," or some other house, "for so much money;" a person is sent to Barclay's country office, and inquires for a cheque, the name of H. Walker,

of the amount stated, from the town the party writes from; that is the first step; then the cheque comes back to the warehouse, and the thing is signed by procuration for H. Walker, by Josslynâ€”his duty, on receiving such a letter from a country customer, was to send for the cheque, not to go for itâ€”I do not know that over and over again he went and signed the cheque by procurationâ€”I am not certain about itâ€”he would send some person, and that person would get a cheque from Barclay's, filled all but the signature, and then he would have to sign itâ€”post-office orders used to come up some
timesâ€”he would sign them, and pay them in to my bankersâ€”sometimes country bank notes used to come upâ€”there were commission travellers, regular travellers, and private customers writing from the country every day, with reference to orders and to payments; that is the ordinary course of businessâ€”I have no London travellers out at the present timeâ€”between 1858 and 1861 there were probably four.
COURT. Q. Were there ever four at one time? A. Not at one time.

MR. CHAMBERS. Q. How many had you out generally at a time? A. Generally twoâ€”I think at one time there was a commission travellerâ€”the commission travellers get orders sometimesâ€”it was not their duty to receive moniesâ€”they were not to collect moniesâ€”the regular town travellers did not collect monies; it was not their dutyâ€”Webb was a country traveller, not a town travellerâ€”I have not the least idea of how many open accounts there were in the town districtâ€”I have looked into itâ€”I have two town ledgers here that will give you the names of all of themâ€”I should say the number is over five hundredâ€”I am my own accountantâ€”I have gone through my accounts; not so as to tell how many open town accounts there were for Mr. Josslyn to attend toâ€”there could not be a thousandâ€”I have taken it at five hundredâ€”there were as many names of town accounts as five hundred on my books when Mr. Josslyn left my service, but, not as many standing openâ€”some had been balancedâ€”my belief is that I had not, at that time, more than five hundred town customers on my booksâ€”I cannot swear to itâ€”I cannot tell you at all what is the smallest amount for which an account was opened in my booksâ€”it is quite possible for lest than 10s. with any respectable person; some for 5s.

Q. What is the lowest you would allow an account to be opened in your books? A It is not a question of what I would allow, when I am not pre
sent at the timeâ€”I cannot tell you the lowest sum for which an account has been opened in my book; may be a half-crownâ€”my town travellers had not the privilege of collecting moniesâ€”the London customers sent their money, or they were called on by a clerkâ€”Woollard the ledger clerk used to go roundâ€”I called him ledger or desk clerkâ€”his duty was to make out invoices and collect monies, and so onâ€”he used not to go round London every dayâ€”some of the customers came to pay at the warehouseâ€”we have only one account for monies receivedâ€”anything that was money he would enter.
COURT. Q. Supposing he received 3l. in the course of the day, were all the items specified? A. Yes; we do not ask all the customers what their names are.

MR. CHAMBERS. Q. Do you put "R M." for ready money? A. Yes; if a customer came from Lambeth to pay and account of half-a-crown it would be entered in his name; and if another came to pay 1l. we should enter it, and so on. Q. Can you give me an idea of how many entries he would be called on to make in that extended way? A. Here is an account, first day, two names, second day, four names, nine names the third day, five names the next, and one the nextâ€”that is about October 15th, 1860â€”when he had received half-a-crown from a Lambeth customer it would be entered

in that bookâ€”he would not enter that againâ€”he counts up the day's monies and the cash accounts received, and then that day's money is carried to this book; each day is carried inâ€”I had in the warehouse during the time, from 1859 to 1861, two females, Miss Hill and Miss Cawthorneâ€”there would also be Woollard, Thorpe, Greenway, Jones a boy, and I believe there was another name, but I cannot recollectâ€”they would not be there all at one timeâ€”there would be five in my employ at one timeâ€”it would be the two young ladies who would have the privilege of selling packets of needles, and receiving the money for themâ€”if Woollard was out, at the banker's, they would be obliged to take the monies, and also receive debts that were dueâ€”Woollard would also do the sameâ€”it would be their duty to hand the money over to Josslynâ€”he would depend on the integrity of the others for what they gave him being all rightâ€”I do not recollect any other duties that he had to do, besides those I have enumeratedâ€”he did not come in the morning at half past 8 and open the establishmentâ€”he came at a quarter to 9â€”his time for leaving varied from half-past 6 to 7, and on Saturday earlierâ€”3 o'clock is our time on Saturdayâ€”I really cannot tell how long that has existedâ€”as soon as he had 20l. he had to pay the money into my banker'sâ€”that was the rule laid down; and another instruction was, that he should never pass a week without a balancingâ€”he was at all times to balance the entire receipts on the Saturdayâ€”as he sent money to the bankers, he sent one of these slips of paperâ€”they make their own investigation of that paper, and send it backâ€”if he sent in a 5l. country note I cannot tell at all whether the bankers would know that he did soâ€”I cannot tell whether the bankers would be able to tell whether that entry of "notes 40l." on 22d September, applied to country or town notesâ€”there is a banker's clerk hereâ€”I cannot tell whether there is to anybody here who can tell you what amounts made up the 40l., and what kind of monies made up the 6l. 15s. 5d.â€”the slip of paper would be sent with the moneyâ€”when that had got the initial of the banker's clerk, the prisoner transmitted it to meâ€”how often he sent them to me would depend upon circumstances; for instance, how often he got themâ€”when he had paid monies in, he sent me these down, and I kept them down at Alcesterâ€”I have a great many of themâ€”the prisoner was suspended on 15th July, and discharged on the 16th, which was Tuesday, I thinkâ€”it was in consequence of something in the account of Hitchmanâ€”I do not know what has become of Hitchmanâ€”he was in my service up to 20th June, or thereaboutsâ€”he was country travellerâ€”I did not discharge himâ€”he has gone awayâ€”I had him in my service about eighteen months, I thinkâ€”I can give you the exact date.

Q. I believe as soon as the defendant was discharged from your service, or very shortly afterwards, he set up on his own account, did he not, very close to you? A. I do not know anything of that at allâ€”I was in town for several days after I had discharged himâ€”I know nothing of his being in business, except by reportâ€”I know the house 10, Huggin-lane, when I see itâ€”it is perhaps sixty yards from my warehouse in Gresham-streetâ€”I have not been to the place where he was in business since the report reached meâ€”I have not passed through itâ€”I have not avoided itâ€”I have been in Huggin-lane but not since the reportâ€”I cannot give you the date when I heard the report; it was a few days before he was taken in custodyâ€”it was mentioned by some one in the warehouse; I cannot say by whomâ€”I cannot recollect how long it was after the prisoner was discharged, that I received a letter from Mr. Clark; it was more than a week afterâ€”I only know by the letterâ€”that letter would, of course, inform me that by inquiry of Mr. Clark I could find out where he was.

Q. How long before you caused him to be taken in custody, did you know where to find him? A. I did not know where to find him at the timeâ€”it was about 30th October that I caused him to be taken into custodyâ€”he was taken in custody at Huggin-laneâ€”that was supposed to be his place of businessâ€”the order was given overnight to the officer; wherever he could find him he was to take himâ€”I did not know he was to be found in Huggin-lane; we thought he would be found there the was looked for there, and we found him thereâ€”he was taken to Guildhall within an hour or two of his being taken up, and there appeared Mr. Robinson, the attorney, and myselfâ€”I never sent to him and said that I had found an error in his accounts; that was at the conversation before he left usâ€”there was never any any talk about a partnershipâ€”before he left I had taken the accounts received book and one of the ledgers to my apartments in Wells-streetâ€”I had done that perhaps two days before he left; I cannot tell to a dayâ€”I cannot tell whether they were at my place of business when he left; they were either there then or within a short time afterwardsâ€”my practice was to take them out and bring them backâ€”I did not come up occasionally to look at the accounts; I am speaking of what occurred in Julyâ€”my practice was to bring the books out in the morning and take them back in the evening, and some
times when they were heavy, a boy did that for roeâ€”that was the practice at that timeâ€”when I came up from the country I did not go through my booksâ€”it was my practice at that particular time to take the books awayâ€”I did it three or four times, night after night; that was since he left meâ€”I never took away the books before he left me, previously to the date I have mentionedâ€”there had not been any conversation between the prisoner and me, with reference to his having anything like a share or a commission for business that was doneâ€”the arrangement was made voluntarily on my side, if the business improved he was to receive a bonus, in addition to his salaryâ€”if the profits increased largely be would have a larger bonusâ€”if they increased to a small amount he would have a smaller bonusâ€”if there was no profit he would get nothing; and if there was a lass he would lose nothingâ€”he was not entitled to a bonus until a profit was ascertained; then he was not entitled to it, but as a matter of giftâ€”I must first ascertain from my stock books if a profit is made, to ascertain if there was to be a bonus, and if so whether it was a large or a small oneâ€”I had no commu
nication from the attorney, applying to see the booksâ€”I received this letter from Mr. Clark on or about the date of the letterâ€”(letter read; "August 17th, 1861. Sir, I have been consulted by Mr. Josslyn, with whom you have for sometime past carried on business as co-partners. I am instructed that you have removed from the business premises many of the books of account, and have taken means to prevent Mr. Josslyn having access to any of them. I have, therefore, on his behalf to request you will appoint some time and place where Mr. Josslyn, with his accountant, may examine all the books that have been in use since the formation of the partnership, and take an account of the business, &c. so that your respective interests therein may be ascertained. Upon hearing from you, that you are ready to comply with this requisition, Mr. Josslyn will, if you wish it, submit to you the name of the accountant he will employ, before, com
mencing the examination and taking of the accounts. I an further in
structed to inform you, that if this request be not complied with proceedings will be commenced in chancery for the purpose of having the accounts taken there. Waiting the favour, of your reply. I am, sir, your obedient servant, THOMAS CLARK. To Mr. Henry Walker, 47, Gresham-street, City.")â€”I took

no notice of that at allâ€”I was in London when I received itâ€”(another letter read: "August 26th, 1861.â€”Sir, before commencing proceedings, I write again to request you will inform me whether you will afford an opportunity for the partnership accounts between yourself and Mr. Josslyn, to be taken. If I do not hear from you in the course of a week from this date, as my letter to you of the 9th, remains unacknowledged, I shall conclude you do not intend replying to my letter, and then shall act accordingly. I am, sir, your obedient servant, THOMAS CLARK. To Mr. Henry Walker, 47, Gresham street, City")â€”I was in London when I received thatâ€”I think it is more than likely that I had remained in London from the time when Mr. Josslyn was discharged, up to August 26thâ€”I cannot say for certainâ€”I was away for three days about that period, just before or just afterâ€”my books were all in my warehouse when I received that letter of Mr. Clark's of 17th Augustâ€”I gave no answer to either of his letters in any wayâ€”I made no inquiries as to where Mr. Josslyn wasâ€”I cannot tell you when I first gave instructions to the police-officer to take him in custodyâ€”the instructions were in all probability given the day beforeâ€”I had not submitted my books to an accountantâ€”I had submitted them to my own examination.

Q. I see that Mr. Clark does propose that an accountant should be named by him and by you, to go through the booksâ€”that was as early as 17th August? A. That was for a very different purposeâ€”I took his two letters to my solicitor, and begged he would take no notice of themâ€”I did not write to Mr. Clark to say who my solicitor wasâ€”my books have never been sub
mitted to a regular accountant; only to my own examinationâ€”I have been used to accounts all my lifeâ€”I am more than an average accountant; I won't say a clever oneâ€”Mrs. Halford's case was not perfectly clear to me within a few days after he had leftâ€”it was more than a month before I found out anything about it, long after the end of Augustâ€”I and my assistants got through the books before we found that outâ€”Smith is one of my assistants, another is named Tnglemanâ€”neither of them are hereâ€”in Mrs. Halford's case, a draft was paid in to my banker'sâ€”he had no right to indorse thatâ€”I have not had the money for that draftâ€”the banker's give me credit for the draft, but I have not had the moneyâ€”they credit me with the amount of 2l. 3s., Mrs. Halford's draft on Glyn and Co.â€”I got a paper at the end of that week that had passed through the bankersâ€”this is the paperâ€”it is the banker's credit note, initialed by the bank-clerkâ€”they give credit for Mrs. Halford's chequeâ€”it is not entered in the cash receipt-book at allâ€”it ought to have the name of Mrs. Halford as paying thatâ€”there is no sum of 2l. 3s. against Mrs. Halford's name thereâ€”the name is not written hereâ€”Mrs. Halford's name is not here at all about this dateâ€”the entry, "September 20th, Haines of Wend over," is Josslyn's writing, and also the 21stâ€”I rely upon this book in the first instanceâ€”the next would be the general cash-bookâ€”this "N. W. bill," is a bill sent to meâ€”that 10l. 12s. 6d. is a bill with another nameâ€”accounts received are on the left-hand side; paid to bank, on the right-handâ€”I cannot tell how long I discovered Halford's case before I gave the prisoner into custodyâ€”I should say six weeks after he had leftâ€”I had to go down in the country two or three timesâ€”I had to go through the books two or three times before I found it out, and made it plain to myselfâ€”I think in Miss Pfeil's case, there were two half notes sent upâ€”her letters are in Courtâ€”my impression is, that she sent up the 5l. in two halvesâ€”I did take the trouble to investigateâ€”it would not follow that two half notes would be paid into the bank, because we received two half notesâ€”they may or they may not have been

paid into the bankâ€”Miss Pfeil lives at Lincolnâ€”I have not found out whether those two half notes were of a Lincolnshire noteâ€”I have not asked the question of my bankers or of Miss Pfeilâ€”I have asked for the number of that note and could not get it from Miss Pfeilâ€”I did not then find out whether it was a Lincolnshire bank-noteâ€”I never asked whether it was a country noteâ€”it was very recently that I asked the number of itâ€”it was longer ago than when I gave the prisoner in custody that I asked the questionâ€”I have looked at the ledger with reference to that 3l. 9d. of Golding'sâ€”that is transferred to Ashley and Teeâ€”I have got the account in the ledger, "Golding of Dart fordâ€”the 3l. 9d. is entered as transferred to Ashley and Teeâ€”the money has not come to me.

Q. I find here, in 1860, you credit them, or they are credited by cash, 2l. February 9th, then Ashley and Co. 3l. 9d. 1d.? A. Yes; he had not received that 3l. 9d. 1d. by the post-office order at that timeâ€”the account is "Ashley and Co. 3l. 9d."â€”that 3l. 9d. is entered to the credit of Goldingâ€”it doses his accountâ€”the post-office order of Golding is paid to the credit of the bankâ€”the sum is here, and also in the post-office orderâ€”the prisoner was to put into the hands of Ashley and Tee a list of overdue accountsâ€”on August 22d, he charges them with 3l. 9d. 1d. to be collected through the instrumentality of the attorniesâ€”they collect it, and he ought to have put in this 3l. 9d. 1d. that he had received from Goldingâ€”it is not thereâ€”Mr. Emmens is here, I believeâ€”I have not the slightest idea what sort of a note he sent upâ€”if anything came from Ashley and Tee's, I got the usual memo
randum, or banker's receipt, so as to show what he paid into the bank that weekâ€”the prisoner gave me, up his keys previous to going awayâ€”he gave me up some money, not a considerable sum, about 37l. 0s. 5d. which was found in his drawerâ€”that was the proper place for itâ€”when I was ex
amined at Guildhall, I did not know what sum he had given upâ€”I had no book to refer to, and I did not knowâ€”I was examined at Guildhall some
where about 12th Novemberâ€”I could not tell how much money I bad found in the drawer at the time I discharged himâ€”I was not prepared to tell, I never counted it at allâ€”I gave it to Woolard to countâ€”it is not simply from Woollard's statement that I know the amountâ€”the money was not out of my possessionâ€”I saw Woollard count itâ€”the memorandum was made by Josslyn himselfâ€”he was not present when I caused the money to be countedâ€”he gave me the money with his memorandumâ€”I have got his memorandumâ€”I had not it with me at the time I was examined, on 12th Novemberâ€”he did not make his accounts up when he leftâ€”we did not call on him to do so, nor to balance his booksâ€”he gave me the paper explaining his balanceâ€”I did not call on him to balance his booksâ€”he gave me several papers, explaining the balance to meâ€”it was on the Monday that the money was given up, and then he gave me some memorandum with reference to the money that was in the drawerâ€”I was examined twice at Guildhallâ€”I was never asked the question whether he handed me over a sum of money on his departureâ€”I never mentioned itâ€”it was 37l. 0s. 5d.â€”part of it was the week's receiptsâ€”I could not call on him before giving him into custody, to come and explain those entries which he had wrongly, made or omitted to make; I did not do soâ€”I never have called on him to come and explain how it is that I have found what I considered to be false entriesâ€”an order was given that he should be taken into custody, prior to my hearing that he was carrying on business in Huggin-laneâ€”I cannot tell you when that order was givenâ€”it was given to the officerâ€”I don't know whether he is here, I think he isâ€”I cannot tell whether I gave it myselfâ€”

I think it was by me or in my presenceâ€”I did not, at the time I told Bull to take him in custody, tell him that he had nothing to do but to go and inquire of his attorney in Dean's-court to find himâ€”I did not tell Bull that the best way would be to go to Mr. Clark's, and that Mr. Clark would give the prisoner's addressâ€”we knew where he lived, Queen's-road or King's-road, Chelseaâ€”I do not know the numberâ€”I knew he lived with his father-in-lawâ€”to the best of my knowledge, he had lived with him all the time he had been in my serviceâ€”I told Bull once to take him in custody, and then we stopped itâ€”I wished to find some informationâ€”Woollard absconded about a fortnight after Josslyn wentâ€”I have tried to find him but cannotâ€”another man absconded, not Hitchman; he has gone through the insolvent courtâ€”he is behind you nowâ€”I did not bring him here as a witnessâ€”I do not know where Hitchman livesâ€”I have never inquiredâ€”the alleged cause for dismissing the prisoner was, that there had been some tampering with Hitch manâ€™s accountsâ€”I have asked Hitchman for informationâ€”I am not going to call him as a witnessâ€”he is going through the insolvent court a second timeâ€”I have not been up there as a witnessâ€”they have cheated me between them, without a doubt.

Q. How is it you have not taken Hitchman into custody? A. The matter is in the hands of my solicitorâ€”I have not charged him with embezzling moneyâ€”I believe the two have embezzled my money between themâ€”I do believe that Hitchman hasâ€”I first believed that, when I saw those entriesâ€”Hitchman did not continue in my service after thatâ€”I first heard that he was going through the insolvent court by a notice he sent me about a month ago I should thinkâ€”I have not been up to the Insolvent court to oppose him, it is too early to give any notice.

MR. ROBINSON. Q. What has Hitchman made you a creditor to the amount of? A. Hitchman says that he owes 55l.â€”that has been for monies that he has received on my account on the journeysâ€”the report about the prisoner being in business in Huggin-lane has nothing at all to do with Hitchman, that I am aware ofâ€”I have not been up Huggin-lane, and do not know who Josslyn was in partnership withâ€”when I was examined before the Magistrate I was not aware of the amount of cash delivered when Josslyn wentâ€”I produce these papers; they explain how the 37l. cash that he left is made upâ€”it is made as part of the last week's statement, as regards the rest, there is a certain sum owing to his other creditâ€”he has borrowed from the other cash 12l. which is deficient thereâ€”here is a paper in my handwriting that would show very clearly how that goes to make up the 37l.â€”these memoranda were made subsequently to my analysis of the accountâ€”the paper about the money that he left is not hereâ€”he left this paper with me, and another, which I have not hereâ€”this is the paper which has been left with the cash, and which has not been before the Magistrateâ€”the cash corresponds with it, and it is initialed by the bank clerk as having been paid inâ€”this account corresponds with the various accounts that he leftâ€”it was simply the last week's cashâ€”there is no debit to the account of Goldingâ€”when an account was put into the book for Messrs. Ashley and Tee to collect, the prisoner's duty would be to enter it at the date that he transferred it to Ashley and Teeâ€”the accounts were put into their hands in the springâ€”the 3l. 9s. should come into this book at once, and then it should come to the hands of Ashley and Teeâ€”the clerks were not all in my service at the same timeâ€”I have had four who have embezzled; they have pleaded guiltyâ€”that has been at various times in twenty-eight years' tradingâ€”what I mean by light work is work that the prisoner could do in a short space of timeâ€”he never complained of

being overworked, or wanting more helpâ€”mine is a wholesale warehouseâ€”sometimes I might not sell one shilling packet for a weekâ€”my retail trade is very littleâ€”I would much rather have been without itâ€”I have bad occasion to bring actions in the Lord Mayor's courtâ€”the signature to that affidavit (produced) is in Josslyn's handwritingâ€”I recollect about January; 1859, writing him a letter, inclosing him some amount for distribution-my letters to him were left by him in the drawersâ€”(MR. CHAMBERS objected to these letters being read. THE COURT considered that they arm out of the cross-examination. Readâ€”"Alcester, January 4th, 1859, Mr. J. U. Josslyn Dear sir, I in close herewith the returns which I think you will find by the day-book are correct. I am sorry to find the sum is much deficient of what I expected to reach; my undertaking, therefore, if strictly carried out, falls to the ground. There are, however, with diminished sales, some indications of better prospects. The returns are made at no greater relative expenses and I am inclined to believe there are less bad debts in the last six months trading, than in the corresponding period. The greater of course the returns, the less relative expense there ought to be; and the fewer bad debts, the less there is to be added to expenses in the shape of loss. Viewing all things, I am still inclined to do in part what I weald have preferred doing entire, if the trade had come up to the amount I therefore inclose herein a cheque for 25l. to be disposed of thus:â€”of the amount, 15l. for yourself, and 5l. for Miss Cawthorne, and the same for Miss Hill. There are many matters in the stock-books that will need great attention, more particularly all the larger articles in muslin; these are, or have been, helps to the amount of returns, but your trade for them is gone; the reason must be found out. If it can be altered here or by you, so much the better; but if not, we shall want something to make up for what will be future deficiency if not considered at once. The older articles, and in fact, every article in needles must be considered. The fancy box-trade is lost; the ridged eyes will be or should be extras. I have a heavy stock yet of all other goods, from six to eight millions of drilled eyed sharps; they are nothing in the needle trade. Sixteen millions were ordered one day recently in one order, I am told, at Redditch. Large orders produce quick cask returns; small orders the contrary. In the one case many profits are made in a year with the same capital; bat with me I only turn capital once a year This is the old style of trading and wants your greatest consideration with a view to alter it I have some articles you sell regularly which can be only made about once in five years, you sell so few; yet they are sold regu
larly, tons weight at a time. Hoping you will all feel satisfied with this inclosure, and wishing we may succeed better in the next six months, I remain, Yours very truly, H. Walker. Sales July 3d, 1858, to December 18th, 1858, 3,425l. 19s. 5d. Twenty-five weeks, average per week, 137l. 0s. 9d. Sales June 7th, 1857, to December 26th, 1857, twenty-seven weeks, net, 4,4741, 16s. 1d., add 2 1/2 percent, all discount being taken off, 109l. 17s. 6d., total, 4,584l. 13s. 7d. Twenty-seven weeks, weekly average, without the 109l. 17s. 6d., 165l. 14s. 8d.")

Another letter. "London, January 5th, 1859. To Mr. H. Walker. Dear sir, I have received yours this morning. Miss Cawthorne and self beg to offer our best thanks for cheque inclosed, and which folly satisfies us. I could hardly have expected under all circumstances to have equalled the amount of last year, considering when I came we had no travellers, and the first five weeks we did not average more than 65l. per week. We have not been so low since until last week; but I hope not to have another so bad,

and I am sure you may rely upon the utmost being done to carry out all your instructions to increase the business, &c. Signed, John U. Josslyn)."â€”That 25l. was sent entirely as a presentâ€”I subsequently to that gave Josslyn and Miss Cawthorne something, several times, in fact every stock taking I gave them somethingâ€”they never made any claim on me for that sum as one I was bound to payâ€”it was never questioned that that was a giftâ€”no question was ever raisedâ€”a conversation took place between me and Josslyn at the beginning of this year, not about giving him anything: it was of this nature, the profits had not realized what I had expected; but at the same time I told him that if they increased sufficiently, I would give him an advanced salary, the bonus system did not workâ€”he assented to that.

ELIZABETH HALFORD . I carry on business at Warwickâ€”I recollect being indebted to Mr. Walker in the sum of 2l. 3s. in September, 1860â€”I wrote him the note which is here, and inclosed him this draftâ€”I never got any receipt for itâ€”I recollect subsequently seeing Webb, Mr. Walker's travellerâ€”the date of that is on the receipt, 3d Octoberâ€”I paid him the 13s. 10d.â€”he made a larger demand on me than that, and I wrote him a letterâ€”I paid that as a balance, settling the amount.
Cross-examined. Q. Are you a customer still? A. Yes.

JOHN WEBB . I am a traveller in the service of Mr. Walkerâ€”I recollect on 3d October, 1860, calling on Mrs. Halford, of Warwickâ€”I made a demand on her for 2l. 3s. beyond 13s. 10d.â€”she communicated to me that she had paid the 2l. 3s.â€”she paid me the 13s. 10d. and I gave her this receiptâ€”I communicated to Josslyn on the order sheet that she had paid that 13s. 10d.â€”I transmitted it to himâ€”I saw him after thatâ€”this letter was written by me on November 8th, on the journey after October 3dâ€”I had seen Josslyn between those dates, and settled with him for the journeyâ€”a list of names were put down, and among them was that amount 13s. 10d.â€”the list has been searched for, and cannot be foundâ€”it was sent up in the ordinary way, stating that such a sum had been paidâ€”I settled the account 13s. 10d. with Josslyn, with perhaps thirty or forty other amountsâ€”the cash that I received was forwarded every day or every other dayâ€”I forwarded the 13s. 10d. the next dayâ€”I recollect calling on Miss Pfeil in January, this year, and in April alsoâ€”I called on her on March 16th, and received the balance of her account, 4l. allowing 2s. discountâ€”she said she had sent 5l. upâ€”I cannot say whether I communicated that to Josslynâ€”I don't recollectâ€”it would be my duty to do soâ€”I should do so, in the ordinary courseâ€”it would be a great dereliction of duty if I had not done so.

Cross-examined. Q. Have you been charged with any mistake or defalca
tion of any kind? A. No; not making any mistakes in any way, nor for being short in my accountâ€”Mr. Walker has never charged me with any
thingâ€”he said there was a balance due to him; but it was not any short
ness of an account, and he investigated itâ€”he found it was an errorâ€”he investigated that just in the same way as the other accounts had been inves
tigatedâ€”he investigated all of themâ€”he wrote me several letters about it, and then I went to see him, and explained it to his satisfactionâ€”I was some little time before I was able to do thatâ€”I was called on to give him some promissory notesâ€”I was called on for those a year before, and it was on those grounds that Mr. Walker asked me, during this affair, for a settle
ment of the accountsâ€”I did not owe them, the account was not correct; that was a year and a half agoâ€”in the early part of this investigation all

the accounts were gone intoâ€”my accounts were gone into about a fort
night or three weeks after Mr. Josslyn was dischargedâ€”I went to the warehouse, and then it was found that the balance was not against me.

MR. ROBINSON. Q. When Mr. Walker mentioned to you that he had got an account against you, did he say whether it was from his own knowledge or from information he had got from Josslyn? A. From information he had gotâ€”it was added up in Josslyn's handwritingâ€”I satisfied Mr. Walker that my accounts were correct.

COURT to MR. WALKER. Q. Had Mr. Hitchman anything to do with the books? A. Nothing whatever; he kept no entries in them, and had no access to them in the discharge of his dutiesâ€”he had nothing to do with them.

EMMA PFEIL . I carry on business at Lincoln, and have a fancy repository thereâ€”in December, 1860, I owed Mr. Walker 9l. 2s.â€”I sent up a 5l. note in December, 1860, and received this receipt from Mr. Josslynâ€”in March I paid 4l. to Mr. Webbâ€”a larger demand than that was not made on meâ€”the account was 4l. 2s.â€”there was no statement made to me about any previous statement in Decemberâ€”we had previously received false state
ments about money that had been paidâ€”I did not pay 5l. in March or April, but I paid 4l. in March of the balance of my account.

Cross-examined. Q. Did you send up 5l.? A. Yes; it was a Liucoln note as near as I can remember; I would not be positiveâ€”I did not tell Mr. Walker that it was a Lincoln note when he spoke to meâ€”he did not ask me such a questionâ€”he did not ask me to inquire where I had got it, so as to be able to trace itâ€”I could not have traced from whom I got it if I had been directed to do soâ€”my impression is that it was a Lincoln noteâ€”we have very few Bank of England notes.
MR. ROBINSON. Q. How many banks have you at Lincoln. A. There are two.

THOMAS EMMENS . I live at Abingdon, and keep & fancy repository thereâ€”I sent up to Mr. Walker a 5l. note in two halvesâ€”I got a receipt for itâ€”I sent one half up about 9th April, and the other about 15thâ€”these are the receipts that I got back.

Cross-examined. Q. Was not the second half as early as the 13th? A. cannot say; I think it was very probably the 14thâ€”I am confident I did not send it on the 12thâ€”I do not think I sent it as early as the 13thâ€”I cannot be quite certainâ€”I did not send the second half as early as the 13 thâ€”I am under the impression that I sent the remaining half on the Sunday evening; Sunday or Mondayâ€”it was a Bank of England noteâ€”I have not got the numberâ€”I could not get the numberâ€”I received a letter from Mr. Walker about the note, but was not able to trace it in any way.
COURT. Q. How long after you sent the second half did you receive the acknowledgement? A. I think it was two daysâ€”I received it on the 17th.
MR. WALKER (re-examined). There is no entry in the cash received of 5l. as received from Mr. Emmensâ€”there is a 5l. entered to Miss Pfeil on the 16thâ€”no 5l. has been entered to her in December.
MR. CHAMBERS. Q. Have you got the bankers receipt note of that date, so as to show what was paid in? A. It is in courtâ€”I keep a bank-book; it is here.

JAMES OGILVIE STEWART . I am clerk to Messrs. Ashley and Teeâ€”I re
ceived on 15th October, 1860, a post-office order for 3l. 9s. from Mr. Golding, I took it to Mr. Josslyn, and got from him a signature to the receipt that is here.

p.hi: submitted that there was no case proved against the prisoner;

div1.p: that hit duties were to receive money, which he was to pay into the bankers, and in the three cam charged they had not shown that he omitted to do to; that in Mrs. Halford's case the money was in the shape of a draft, which he had paid in, and had never received a farthing upon it: it therefore was not embezzled: that in Miss Pfeil's caset he granted that the prisoner had received the 5l. on account of his matter, but that the note which might have been traced had not been traced, and therefore they had failed to prove that it was not paid in to the bankers at the time it ought to have been; that on 9th December there was a large sum of notes paid in and they ought to have shown that the note in question was not included in them: that in Golding's case, the prisoner did enter the post-office order for 3l. 9s. to the bankers' account, and therefore it was not embezzled by him; and that in all three cases, the sums were given credit for, or actually paid in to the bankers.
MR. ROBINSON, in replying to the objections, was stopped by the COMMON SKRJEANT, who was of opinion that the case must go to the Jury.

p.hi: The prisoner received a good character.

div1.p: NOT GUILTY .

p.hi: There were other indictments against the prisoner which were postponed until the next Session.

div0.p: PRESENTâ€”Mr. RECORDER and Mr. Ald. PHILLIPS.

div1.p:
48.
EDMUND FIELD (37)
, Unlawfully uttering counterfeit coin.
MESSRS. CRAWFORD and POLAND conducted the Prosecution.

JOHN BRISTOW . I am barman at the Bell and Anchor public-house, Holbornâ€”on 8th November, the prisoner came there between 10 and 11â€”I served him with half a quartern of rum, and half a pint of beer, which came to fourpenceâ€”he gave me in payment a bad florin, and I gave him in change 1s. 6d. and twopenceâ€”I put the florin in the tillâ€”there was no other florin thereâ€”the prisoner then asked me for some gin, and I put some in a bottle for himâ€”it came to five penceâ€”he put down another florinâ€”I looked at it; it was badâ€”I said, "This is a bad one; this won't do"â€”he said, "Give it to me back againâ€”I said, "I never return bad moneyâ€”I then went to the till, and found the other florin thereâ€”I sent for a constable and gave the prisoner into custody, and gave the two florins to the constableâ€”the one in the till was badâ€”there was a woman with the prisoner; his wile, I believe.

Prisoner. Q. Did not I come in alone first of all? A. I don't know; I do not know whether the woman came in with you; she was with youâ€”I looked at the first florin at the time I took it, but did not notice whether it was good orbed.

WILLIAM ELDRIDGR (Policeman, E 85). I took the prisoner on 8th November, at the Bell and Anchorâ€”he was given in charge by the last witnessâ€”I received these two florins from him (produced)â€”I searched the prisoner, and found a third bad florin in his right handâ€”this is it (produced)â€”the prisoner struggled with me, and he swallowed something; I did not see what it was; it made his mouth bleedâ€”I also found twopence in copper on himâ€”I did not find a shilling, or a sixpenceâ€”his wife was there at the time.
WILLIAM WEBSTER . I am inspector of coin to the Mintâ€”these are all counterfeit florins, and from one mould.

Prisoner's Defence. I leave it for you to judge, when I went into the house, what I wanted to change a second 2s. piece for, when I had the change in my pocket. I had been making too free with drink; I was out some
time before I went in the second time. I was coming home and I met my wife, and all I had I gave to her previously to going in. We went and had something to drink, and the only money I had on me was the twopence which the officer found. The one that the policeman took from my right hand was the one I gave to the barman, and he gave me back. The policeman knows I have a good character.
WILLIAM ELDRIDGE (re-examined). I have known the prisoner nine or ten yearsâ€”I have never heard anything against himâ€”he keeps a sort of general shop, a butcher's shop.
MR. CRAWFORD. Q. Have you not heard that he has been charged since this offence? A. No, not to a certainty.
Prisoner. I say, standing here as a living man, that I did not pass one counterfeit coin, let alone three.

GUILTY .â€”Recommended to mercy by the Jury on account of his previous good character.
Confined Nine Months.

49.
JAMES GOULD (22), was indicted
for a like offence.
MESSRS CRAWFORD and POLAND conducted the Prosecution.

HENRY PETT . I am eleven years old and live at 56, Weston-street, Pimlicoâ€”I remember on a Tuesday in this month being near Mr. Bates' shop at a quarter to 1â€”he is a greengrocerâ€”while I was there the prisoner came up and asked me to go and get A pennyworth of carrots from Mr. Bates', and he would give me a pennyâ€”he said that he had had a row with Mr. Bates the other night and he did not like to go himselfâ€”I said that I would goâ€”he gave me a bad shillingâ€”I did not know it was badâ€”I took it to Mr. Bates' shop and gave it to himâ€”he spoke to me about it and gave me the carrotsâ€”I went out with the carrots to find the prisoner, and Mr. Bates went out some yards behind meâ€”when I got out I saw the prisoner some distance from the shop; I pointed him out to Mr. Batesâ€”the prisoner was talking to a lemon boy at the timeâ€”he ran away as soon as he saw Mr. Batesâ€”I left the shilling with Mr. Bates.
Prisoner. Q. Did I say to you that I bad had a row with Mr. Bates? A. Yes; I am quite sure about that.

WILLIAM BATES . I am a greengrocer in Effingham-street, Pimlicoâ€”I remember the lad coming to me on Tuesday, 12th November, about 1 o'clockâ€”he came to purchase a pennyworth of carrotsâ€”I served him and he handed me a counterfeit shillingâ€”I gave him the carrots and told him to take them on, and I would come after himâ€”I said before that, "Who are they for, Harry?" and he said, "A costermongerâ€”I said, "Who is it?"â€”he said, "I have seen him, Mr. Bates, but I do not know him"â€”I then told him to take the carrots and point me out the manâ€”I followed him about fifteen or twenty yardsâ€”the prisoner was about twenty-five yards from my shopâ€”as soon as he saw me, he took to his heels and ran.

COURT. Q. What did the boy do to point him out? A. With his finger in that mannerâ€”he did not speakâ€”I told him not to speakâ€”I had not said a word before the prisoner ran awayâ€”I have never had any quarrel with himâ€”I believe I have seen him beforeâ€”I ran after him about a quarter of a mileâ€”he went under the railway arch through a gateway there, over the railway fence, over the line and the next fence, and into the water-works groundâ€”he pulled up there, and I caught himâ€”he put his hands together

and laid, "So help me Gâ€”I am innocentâ€”I believe those were the wordsâ€”I was out of breath with running; I did not speak to himâ€”a constable was on the other side of the fence, and I gave the prisoner aud the shilling into his charge.

WILLIAM WALDRON (Policeman, B 239). The prisoner was given into my custody by the last witnessâ€”I saw the shilling at the time, and Mr. Bates gave it to me at the station afterwardsâ€”this is it (produced)â€”I searched the prisoner and found a half crown, a sixpence, and a fourpenny bit, all good money, on him.
WILLIAM WEBSTER . This is a bad shilling.

The prisoner's statement before the Magistrate was here read at follow: "I was out with herrings on Monday and I took this shilling, and laid of seven and got eight. I had only earned this bad shilling. I met this young fellow and asked him to go and get the carrots for supper. I did not tell him I had quarrelled with Mr. Bates.
Prisoner's Defence. I am innocent of it.
GUILTY .

p.hi: The witness Pett stated that he saw the prisoner, just before, give a shilling to another boy to get some apples at Mr. Bates'.

stated that this shilling was bad, from the same mould as the other.â€”
Confined Six Months.

div1.p:
50.
LYDIA ATKINS (28)
, Forging an order for the payment of 15l., with latent to defraud.

GEORGE VIRTUE . I live at Oakland's-park, Walton-on-Thamesâ€”the prisoner was in my service as cookâ€”she had been about three months with usâ€”this cheque (produced) purports to be drawn by me on the London Joint Stock Bankâ€”it is not in my writing, or written by my authorityâ€”I knew nothing of it till the officer came down with itâ€”the prisoner was left in the house on Sundays when we went to churchâ€”she was the only servant who remained in the houseâ€”I kept my cheque book in a small breakfast room, in a desk, but not lockedâ€”she had access to that room among other roomsâ€”the door was left unlockedâ€”she had no business thereâ€”I never saw her write till the officer asked her to write my name, when he came down to take her into custody.

Cross-examined by MR. ORRIDGE, Q. Would anyone coming into the house have access to that breakfast room? A. Yesâ€”I have understood since that a man named Manning used to come down to see herâ€”I heard him say so at the Mansion-houseâ€”I never saw him before thenâ€”I had a good character with the prisonerâ€”her sister is in ray employment now, as housemaidâ€”her father and mother live close to usâ€”the sister had been with us a year or two before the prisoner came.

FANNY BETTY . I live at 18, Craven-terrace, Bayswater, in the same house with Mrs. Elizabeth Boweâ€”on 29th October, I took a letter from the postman for Mrs. Boweâ€”I gave it to my motherâ€”I did not see it given to Mrs. Boweâ€”I know the prisonerâ€”I have seen her at that houseâ€”she was in the habit of sending letters to the house to Mr. Manningâ€”he is Mrs. Bowe's brotherâ€”I know the prisoner's writing by taking lettersâ€”I often took in the letters for Mrs. Bowe and Mr. Manning, and I knew her writingâ€”I have never seen her writeâ€”I have not spoken to her about lettersâ€”she has not said whether the letters were written by her or not.
ELIZABETH BETTY . I live at 18, Craven-terraceâ€”on 29th October, I received a letter from my daughterâ€”I took it up stairs and gave it to Mrs.
Boweâ€”I did not see what she did with itâ€”I came down againâ€”I know the prisonerâ€”I do not know her writing exactlyâ€”I have never seen her write.

ELIZABETH BOWS . I am the wife of Albert Bowe, of 18, Craven-terrace, Bayswater, and sister of Richard Manning on 29th October Ireceived a letter from Mrs. Bettyâ€”after looking at it I gave it to my brotherâ€”I broke the envelope, and the letter and the envelope were burnt in my presenceâ€”there was a cheque in that letterâ€”this is itâ€”the address on the letter was "Mrs. Bowe, 18, Craven-terrace, Craven-hill, Bayswater," and inside there was another envelope with "R. Manning" upon itâ€”I saw part of the letterâ€”I remember part of itâ€”I have known the prisoner for three yearsâ€”I know her writingâ€”I have seen her write twice or three times, I cannot sayâ€”I have been in the habit of receiving letters from herâ€”the writing on the envelope and letter was her'sâ€”I believe the writing on this cheque to be the sameâ€”my brother went up to the police-court to be examinedâ€”he was there taken with a fit and obliged to be carried out, and has been very ill ever since.

Cross-examined. Q. Where is your brother! A. At Salkham, near Kingsbridge, Devonâ€”he went there last Tuesday weekâ€”I have not seen him since thenâ€”I saw the letter burnt by my brotherâ€”we did not look at the writing at the timeâ€”we did not know that he had anybody like this to deal withâ€”I saw the prisoner write an address when she lived at Colonel Rowcroft's, and she wrote an address for me when she was leaving her situation to go into the countryâ€”I remember her going to Mr. Virtue'sâ€”my brother was in the habit of showing me his letters from herâ€”I saw the letter in which she had written Mr. Virtue's name and addressâ€”my brother is a butcherâ€”he has not been in any employment for five monthsâ€”he has not been wellâ€”he was too ill to workâ€”he did not go down very often to see the prisonerâ€”I know that he was there on the Sundayâ€”he did not always go on Sundaysâ€”I never heard him propose driving a cab.

MR. METCALFE. Q. Your brother was first taken into custody on the charge? A. Yes, and then the charge was withdrawn, and he was taken up to the Police-court as a witnessâ€”I saw my brother take the cheque out of the letter, and the week before that there was a letter, saying she had for
warded the money, and there was no money forwarded.
GEORGE VIRTUE . (Re-examined). This is my cheque-book (produced)â€”the number of this check is 88,986â€”I find that number missing from the cheque-book; it is taken away with the counterfoil.
MR. ORRIDGE. Q. That is from the middle of the book, not taken from a consecutive number? A. Yes; the date of the last cheque that I drew was 16th October.

HATTAM WINDLE . I am cashier at the London Joint Stock Bankâ€”Mr. Virtue keeps an account thereâ€”on 29th October, about 11 o'clock in the morning, this cheque was presented to me by a person of the name of Richard Manningâ€”I at once saw it was not Mr. Virtue's signature, re
fused it, and the person who presented it was given into custody at that time.
Cross-examined. Q. You knew Mr. Virtue's signature? A. Yes; I at once saw it was not his.

GEORGE SCOTT . I am a detective officer in the Cityâ€”on 29th October, I was sent for to the London Joint Stock Bankâ€”I found Manning there, and he was given into my custody on a charge of uttering a forged chequeâ€”in consequence of the explanation that he gave, I went down to Walton, and saw the prisoner thereâ€”I asked her if she knew Manningâ€”she said,

"Yes"â€”I then asked her if she owed him any moneyâ€”she said, "Yes, she had paid him some sometime ago"â€”I asked her if she had paid him any by chequeâ€”she said, "No"â€”I said, "Did you send a letter to him last night containing a cheque?"â€”she said, "No"â€”I then produced the cheque in question, and asked her if she bad ever seen that cheque beforeâ€”she said, "No"â€”I asked whether she wrote it, and she said, "No"â€”I had previously told her that I was an officer, and was making inquiries with reference to the cheque; there was a pen and ink on the table and I asked her to write the name of her master, putting a piece of paper before herâ€”she began to write "Mr. Virtue," and I said, "No, George Virtue," and she wrote George Virtueâ€”I then looked at the two, and in consequence of what I saw, I took her into custody.

Cross-examined. Q. You have told us that she said she had not sent him a cheque, did not she also say she had sent him a letter about a week ago? A. She did, and that it contained no chequeâ€”I asked her whether she sent him a letter last night containing a cheque, and she said, "I sent him a letter about a week ago, but not containing a cheque; I never sent a letter with a cheque"â€”I have seen Manning since his examination; he is out of his mindâ€”there is no medical man here to speak to his state, that I know of.
NOT GUILTY .

51.
JOHN EVANS (20), and
WILLIAM PICKARD (29)
, Stealing, on 4th October, 1 bag, 1 pair of spectacles, 1 thimble, and 7l. 10s. in money, the property of
Thomas Fossey, from the person of
Naomi Fossey.

NAOMI FOSSEY . I am the wife of Thomas Fossey, an artist, and reside at 26, Hackney-roadâ€”about a quarter-past 5 on 4th October, I was passing along Crabtree-row, which leads into the Hackney-roadâ€”I had a leather bag, twisted round my arm, tight; it contained' a 51. Bank of England note, two sovereigns, and 10s. in silver, a pair of spectacles, a thimble, a piece of em
broidery, and two linen handkerchiefsâ€”a lad came upâ€”I do not know which way he cameâ€”he ran at me, put his hand under my mantle, and got the bog, after a severe struggleâ€”he pulled me down, and I was severely bruisedâ€”I have no doubt that Evans is the young man; he answers in size and otherwise; he looked like himâ€”I called out "Stop thief!" and ran down the courtâ€”I turned back againâ€”I was afraid of going after him farâ€”I did not see the other prisoner.

Cross-examined by MR. COLLINS (for Evans). Q. You were very much frightened, I suppose. A. Yes, very much agitatedâ€”Evans was very much like the manâ€”I did not see him again till I saw him at Worship-streetâ€”I there saw him in the dock, and I then said it was himâ€”I did not know it was our caseâ€”I have no doubt it is him.

GEORGE HENDERSLY . I live with my father, a costermonger, at 16, Crab
tree-rowâ€”on Friday afternoon, 4th October, about 5 o'clock, I was outside my father's doorâ€”I saw a lady coming along, and the two prisoners standing togetherâ€”Evans took a bog she had, and ran down the court with itâ€”the lady struggled very much, and he pulled her on the groundâ€”she went a little way down the court and then turned back; the other prisoner stopped behind and then went down the next courtâ€”he was not above half a yard from Evans when Evans took the bag; he then stopped behind a little while and then went down the next court, which lead to Pickardâ€”I had seen them together before this at the corner of the turningâ€”I know them quite well.
Cross-examined by MR. COLLINS. Q. You had had a quarrel with

had you not A. Noâ€”I did not throw rats at him, and he at me; my father charged some one with throwing rats down his chimney; not Evansâ€”I don't know who it wasâ€”I think Evans was taken in custody about the 29thâ€”I saw him once before that, on the Sunday; not more than onceâ€”I did not know where he livedâ€”I saw him about five or six days after the robbery, in the same place; on the ruins.
Cross-examined by MR. METCALFE (for Pickard). Q. A great many boys play there, do they not! A. Yesâ€”this was about 2 o'clock in the afternoon.

RICHARD KENWOOD (Policeman, H 194). On the morning of 29th, I and Double took the prisoners into custody at 10, Collingwood-streetâ€”they were together, in one roomâ€”I took Evans, and told him he was charged with stealing a bag on the 4th, from a lady in Crabtree-rowâ€”he said "You have got me to rights this time; but I thought it was all forgotten before now"â€”I then took him to the station, and he was identified by the boyâ€”I afterwards went back to the house and found five handkerchiefs, two with the names cut outâ€”I did not find anything belonging to Mrs. Fossey.

p.hi: considered that there was no case against Pickard.

div1.p:
PICKARDâ€”
NOT GUILTY .

EVANSâ€”
GUILTY .*â€”
Four Years' Penal Servitude.

52.
WILLIAM PICKARD
was again indicted for stealing a watch and chain, value 60l., the property of
Robert Bruce Durham, from ha person.

ROBERT BRUCE DURHAM . I am a shipowner, and reside at Stock-lodge, Ingleston, Essexâ€”on 17th October, I was walking along Bishopsgate-street, about ten minutes past 6; and passing by Catherine Wheel-alley a man passed out, brushing me as he passedâ€”I turned to avoid him, and the prisoner came on this side, rendered this arm powerless, took my watch and chain out of my pocket, and rushed up the alleyâ€”I am quite sure he was the manâ€”I pursued him three or four steps, and then saw two women standing in the courtâ€”they stopped me and said, "Have you lost anything, Sir?"â€”the prisoner then seemed to have gained on me, and I went back and got a policemanâ€”I paid 35l. for the watch, and the chain, which was a present, was 25l.â€”I have never seen them since.

Cross-examined by MR. METCALFE. Q. Where did you next see the prisoner? A. At the Bishopsgate-street police-station, amongst ten or twelve others; there were two or three officers thereâ€”a letter was written to me by the inspector, to come up to London, and I did soâ€”the police officers took me into the yard, and the prisoners passed in procession before me, and they asked me to point out the man who robbed meâ€”there were some of his age and appearanceâ€”no signal was made to me; I am quite sure of that.

GUILTY .**â€”
Four Years' Penal Servitude.

div0.p: PRESENTâ€”Mr. BARON BRAMWELL; Mr. Ald. CARTER; Mr. Ald. ABBISS; Mr. Ald. DAKIN; and Mr. COMMON SERGEANT.

div1.p:
53.
GEORGE WELLS (23)
, Feloniously setting fire to a stack of hay, the property of
James Marshall; to which he

PLEADED GUILTY .**â€”
Six Years' Penal Servitude.

54.
JOHN GRIFFITHS (35),
B----gâ€”y.
MESSRS. CLERK and BEASLEY conducted the Prosecution and MR. RIBTON the Defence.

55.
ADOLPHUS MANTON (32)
, Feloniously stabbing
Henry Burke Berryman upon the high seas, with intent to murder him. Second Count with intent to do him some grievous bodily harm.

HENRY BURKE BERRYMAN . I am the brother of Edwin Berryman, the captain of the brig Miloâ€”she is now in the West India docksâ€”on 28th of May she was at seaâ€”I do not know whereabouts; I did not navigate herâ€”we were going from Liverpool towards Cubaâ€”the prisoner was on board the vessel as an able seamanâ€”there was also a sailor on board of the name of Pratt; he was also a man of colourâ€”on 28th May the master was endea
vouring to put Pratt into irons for not doing as he was told, or something of that kindâ€”he was violent, and resistedâ€”while that was being done, the prisoner cam down from aloft, and called out to Pratt, "Don't give in to the b----"â€”he called that out several times; besides that he used other ex
pressions; I do not recollect what they were; they were inciting Pratt to resistâ€”Pratt was ultimately put into ironsâ€”four persons were engaged in doing that, the chief mate, the second mate, the steward and Iâ€”the captain was at that time in the cabinâ€”after Pratt was put in irons I came on deckâ€”the prisoner was standing at the poopâ€”the captain told him to go forward; to go down on the deckâ€”he gave the captain some insolence at the time, but he went down after a time into the forecastleâ€”the captain told him to go to his workâ€”he was blacking the mainsheets, I believeâ€”he did not do itâ€”he went into the forecastleâ€”the captain asked him several times to come out and he refused to do itâ€”he said, "Come in and take me, you b----; come in and take me"â€”he said he would not come outâ€”after he had been asked for some time, I and the second and chief mates went into the forecastleâ€”the chief mate then asked him to come out againâ€”he had been there about a quarter of an hour at that timeâ€”during that time the captain was endeavour
ing to get him out to his workâ€”when the chief mate asked him again, he said he would not come out, and refused the same as he did beforeâ€”the mate then attempted to take hold of him, and he went to resist, and we all laid hands on him, and he drew his knife in the struggleâ€”he took it from his backâ€”he had it concealed behind him, in some place or otherâ€”he had not a sheath onâ€”it was a knife that goes into a sheathâ€”I should think the blade was six inches longâ€”this is it (produced)â€”he stabbed me with it in the rumpâ€”it was done violentlyâ€”I think it went in about an inch and three
quarters, the doctors sayâ€”the blood flowed very muchâ€”he said about the time he struck me that he would have the life of one of usâ€”I do not recol
lect exactly when that was; it was before he struck the blow; before we went into the forecastleâ€”he could not be takenâ€”we went out of the forecastle, and the captain ordered him to be battened into the forecastleâ€”we could not take him withoutâ€”he fired bottles several times; not while I was in the forecastleâ€”I saw some bottles thrown out of the door and windowâ€”that was

after to had gone outâ€”I think they were thrown at the captain principallyâ€”they were large glass bottles, and a stone bottle also; some of them were smashedâ€”one struck the captain on the nose, and cut it considerably.

Cross-examined by MR. RIBTON. Q. Was Pratt, who was put in irons, a black man? A. Yes; and there were two other black men on boardâ€”the crew consisted of eight, four white boys and four black men; I do not include the captainâ€”I include myself amongst the boysâ€”toe prisoner had been up aloft that day blacking the sheetsâ€”he spilt some of itâ€”I do not think it was by accident; I think he did it purposelyâ€”he said he could not do it, and the captain went aloft and did a little of it for him to show him that it could be doneâ€”I can't say that there had been a good deal of unpleasantness between him and the captain fur some daysâ€”he was always giving insolence, and I think the captain punished him at one timeâ€”he put him in ironsâ€”it was on 13th April that he punished him the first timeâ€”I can't say how long he was in irons thenâ€”it was for giving insolenceâ€”I was not on deck at the time, and do not know what it was forâ€”I do not think he was punished between 13th April and the 28th May; not to my knowledgeâ€”on the 28th May he was struck by me in the scuffle, when I was stabbedâ€”I struck him with an arrangement I had made, and which I kept in the cabin as a defence; I was always afraid that something would occur; he was always a very disagreeable man; I had four revolver bullets, and I put some paper round them, and put a lanyard on them; and always had it in the cabin where it could be got in a moment if the fellow should attempt my lifeâ€”I think I struck him with it that day; I could not swear to itâ€”I could not swear that I struck him with it before I received my wound, and I could not swear that I did notâ€”I have not said that I struck him with that instrumentâ€”I struck him with my hand in the scuffleâ€”I had this weapon with me when I went into the forecastleâ€”I do not know whether or not I only struck him with my hand, I intended to if it was necessaryâ€”I did not see any one else strike himâ€”he was fired atâ€”the mate fired at him with a pistol charged with peasâ€”that was not before the scuffleâ€”he was not fired at before I received the wound, not to my knowledgeâ€”three of us went into the forecastle after him, the mate, the second mate, and myselfâ€”we were all armed; the mate had a pistol loaded with peas, the second mate had a wooden heaver, and I had the instrument I have describedâ€”he was not struck by any of us before I felt the wound; I swear that positivelyâ€”I am not sure whether I struck him with the slung shot or not; but I did not strike him with it before I received the wound, nor did I see the others strike himâ€”no shots "were found in the pri
soner afterwardsâ€”he was fired at with peasâ€”he was not hitâ€”the doctor examined him at Cuba, and there was no mark whateverâ€”when we went into the forecastle I think the mate said to him, "I want you to go in irons"â€”the prisoner did not reply, "Mr. Mackie, you had better mind what you Are about"â€”I don't know what he said; he very likely said somethingâ€”I did not see the mate take him by the collar; I was close to himâ€”I think the mate put his hand upon his collarâ€”I did not then go up and strike him on the head with the slung shotâ€”he was not knocked down in the scuffle before I was wounded; I swear thatâ€”I did not see the boatswain strike him with the heaver, and I do rot believe that he didâ€”we attempted to drag him out of the forecastleâ€”I caught hold of him to attempt to drag him outâ€”we were not all three dragging him outâ€”I caught hold of him to Attempt to do so; that was before I was woundedâ€”the others were going to lay hold of him when I was stabbed, but they did notâ€”it was after I was wounded that the captain fired at himâ€”he did not fire at him; he fired into the forecastle

while the prisoner was thereâ€”we left him in the forecastleâ€”I can't say how often be tired into the forecastle, two or three times; twice I think it wasâ€”he did not fire at him, because he had no chance, he was in a cornerâ€”he did not intend to hit him, it was merely to intimidate him, that was allâ€”I did not see him holding up his pea-jacket to save himself from the shotâ€”it was not after the shots had been fired at him that he flung the bottles out; it was before, and after alsoâ€”I did not see the mate point his pistol through the stove-holeâ€”the boatswain is second mateâ€”I did not hear the captain order him to bore a bole on each side of the forecastle, large enough for a ball to go through; nothing of the sortâ€”we kept him somewhere about two days and two nights in the forecastle.
COURT. Q. How did he get out at last? A. He was taken out by the police at Cuba.

MR. RIBTON. Q. Did you ever hear angry altercations between him and the captain before I A. No; I cannot say that I didâ€”I never heard the captain say that the mate should take a hand-spike and lay him stiff on the spotâ€”the captain never allowed the mate to strike himâ€”I never heard him say anything like, "Mind what you are about or I will sacrifice you before you get to Cuba"â€”I did not hear the prisoner say to the captain that he was born under the British flag, and ruled by the laws of the country; nor the captain reply, "D----the flag, I know what flag you shall belong to"â€”I did not hear him say, "You shall not have a farthing when you are paid off; for the last fifteen years I have been complaining of the likes of you, and this is the way I serve themâ€”I heard nothing of the sortâ€”my wound is still a little sore at times, with very much walking or anythingâ€”I never heard the captain call the prisoner a black son of a b----hâ€”this knife was used by the prisoner for work about deckâ€”he carried it about with him.

MR. METCALFE. Q. You say the captain shot two or three times, could he have hit him where he was? A. No; it was utterly impossible; there is a torn in the forecastle, and he was behind it in a corner; the only object was to intimidate himâ€”we did not succeed in getting him out; he was very violentâ€”he is a very powerful manâ€”we kept him battened up until we got to Cuba; daring that time his food was put through a hole in the forecastleâ€”he was left there until the authorities at Cuba took him outâ€”before be stabbed me no violence was used towards him except what was necessary to control him.

COURT, Q. Did yo bring him back to England? A.
