Yesâ€”when he had got into the forecastle we told him to come out and he would not come; then three of us went in, and it was when I caught hold of him that I was stabbedâ€”I fell over a chest that was in the forecastleâ€”I had my arm on his shoulder or neckâ€”he tripped with me, and then he struck me with the knifeâ€”I can't say which hand he had it in; I think it was the right handâ€”I did not put my hand on him very gently; not as I would to a friendâ€”I merely took hold of himâ€”I meant to pull him out to put the irons on himâ€”he stabbed me, and that disabled meâ€”the others he kept at bay with the knife and the bottlesâ€”I came out myself, and. the others came out too.

EDWIN WILLIAM BERRYMAN . I am master of the ship Miloâ€”on 28th May, we were at sea about sixty or seventy miles from Cubaâ€”some of the officers were engaged in endeavouring to put a man named Pratt, in ironsâ€”Pratt had laid up without any cause, with a small pimple on his finger; and he would not keep a look-outâ€”we were getting close to the land, and were short-banded, having only four able seamen on board, with two boysâ€”he was

violent; he would not go in irons, and aid the whole ship could not put him in ironsâ€”he was a black manâ€”the prisoner was on the mainyard at the time, blacking the topsail sheetsâ€”he had left about two or three feet undoneâ€”the mate told him to go on with it, he said he would not and he could notâ€”I then told him I would not ask him to do anything I could not do myself and I went up to the mainyard outside of him, took the brash and blacked the chain; I then came down, and told him to go on with his work, which he did, swearing, and he upset a bucket of tar upon a new mainsailâ€”directly after this I sent the mate forward to bring Pratt to me, that I might look at his fingerâ€”while Pratt was being put in irons the prisoner came down off the mainyard, saying, "Don't go in irons, Jack; don't go in irons for the b----"â€”I was on the poop at that timeâ€”he used strong language besides thisâ€”I ordered him to go to his workâ€”he used all kinds of expressionsâ€”"Go to h----and be d----d," and instead of going to his work he went into the forecastleâ€”I waited until the others came up from below, from putting Pratt in irons, and we then went forward to the forecastleâ€”I told the prisoner to come out and go to his work; he said he would not, and told us to come and take him out; and the first man that came in he would have his lifeâ€”he kept singing out, "Come and take me you b----, come and take meâ€”I talked to him and told him to go to his work, and I called the crew and told them that man would not go to his work, and that he was armed with a knife, which the second mate called outâ€”I told him the consequences if he did not go to his work, and told him the mate was going to arrest him with the second mate and my brother, and if he used a knife I would shoot him. at that momentâ€”I went to the forward window of the forecastle with my revolver, which was loaded with shotâ€”they went into the forecastle, and the first I heard was some one singing out, "I am stabbed"â€”they ran out of the forecastle door, I came aft and saw that my brother was stabbed in the right hipâ€”I then went forward to the window to try and see where the prisoner was, and he threw a large quart glass bottle at me, full of palm oilâ€”it struck me on the nose and face, and cut me very badlyâ€”he threw numerous bottles after that, whenever we went past the passageâ€”I then fired two or three times through the windowâ€”I could not hit him from where I wasâ€”I did not try to do soâ€”I did it to try and frighten himâ€”I could not have hit him if I had tried to do soâ€”I did not hit himâ€”finding I could not get him out, I had to batten him up in the forecastle till we got to Cuba; and I had to put a small foolish boy that I had on board, in the passage while it was doneâ€”if the carpenter had tried to batten him up without that, he would have thrown bottles at him, but I knew he would not throw at the foolish boy, so I stood him in the passage, and then battened up the forecastleâ€”when we got to Cuba he was taken out by the authoritiesâ€”I saw my brother's hipâ€”there was a wound nearly four, inches long, and I think the doctor said an inch and three-quarters deepâ€”the doctor is not hereâ€”he was examined in Cubaâ€”it was a very bad wound; it bled very considerably.

Cross-examined. Q. Do you mean to swear that the prisoner was not struck with the shot? A. I did not see him struckâ€”I did not afterwards see some shot lodged in any part of his bodyâ€”I swear thatâ€”I did not find any of them in his pea jacketâ€”they were not pointed out to me by anybodyâ€”Pratt was put in irons about 9 o'clock that morningâ€”I think there was a cry of "murder" from himâ€”that was before the prisoner came downâ€”he come down immediately after Pratt was crying; but I do not think anybody could hear what he was cryingâ€”he was kept in irons about five

days, until we got to Cubaâ€”I did not keep him in irons while we were at Cubaâ€”he was taken on shore by the policeâ€”we did not get to Cuba two days after this occurrenceâ€”I think it was four or five days, but I will not be confidentâ€”when I came out of my cabin after breakfast, the prisoner was up aloftâ€”I do not recollect saying to him that he was too comfortable thereâ€”I desired him to come down on the foot ropesâ€”I won't swear that I did not say he was too comfortable there; very likely I did say soâ€”he told me there was no hold on the foot ropesâ€”very likely I said, "Then I must have you sit that way,"I do not recollect itâ€”that was before he came downâ€”I then went up myself and did what he was doingâ€”it was after that that some of the blacking was spilt on the sailâ€”I told him I would make him pay for it; then came the cry of "Murder!" from Pratt, and then the prisoner came downâ€”I did not see anybody strike Prattâ€”I do not know whether the boatswain struck himâ€”I did not see himâ€”I came up with my revolver while Pratt was in irons and while the prisoner was on the deckâ€”I desired him to go forward or else I would shoot himâ€”I told him to go to his work, and if he came one step further I would shoot himâ€”he did not say it was a shame for a man with a bad finger to be put in ironsâ€”he did not go forward until after Pratt was put in ironsâ€”when I said I would shoot him, he told me to shoot and be dâ€”d, he did not care a dâ€”he did go forward after thatâ€”I did not say to the mate, "Lock Pratt up, and then come forward and put the other fellow in irons"â€”I might have said itâ€”I do not recoil act itâ€”he did not ask me what I wanted him to go in irons for, nor did I say, "I will answer you the other wayâ€”he did not tell me that I had put him in irons once, and ill-treated him without any causeâ€”I did not say, "I don't care; I will pot you in irons dead or alive" nothing of the sortâ€”the boatswain had not a hand-spike in his hand; he had a wooden heaverâ€”I did not tell him to knock the prisoner down with itâ€”I swear that.
COURT. Q. Is the ship an English ship? A. Yes; with British owners.

MR. RIBTON. Q. Did you call the prisoner more than once, a black son of a b----? A. No; no language of the sortâ€”I swear thatâ€”he did not say, "Captain, do you think it is the right way which you are treating me, on board your ship"â€”I desired the three men to go into the forecastle to arrest the prisonerâ€”I did not say, "If the three of you will come in and put him in irons, I will go to the forecastle window and fire at him if he attempts to resist"â€”I did not fire at himâ€”when I went round after he had thrown a bottle at me, I fired in the forecastleâ€”I did not fire at him, because I could not shoot him where he was, from the very fact of how the forecastle is builtâ€”I tried to intimidate him; I did it for no other purposeâ€”I saw the three men go into the forecastleâ€”I did not see what took place in the forecastle, because I was forwardâ€”I went forward in order to protect them with my pistolâ€”I could not see into the forecastleâ€”I could see a part of it, but not where the prisoner wasâ€”I did not see him struck by anything and knocked downâ€”I did not see the wound inflictedâ€”I think I fired at him afterwards with ball; that was in order to frighten himâ€”I did not fire at him; I fired into the forecastleâ€”I desired the boatswain to bore a hole in the forecastle; that was to admit airâ€”it was not through that hole that I fired the ballâ€”he bored a hole about an inch and a quarter or an inch and a halfâ€”I did not desire him to bore a hole on each side of the forecastle, large enough for a ball to go throughâ€”I told him it was to admit the airâ€”I told the carpenter so; he is hereâ€”the prisoner was kept in the forecastle till we got to Cubaâ€”we remained there some three or four weeksâ€”I was in different parts of Cuba for two or three monthsâ€”he was

in prison there all that timeâ€”he did not, to my knowledge, demand to, be tried in Englandâ€”he was brought home in ironsâ€”we were fifty-one days on our voyage homeâ€”he was in irons during all that time; that was by order of the Consul, and the Naval Court, held at Cuba.

COURT. Q. What are the irons into which you put people? A. Hand
cufs; there are no irons to the feet; a man can walk with them; they are simply handcuffsâ€”the prisoner was hand-cuffed for that fifty-one days; that was my ordersâ€”I could not go against the orders of the Naval Court at Cuba; I bad written orders.
MR. RIBTON. Q. When you were coming home did you order him to walk on deck, and had he a Bible with him? A. No; not in coming homeâ€”it was after this had happened; after we had got to Cuba.

COURT. Q. Did you cruise about with him at Cuba in irons? A. I didâ€”he was in irons not only for the fifty-one days on the voyage home, but for four months besidesâ€”he has been in irons something, over five months.

MR. RIBTON. Q. Did you order him on deck, and did he bring his Bible with him? A. No; I came on board one evening; he was always very impudent; he had a book in his handâ€”I did not know what it wasâ€”I asked him what he had in his handâ€”he said it was his; he did not say what it wasâ€”I said, "Give it to me," and I took it down belowâ€”that was on my passage from Cubâ€”it was a Bible that he had; but I did not know it was a Bible at that time.

COURT. Q. But whatever it was, what right had you to take it from him? A. He never used it; he never, looked at anything; it was just a bit of bravado on his partâ€”I had him on board for the purpose of bringing him here to be triedâ€”my orders were, to take him in irons to Englandâ€”as soon as I found what book it was, I told the steward to take it to him; which he did the next morning.

MR. RIBTON. Q. He was in irons at the time you took it from him, was he not? A. Yeaâ€”I did not say to him, "You are my prisoner, and the law of England allows me to do as I like with you"â€”I do not recollect what I said to himâ€”I did not say, "I will put you where you won't see to read your Bible"â€”I mean to swear that at the time I took it from him I did not know it was a Bible; I did not look at it at the timeâ€”it was an ordinary sized bookâ€”I did not say to him, "To-morrow I will take you ashore and put you in chains"â€”he was put in the stocks by order of the British Consul; that was not on the way homeâ€”it was at New Wales after we left Cuba; not on board, ashoreâ€”I put him ashore because the law of the mercantile navy tells me that I cannot keep a sailor on board in ironsâ€”I had nothing to do with putting him in the stocksâ€”I did not tell him I had arranged it so that when I got him to England I would transport him or hang him; nothing of the sortâ€”I have been a captain about two yearsâ€”I have been on board a vessel altogether fifteen yearsâ€”I have never been mixed up in any of these cases beforeâ€”I have never given evidence before, or had evidence given against meâ€”I swear that.

MR. METCALFE. Q. You say you returned the Bible to him the morning after you had taken it away? A. The steward took it to him by my ordersâ€”whatever took place after we got to Cuba, was by the direction of the Court thereâ€”the proceedings are lodged there; I brought a copy of them with meâ€”he was tired at Cuba, and found guilty of mutinous conductâ€”whatever was done after I got to Cuba, was done by the direction of the authorities there; by the direction of the Naval Courtâ€”I had no option in the matter.

COURT. Q. I suppose you landed the prisoner? A. I applied to the British Consul for police officers, and he was landedâ€”I made my complaint before the British Consul, and he convened a civil court, consisting of the masters of four British shipsâ€”the Spanish authorities had nothing what
ever to do with itâ€”it was determined that the prisoner should be sent back here to take his trial, and I was to bring him back; and as I was going a long coasting voyage I was to take him along with me to the different ports I touched at, and then back to England in ironsâ€”my vessel was the only vessel that was going to England for two or three months, not from Havannah, but from St. Jago de Cubaâ€”mine was the first vessel that was expected to get to Englandâ€”Havannah is directly across the islandâ€”I don't suppose it would be above a hundred miles.

PATRICK SLACK . I am boatswain and carpenter on board the Miloâ€”I remember the 28th May, when Pratt was put in ironsâ€”while it was being done the prisoner came down from aloftâ€”he said, "Don't give in to the b----s, Jack, don't give in to themâ€”after Pratt was put in irons, the captain told the prisoner to turn to his workâ€”the prisoner said he would do no more, he would be d----d if he would; and he went into the forecastleâ€”I heard the chief mate, and likewise the captain, ask him civilly to come out and turn to his workâ€”he said he would do no moreâ€”I suppose they were talking to him about a quarter of an hourâ€”he said, "I will do no more; come in and take me, and I will have the life of some of youâ€”after this I saw the mate and young Berryman go in; I went in with themâ€”I had a wooden heaver in my hand, which the mate gave meâ€”when we went in, the mate put his hand on the prisoner's' shoulder, and said, "Will you turn tot?"â€”the prisoner put himself in a fighting attitudeâ€”young Berry
man sprang in between them, and both of them were in a scuffle, and they had the prisoner down in a kind of a stoopâ€”it is quite a narrow passage; the forecastle is on deck; and the galley is partitioned off from the forecastleâ€”they did not have him down; they had him in a stooping position, and he sent the knife up from below into Berryman's legâ€”I saw thatâ€”after that Berryman ran out of the forecastleâ€”he bled a good dealâ€”I and the mate also ran outâ€”the prisoner then went in round a corner of the partition, and stood with a knife in one hand, and a bottle in the otherâ€”I saw him throw a bottle at the captain which struck him on the face.

Cross-examined. Q. Was that after the captain had fired at him? A. No; beforeâ€”the captain did fire at him I believe, with a pistolâ€”I saw him fire at himâ€”the shot did not strike him, because it could not, he was round the corner, and the captain stood in the doorway, and he fired right straight inâ€”the captain could not see him from where he stoodâ€”the prisoner did not show me any of the shot afterwardsâ€”I swear that no shots were fired until after he struck Henry Berrymanâ€”I have not been talking to the other witnesses since they were examinedâ€”I had never heard the captain use violent language to the prisonerâ€”I can't say whether or not he was struck while we were in the forecastleâ€”he was not knocked down to my knowledgeâ€”he was in a stooping positionâ€”I suppose that was from their trying to drag him out of the forecastleâ€”I did not put my hand upon himâ€”Henry Berryman and the mate didâ€”I did not see Berryman strike him; I don't know what he was armed withâ€”he went in along with the mateâ€”I did not use the heaverâ€”I know nothing about the prisoner being kept for two days and more with very little foodâ€”I have not been talking this matter over with the captain and the mate coming home.
COURT. Q. Did you go with the brig on her voyage to the different places

she went to? A. Yes, and back with her to Englandâ€”the prisoner was not on board the whole of that time; he was ashore at St. Jago until we left, we then took him with usâ€”he was used well and fairly fed; he did no work; he was not beaten or knocked aboutâ€”he had as good a berth as any in the ship, except the captainâ€”when he went to bed the handcuffs were still onâ€”there was no person to undress him, or anything of the kindâ€”he was un
dressed and washedâ€”the young man that he stabbed used to wash him regularlyâ€”during the passage home he was kindly treated.

SAMUEL JOSHU
A. I was a seaman on board the Milo, and went out from Englandâ€”I remember, on 28th May, Pratt being put in ironsâ€”while that was being done the prisoner came down from aloftâ€”he said, "Don't give in to the b----s; don't give in to the b----sâ€”the captain said, "Go about your workâ€”he did not; he went into the forecastleâ€”the captain told him to come out and go about his workâ€”they were asking him for about half
an-hourâ€”he said, "I will see you d----d first; I won't come out of the fore
castle; if you are man enough to come and take me out, I will have your life, or one of the threeâ€”I did not see them go into the forecastleâ€”I saw Berryman come out, and saw the blood on the deck.

Cross-examined. Q. How long have you been in the same vessel with the prisoner? A. Nearly seven monthsâ€”I do not come from the same country as he does, I belong to St. Helena; I was born there; he belongs to some part of the West Indiesâ€”I did not know him beforeâ€”we have not been good friendsâ€”we had a squabble togetherâ€”we never spoke except on duty, but when we got into the forecastle we never spoke togetherâ€”we never quarrelledâ€”we were not good friendsâ€”the day we came on board we never spokeâ€”he no care about speaking to me, so I no care about speaking to himâ€”I don't know why he did not speak to meâ€”I never saw him beforeâ€”I did not try to speak to himâ€”I liked the man very well; I don't 'know whether he liked me or notâ€”I suppose he was too good a man to speak to me; I suppose he thought too much of himselfâ€”we had our meals togetherâ€”we did not speak thenâ€”I had a boy in there to speak to me; a little boy that we had in the forecastleâ€”I came home in the vesselâ€”the prisoner was in irons the whole timeâ€”I did not speak to him then, or do anything for himâ€”he still thought himself a better man than me when he was in ironsâ€”I have been in irons sometimes, not very oftenâ€”I was put in irons at Bombay; not by this captainâ€”it was for not obeying the captain's orderâ€”I was in irons six weeksâ€”I was tried at Bombay; I was punished for six weeks in gaol, and then put on board againâ€”that was the only time I was ever in irons.

COURT. Q. Are you in the Milo now? A. No; I am doing nothing nowâ€”I have not got a ship; I am looking out for oneâ€”I believe the Milo is in the dry dock undergoing some repairsâ€”I don't know when she will be ready to sailâ€”I am not looking out for a berth with Captain Berryman; I have nothing to do with him nowâ€”I never sailed with him before, and never saw him beforeâ€”there was another man of colour on board besides Pratt and I; he has gone awayâ€”I did not get into trouble with Captain Berryman at all this voyage.

p.hi:
Recommended to mercy the jury on account of kit long imprisonment.â€”
Confined One Month.

div0.p:
PRESENT.â€”Mr. JUSTICE BYLES; Sir
FRANCIS GRAHAM MOON , Bart.; and Mr. Ald. ABBISS.

div1.p:
56.
THOMAS FRAZER (45), was indicted
for feloniously committing an unnatural offence on 25th May, upon the High Seas.
MR. PLATT conducted the Prosecution, MR. METCALFE the Defence.
NOT GUILTY .

57.
THOMAS FRAZER was again indicted
for a like offence on 7th May; upon which MR. PLATT offered no evidence.
NOT GUILTY .

div0.p: PRESENT.â€”Mr. Ald. PHILIPS; Mr. Ald. DAKIN; and Mr. COMMON SERJEANT.

div1.p:
58.
HENRY BURNHAM (38), was indicted
for bigamy.

GEORGE KILLY (Policeman, M 297). I produce two registers of mar
riages, marked A and Bâ€”I compared them with the register books, they are quite correctâ€”(One of these being read, certified a marriage at St. James's, Westminster, on 13th March, 1843, between Henry Burnham and Catherine Thomas)â€”the prisoner was given into my charge by Sarah Beardâ€”she said, "I give him in charge for bigamy"â€”I have been in the force about four yearsâ€”I am quite sure she used the word bigamyâ€”she did not say for marrying her when he had another wife aliveâ€”the prisoner said, "I had another wife, and you have got to find out whether she is alive or dead."
Prisoner. I said I had had another wife, but I was given to understand that she was dead. Witness. I am sure he did not say that; nothing of the kind.

CATHERINE DAVIS . I am a widow, and live at 33, Great Chapel-street, Westminsterâ€”I know the prisonerâ€”I was present at St. James's Church, Piccadilly, many years ago, when he was marriedâ€”I was bridesmaidâ€”it is so many years ago that I cannot recollect what year it wasâ€”it was the marriage of the prisoner to Catherine Thomasâ€”it was by bannsâ€”I signed my name as bridesmaidâ€”I am quite sure he is the same manâ€”I have not seen much of them sinceâ€”I have not seen Mrs. Burnham these twelve yearsâ€”she is dead.
COURT. Q. Did they live together for some time after the marriage? A. Yes.

MATILDA JANE THOMAS . I live at Wood-street, Barnet, and know the prisonerâ€”he lived with my mother, Catherine Thomasâ€”I am not his daughterâ€”I am twenty-two years oldâ€”the prisoner lived with her as man and wifeâ€”I cannot say up to what periodâ€”my mother died on 7th August, 1857.
SARAH SQUIRES BEARD . I live at 2, John-street, Christchurch, Surrey, and did at the time this happenedâ€”I was married to the prisoner on Monday, 3d June, 1856, at the registry office.

COURT. Q. Had he courted you long? A. We lived together as man and wife two years beforeâ€”after I had lived with him a twelvemonth, I heard he had another wife, but I was given to understand she was deadâ€”I gave him in custody because we had been having a few words; a quarrel.
NOT GUILTY .

59.
JOHN DOWNES (19)
, Stealing a watch, the property of
Thomas Fulford, from his person.

THOMAS FULFORD . I am a plumber and glazier, of 108, Limington-street, Pimlicoâ€”on 14th November, between 2 and 3 o'clock in the after
noon, I was walking along Tower-hill with a friendâ€”I stopped a minute or two to look at a man selling something at the side of the roadâ€”just as I was moving on, I felt tug at my watch chainâ€”I looked down and saw the watch in the prisoner's handâ€”I seized hold of him, and held himâ€”he struggled to get away, and he managed to pass it away to some persons in the crowd which had gathered roundâ€”I held him till a police
man came, and gave him in chargeâ€”some one found the bow of the watch at his feet,. and gave it to meâ€”the value of the watch was three guineasâ€”I am quite certain the prisoner was the manâ€”I hate not found my watch sinceâ€”he had the guard in one hand.

Prisoner. Q. Which hand did you see the watch in? A. In your left
handâ€”I won't be certain which; I am quite sure I saw it in one of your handsâ€”you were too sharp for me to catch hold of the hand in which it wasâ€”I caught hold of your collarâ€”I do not know which way you were goingâ€”you had your handkerchief in one hand, and the guard also in the same hand.
JONATHAN NEWMAN (Policeman, H 71). The prisoner was given in charge to me by the last witnessâ€”he said, "You're too late; it's goneâ€”I saw the ring on the guard.

GUILTY .*â€”
Confined Nine Months.

60.
HENRY NICHOLLS (21), and
JOHN WALDREN (21)
, Stealing I box, and 46 lbs. of tea, the property of the
Midland Railway Company.

RICHARD KENWOOD (Policeman, H 194). I had known the two prisoners some yearsâ€”on the evening of the 17th October, about half-past 5 o'clock, I was in Shoreditch, and saw them there walking in company togetherâ€”I followed them for something like half an hour, through various streets into the Minoriesâ€”when they got there they met a van laden with corn and tea, belonging to the Midland Railway Companyâ€”directly they met it they turned and followed it through Hounsditch, through Wormwood-street to the corner of London Wall, when Nicholls went up and lifted the tea off the front part of the van, and was coming back towards meâ€”I went to take him in custody, and he threw the tea at meâ€”the driver was sitting on the box, above the tea; the tea was at the back of himâ€”both prisoners made their escapeâ€”Waldren was close by his side when he took the teaâ€”they both turned together, and came back towards me together, and I went to take them in custodyâ€”they both ram in the same direction, close togetherâ€”I have known Nicholls for some years by the nickname of Brewer.

Cross-examined by MR. COLLINS (for Nicholls). Q. What time was this in the evening? A. From ten minutes to a quarter past 6 when it was taken offâ€”it was darkâ€”it was gas-lightâ€”I might be perhaps twelve or sixteen yards off, or perhaps twenty, when I saw him take it offâ€”it was not a very crowded thoroughfareâ€”the van was walking on, not stoppingâ€”he took it from just underneath where the driver was sitting, more in the front than in the centreâ€”he went and took it off with his hands.
COURT. Q. Is it one of Pickford's vans? A. The same shape.
Cross-examined by MR. ROSHER (for Waldren). Q. Art you positive as

to Waldren being the other man? A. Yes; I could see distinctlyâ€”the two were side by side when Nicholls lifted it off, as close as they could get to one anotherâ€”they had been in company the whole of the time that I followed them; walking together, sometimes two or three paces apart, and sometimes togetherâ€”they were conversing together on different occasions on the wayâ€”I kept a certain distance behind them, sometimes twenty yards, sometimes perhaps twenty-five or thirty, so as to keep them in sightâ€”I did not hear them talking together at that distance, but I could when I was closer to them, and could see them talkingâ€”when they returned from the van I was as near to them as I am to youâ€”I could not hear what they said thenâ€”I swear they were talkingâ€”I could see them talkingâ€”I stood in an archway, and they passed me.
MR. POLAND. Q. Were you in plain clothes? A. Yesâ€”I was watching them altogether about three-quarters of an hourâ€”I am quite sure about both of them.

JAMES WHITE (Policeman, H 90). I received information about this robbery, and looked after the prisonersâ€”on 19th October, I was on duty in Hare-street, Bethnal-green, and saw Waldren go into the Red Cross public-houseâ€”I went in, tapped him on the shoulder, and said, "Brown, I want you for stealing half a chest of tea in the City the other nightâ€”he said, "Me! I am not the man at allâ€”I said, "Very well, you will have to come with me to the station"â€”he did so, and while waiting for Kenwood to come he said that he was in company with the other man, but did not know he meant to steal the teaâ€”I asked him what other manâ€”he said, "Brewer"â€”I had seen Nicholls beforeâ€”I knew him by the name of Brewer, and Waldren by the name of Brown.
Cross-examined by MR. COLLINS. Q. Did you know any-one else of the name of Brewer? A. I did not.

Cross-examined by MR. ROSHER. Q. You took Waldren in custody about 4 o'clock in the afternoon? A. Yes, in a public-house, where he was standing talking to the landlordâ€”Hare-street, Bethnal-green, is a wide thoroughfareâ€”I know the places thieves generally go toâ€”it is a place where I should expect to find a man that I was looking afterâ€”I knew he was in the habit of going to the Red Cross, and that was why I went there.

ISRAEL WATTS (Policeman, N 184). On Saturday, the 19th, about half-past 10 in the morning, I took Nicholls in custodyâ€”I told him he was charged with stealing half a chest of tea the other day from a van in the Cityâ€”he said be knew nothing of it at allâ€”I said, "You will have to come with me to the station; the constable that saw you do it is at the police-court"â€”I kept him outside till Kenwood came to identify himâ€”I do not of my own knowledge know Nicholls by any other name.
Cross-examined by MR. COLLINS. Q. He came with you directly? A. Yes.

WILLIAM HALL . I am a carman in the employment of the Midland Railway Companyâ€”I was driving a van belonging to that company on 17th October, about half-past 6 o'clockâ€”I was in the Minoriesâ€”I had this half chest of tea (produced) in the van, in the front partâ€”I was sitting up on one of those high things drivingâ€”I went through London-wallâ€”I was not aware of this being taken off the van at the timeâ€”I loaded the van.
Cross-examined by MR. COLLINS. Q. You did not miss this chest of tea, did you? A. Not till I was told it was goneâ€”the policeman did not tell me at the timeâ€”he had not the opportunity.
RICHARD KENWOOD (re-examined). I took charge of this chest of teaâ€”I took it to the station and gave a description of the prisonersâ€”I let the van
go onâ€”I had no chance to run after it, because it had got some yards onâ€”I went to look after the prisonersâ€”the chest has been in my possession ever since.
GUILTY .
WALDREN was further charged with having been before convicted at this Court, in May, 1858; to which he

PLEADED GUILTY.**â€”
Four Years' Penal Servitude.

NICHOLLS.**â€”
Confined Eighteen Months.

61.
CHARLES BENNETT (38), and
JOSHUA SMITH (24)
, Stealing, on 26th October, 500 lbs. of rags, and on 31st October, 1,189 lbs. of rags, the property of
William John Hall and another, the masters of Bennett.

THOMAS CLARK . I am an inspector of the Thames policeâ€”at half-past 9 on the morning of 1st November, I went to the prisoner Smith's house in consequence of some informationâ€”he keeps a small marine store-dealer's shop in Rosemary-lane, Whitechapelâ€”I said, "I am an inspector of police; have you bought any rags since yesterday morning?"â€”he said, "I have bought no rags this last eight months"â€”that was all he said to meâ€”I had a constable with meâ€”I left him with Smith, and proceeded to Messrs. Hall's warehouse in Seething-laneâ€”Bennett was employed there as foremanâ€”I saw him on the premises there and said, "I belong to the police; have you delivered any bales of rags since yesterday morning from the warehouse?"â€”he hesitated and said, "No"â€”a minute or more afterwards he said, "I delivered two bales of rags from the warehouse yesterday morning to a man of the name of Smith, a marine store dealer in Rosemary-lane; he gave me an order for them, but the order was not signed"â€”I said, "Where is that order?"â€”he said, "I gave it back to Smith again"â€”I then said, "You will consider yourself in my custody for stealing a quantity of rags"â€”I took him into custody, and on taking him past Smith's premises in Rosemary-lane, he said, "That is where Smith lives, who I sold the rags to"â€”that is all he said.
Smith. I did not say that I had bought none for seven or eight months.

Witness. I am quite certain that you didâ€”I met you close by your doorâ€”I did not ask you whether you had bought two bales of rags from Seething lane that morning, nor did you reply, "No"â€”you did not tell me that you had got two bales of cloth cuttings, which in the trade were called mungoes, and were not bales at all; nothing of the sortâ€”you did not tell me where they were in the shop.
COURT. Q. Did you see any cloth cuttings that answered to the description of mungoes? A. I saw a quantity of cloth cuttings in the shop.
MR. LEWIS. Q. Were those cloth cuttings separate from the 1,189 lbs? A. They were the 1,189 lbs. in question.
COURT. Q. Are they cuttings of woollen cloth? A. Yes; I saw them as soon as I entered the door.

HENRY DYER (Thames-policeman, 51). I was with Inspector Clark when he met Smithâ€”I did not hear the conversation that passedâ€”I crossed over to Smith and said, "Mr. Smith, have you received any bales of rags within this last week?"â€”he said, "No, I have not, not for this last eight months"â€”I said, "Have you sold any within this last week?"â€”he said, "No"â€”about this time we arrived at his house and went into his shopâ€”there were seven sacks of rags lying in the shop, and three I discovered in a cupboardâ€”I was left in charge of the prisoner by Inspector Clark, in whose absence I asked the prisoner whether he had got any bookâ€”he said, "Yes," and produced this oneâ€”I find the last entry in it to be 1st November, 1858â€”I

did not say anything to him on thatâ€”a short time afterwards he pulled out a quantity of papers from his pocket and began inspecting themâ€”he was about to replace them in his pocket when I said, "I will take charge of them"â€”I took them and found amongst them this paperâ€”(Read: "For cwt. of doth rags, 26th October, from Smith, Rosemary-lane")â€”the rope that I found concealed in a cask corresponded with the rope I have seen on Mr. Hall's premisesâ€”it is a very peculiar knot.
Smith. He never said anything about asking me if I had any rags or bales. Witness. I did.

COURT. Q. Was it before he was taken into the shop? A. It wasâ€”he was about thirty yards from the shop when Inspector Clark first spoke to himâ€”I did not know what Inspector Clark had asked himâ€”there was room in the shop for the other three bales.

CHARLES GILBERT . I live with my father, at 92, Royal Mintâ€”street Tower
hillâ€”he keeps a cart for the purpose of being hiredâ€”I know the prisoner Smith by sight, by doing a little job now and thenâ€”I have seen him several times, when he has come for the cartâ€”I recollect his coming to my father for a cartâ€”I cannot say bow long it was before this robbery, or how long it was before I was examined before the Magistrateâ€”I cannot tell how many weeks, days, or monthsâ€”it was a week or two, or a month before I was examinedâ€”Smith was not in the cart; he walked alongside of itâ€”I went in the cart to Crutched-faiarsfriarsâ€”I know Seething-lane; it is in Crutched
friars, through the railway arch, on the left hand sideâ€”I saw a bale put into the cart; I cannot say by whomâ€”it was lowered down by a crane from some warehouse; from a high place, a loopholeâ€”Smith was out of my Sight thenâ€”he had not led the horses up to this placeâ€”I had; I drove the cart, and he walked by the sideâ€”he told me to follow him and I did so, and he walked up to this placeâ€”I stopped because he told me toâ€”I saw him after the bale was lowered; as soon as I bad got out from the yardâ€”I had drawn into a yard and turned roundâ€”when Smith came down he told me to go on homeâ€”I knew where "home" wasâ€”I knew he meant to go on to his houseâ€”I knew where he livedâ€”I went to his houseâ€”he walkedâ€”when we got to his house we unloaded the cart and left the bale at Smith's shopâ€”about fire or six days afterwards, we removed some sacks from his house, and took them to Limehouseâ€”there was something in them; I cannot say whatâ€”the bale that was lowered into the cart was in a sack.

Smith. The father and the boy came down with me in the morning. Witness. My father was with me one morning, but not this morning that I have been speaking ofâ€”there was one man with you; not all the while.

COURT. Q. What part of the time was he with him? A. When I went to fetch the balesâ€”the man remained in the cart with me; he was there when the bale was loweredâ€”the prisoner left the cart at the top of Seething-laneâ€”the man went right home with me and Smithâ€”I left him at Smith'sâ€”Smith said, when he left me at the top of Seething-lane, "If any one asks, you may tell them this is Smith's cart"â€”I said, "All right."

TIMOTHY DONOGHUE . I carry on business at 34, Royal Mintâ€”street, as fishmonger and greengrocer, and keep a horse and cart, which I let out for hireâ€”I know Smithâ€”on 31st October, about 8 o'clock in the morning, I saw him go up and down the street before be spoke to me, and then he said, "Will you come and do a job this morning?"â€”I said, "I can't, I got Something else to do"â€”at last he offered me 4s., which was a little above price, and I consented to do the job for himâ€”he and I jumped into the cartâ€”we got down to Seething-lane and went up a gatewayâ€”I did not know

the name of the premises at that timeâ€”I am told they belong to Messrs. Hallâ€”when we got into the yard two bales were put into my cart; bales of rags, I believe, from a loophole in the warehouseâ€”Smith was not in the cart at that time; he had got outâ€”he left before we came into Seething-laneâ€”I saw him in the yard as we were loadingâ€”I saw him before we leftâ€”he told me to take the bales to his place, and I did soâ€”he followed after usâ€”I cannot recollect his telling me to leave them at his place, but I suppose it was by his directions, or I should not have left them thereâ€”he paid me the 4s.

HENRY BACON HALL . I am superintendent of the business of William John Hall and another, harbingersâ€”they have wharves at Custom-House Quay, and had warehouses at Seething-laneâ€”Bennett had been in? our ser
vice for about two and a half years from beginning to end; but not more than twelve months in charge of the warehouse as foremanâ€”it would be his duty, as foreman, to deliver bales to persons on receiving an order; that order being entered in this book (produced), and countersigned by one of usâ€”he would bring that order down at night to account for his delivery; it would be filed and brought back to the warehouseâ€”it owned be his personal duty to bring it to the quayâ€”he would execute the order and deliver the goods; and then return the order at night, and it would be checked and filedâ€”we should keep the order as our voucher for the delivery of the goodsâ€”it would be his duty to see that it was numbered in numerical order, and countersigned by usâ€”he had not the least authority to part with goods without that orderâ€”it is a par
ticular form of orderâ€”they may write themâ€”we have printed forms as wellâ€”sometimes they write them themselvesâ€”I have been fifty-five years as a wharfinger, and so have some knowledge 'of the trade; not only in ragsâ€”I do not find in this book any order for 5 cwts. on 26th Octoberâ€”nothing of the kind; nor an entry on 31st October for 1,189 lbs.â€”they would not be speci
fied by pounds, but by bales, which would weigh 5 1/2 cwts.â€”they give us the landing weight on the order, which we should deliverâ€”I have examined these rags (produced) forming the bulk of 1,189 lbs.â€”they are French ragsâ€”I have compared them with some others from bales from which we have missed some, and they are as closely alike as possibleâ€”the canvas is exactly alike, and the rope and tie of the knot are exactly the same.
COURT. Q. Had you ever dealt with Smith? A. No; I never saw him till he was in custody.
MR. LEWIS. Q. You do not sell rags yourself? A. Certainly not, we are warehousemen; we only hold them for the ownersâ€”Bennett had no authority to sell rags.
DANIEL SMITH (Thames-policeman, 79). I took Bennett to the stationâ€”I asked him if he had sold any ragsâ€”he said, "Yes, I sold two bags to Mr. Smith, but T am not paid for them."

Smith's Defence. A man came one morning to my shop and asked me if I would buy some cloth cuttings. I asked him how many he had got. He said about half a hundredweightâ€”I said I would give him 18s. a cwt. I weighed them; there was just half a hundredweight. I paid him; he did not want the bag back in which they were. About 3 o'clock he brought another half hundredweight. I asked him whose they were; he said his master's. I asked him where he lived; he said in Seething-lane. I asked him his name; he said Bennett. I asked him how he came by them; he said there had been a sale. I bought them for 9s., and sold them for 1l. At night he came and asked me if I was a buyer of rags; I said I would buy them of him, and he told me to hire a cart and send it round.

I hired one, and went with them and showed them where Seething-lane was, I left them and went home, and in about half an hour afterwards the bale of rags came. I unloaded them and sent the cart home. I had to take the rags out of the bales, because the bales were too big to come in. I did that in the street. Next morning I had another bale; it was not so good as the the first, I said I could only give 16s. a cwt. for it. When we got the first bale in the cart, he said, "You might as well take the two, this all I have got," and I did so. I told him I could not pay him then, I did not know the worth of them. I tried to sell them at a place, and they offered 15s. a cwt which I did not think enough, and I said he had better let me have them a day or two, and I would try and get as much as I could for them. The man told me they were his own property. If I had been aware they were stolen goods, I should not have sold them to my next door neigh
bour. I know there are very often sales in Seething-lane and in Mark-lane. I can take my solemn oath that I did not know they were stolen.

MRS. COHEN. I have known Smith about eighteen monthsâ€”I am a marine-store dealer in Royal mint-streetâ€”he has been carrying on business in Rosemary-laneâ€”I have always known him to be an upright, honest, steady young manâ€”that is his character.

Cross-examined by MR. LEWIS. Q. How long has he had that shop? A. About four monthsâ€”he used to deal with us at one time in ragsâ€”he has not bought any of usâ€”when he first went into business he used to sell to us; but latterly, I suppose, he has sold to better merchants, where he could do better than with usâ€”I do not think he has sold to us for four or five months; not rags of this kindâ€”I never saw anything of that sort in his possession before to-day.

p.hi: also gave Smith a good character.

div1.p:
GUILTY .â€”MR. LEWIS stated that delivery orders had since come in to the prosecutors, for sixty-seven bales, and in every one of those bales there were defi
ciencies in the weight. The Jury stated their impression to be that Smith had been rather the dupe of Bennett.

BENNETTâ€”
Four Tears' Penal Servitude.

SMITHâ€”
Confined Nine Months.

div0.p:
PRESENT.â€”SIR
JAMS DUKE , Bart. M.P. Ald.; and Mr.RECORDER.

div1.p:
62.
WILLIAM SWAINE (49)
, Embezzling and stealing the several sums of 3l. 6s., 1l. 6s. 3d., and 8l., received by him on account of
George Evans, his master; to which he

PLEADED GUILTY .â€”
Three Years' Penal Servitude.

63.
SARAH BARTLY (38)
, Unlawfully obtaining by false pretences 6 pinafores, 1 coat, 2 jackets, 2 handkerchiefs, 3 pillow-cases, and 3 shirts, the goods of
Charles Hardy.

ANN DORLTON . I am servant to Mr. Charles Hardy, of 32, Castle-street, Holbornâ€”a person named Edwards mangles for himâ€”she lives at 19, Leather-laneâ€”on 13th November last the prisoner called at the houseâ€”I knew her by sight beforeâ€”she asked me for the manglingâ€”she had been in

the habit of fetching it before for Mrs. Edwardsâ€”I gave her twenty-six pieces; they consisted of pocket handkerchiefs, towels, jackets, pinafores, a child's coat, and other thingsâ€”she took those things awayâ€”she did not say she came from Mrs. Edward's on this occasion, but she did at firstâ€”she asked for the mangling as she had done on former occasions.
Prisoner. Q. Had you not left off sending your mangling to Mrs. Edwards? A. No; no one came to the house but you.

MARY ANN EDWARDS . I live at 19, Leather-lane, and keep a mangleâ€”I have been in the habit of doing mangling for Mr. Hardy for about twelve monthsâ€”the prisoner lodged in the same house with meâ€”she has gone two or three times to Mr. Hardy's for the manglingâ€”I did not send her on 13th November; she had left the house on the Sunday before thatâ€”she did not bring me any things to mangle.
Prisoner. I am innocent. I had no mangling.

JAMES MCWILLIAM (City-policeman, 224). I apprehended the prisoner on 22d Novemberâ€”I told her she was charged with obtaining from 32, Castle-street, some goods by false pretencesâ€”she said it was a mistake; she had not been near the placeâ€”she said she had no home at the time; she had been living at 19, Leather-lane.

COURT to ANN DORLTON. Q. Are you quite certain she is the person who came for the things? A. Positive; I had seen her four times before, and it was because she had had them before, that I gave them to her on this occasion.
Prisoner's Defence. I am not guilty. I never was in a station-house before.

GUILTY .*â€”
Confined Six Months.

64.
SAMUEL FULLER (21)
, Unlawfully assaulting
Frances Arnold, with intent, &c.
NOT GUILTY .

65.
HENNRY WILSON (27)
, Feloniously forging receipts for the sums of 3l. 16s. 1d., 4l. 13s. 3l. 12s. 2d., 3l. 16s. 4d. and 4l. 5s. 1d., with intent to defraud; to which he
PLEADED GUILTY .

MR. COOPER, for the prisoner, stated that he had been in the service of the South Eastern Railway Company for three years and eight months, that owing to sickness in his family he was led to forge these receipts, and that a gentleman present would, after the expiration of his sentence, take him into his service.

p.hi: for the prosecution, stated that he was not instructed to press for a heavy punishment.

div1.p:
66.
GEORGE PROCTOR (23)
, Stealing 6 metal pole-ends, 24 rings, and 7 bars of soap, value 7s., the property of
William Britter.
MARY ANN BONSEY . I am servant to Mr. William Britter, of Lewisham

â€”on Saturday, October 26th, about noon, I saw the prisoner in a field at the bottom of our gardenâ€”he was in the middle of the field, about thirty yards from the footpath, and was looking over our fenceâ€”another man was with himâ€”after that the witness Pearson came to the house, and in consequence of what he said I went into a field adjoining the one I had seen the prisoner in, and in a ditch there I found these curtain rings (produced)â€”they are my master'sâ€”I had seen them safe a few days beforeâ€”they were kept in a store-room over the stablesâ€”I had seen the stable-door fastened at 10 o'clock that morning; but I do not know that the things were there then.
Prisoner. You said at the police-court that it was 150 yards from where you saw me. Witness. No; I said it was 50 yards, and it was 200 yards from where the things were laid.

WILLIAM BRITTER . On 26th October I was from homeâ€”I returned about half-past 5â€”in consequence of what the servant told me I went to the stableâ€”I examined the room above it, and found it had been broken openâ€”I saw these things that evening at the station, and identified them as mineâ€”next morning I found seven bars of soap at the end of the stable; they had been removed from the room aboveâ€”the stable door had been forced.

WILLIAM PEARSON . I am a labourer at Forest-hillâ€”on Saturday, 26th October, about a quarter to 1, I was walking round the fields behind the prosecutor's house, and saw the prisoner and another man coming in a direc
tion from the houseâ€”the other man was carrying something under his coat; I could not see what it was, but it looked shineyâ€”on seeing me they put the things in a ditch, and passed meâ€”I went up and saw what they wereâ€”I then went to Mr. Britter's house and asked if they had lost anything, and then went to the constable's houseâ€”I saw the things found in the ditch; it was where I had seen them put something in.
Prisoner. Q. What distance were you from the men you say you saw carrying something? A. About 150 or 200 yardsâ€”I saw nothing in your possession.
COURT. Q. Did you know the prisoner before? A. Yes; I had seen him round there twice beforeâ€”I saw him again on the following Wednesday when was taken into custody.
JOHN MOORE (Policeman, R 164). I apprehended the prisoner on 30th October.

Prisoner's Defence. Pearson says he was 200 yards away from the men when he saw them put these in the ditch. It is not feasible that he could discern where a man put anything at such a distance. I was in a cell by myself at the police-court when be came to identify me, and I was shown by myself to the servant.

GUILTY .*â€”
Confined Nine Months.

67.
MARY MOONEY (27)
, Stealing a purse containing 25s., the pro
perty of
John Conner, from the person of
Margaret Conner, having been before convicted of felony; to which she

PLEADED GUILTY .**â€”
Three Years' Penal Servtiude.

68.
EDWARD HAVER (15)
, Stealing a tin canister and 121. in money the property of
Thomas Stace Chubb, in his dwelling house; to which he

PLEADED GUILTY .â€”
Confined Nine Months.

69.
DAVID MONTRION (22)
, Feloniously uttering on 19th October a counterfeit shilling to
Alfred Bastin, having been before convicted of uttering counterfeit coin twice on the same day.â€”

The prisoner pleaded NOT GUILTY, and MR. RIBTON on his behalf, contended that on the arraignment, the Clerk of the Court had not proceeded according to the order laid down in the Criminal Law Consolidation Act, 24 and 25 Victoria, c. 96, Â§ 116, which directed that "upon any indictment for committing any offence after a previous conviction, the offender shall first be arraigned upon so much of the indictment as charges the subsequent offence, and, if convicted, shall then be asked whether he has been previously convicted;" that, though the Old Act expired on 31st October, an offence committed in October under the Old Act must be tried under the New. MR. COOKE, for the prosecution, submitted that as the prisoner had to be tried for an offence under the Old Act, the old form of procedure must be followed, as the 3rd section of the New Act stated that uany offence committed against any of the said Acts shall be dealt with, inquired into, and determined, in the same manner as if those Acts had not been repealed," MR. RIBTON in reply, contended that the 3d section applied to the form of the indictment and to the trial itself, but did not touch the form of procedure. THE COURT having con
sulted MR. RECORDER, was of opinion that the old procedure should be adopted, that the case did not come under the 37th clause, and that the words in the first clause governed the whole.

PETER PROUT (Police-sergeant, 37 R). I produce a certificateâ€”(Read;" Central Criminal Court, January 1st, 1855, Edward Neville, convicted, on his own confession, of uttering two counterfeit florins, on the same day-Con
fined Nine Months")â€”I was a witness on the trial, and believe the prisoner to be the person.
Cross-examined by MR. RIBTON, Q. Are you sure of him? A. Yes; I have seen him since.

EMMA BASTIN . My husband keeps a grocer's shop in Lewisham-roadâ€”on, I believe, 5th October, the prisoner came thereâ€”it was about a fort
night before my confinementâ€”he asked for two ozs. of tea, two ozs. of cocoa, and 11b, of moist sugar; they came 1s. 1d.â€”he gave me a shilling and a penny, and left with the goodsâ€”I put the shilling with two other shillings in the drawerâ€”I suspected it to be bad and took particular notice of it; it was a Victoria shillingâ€”my husband came in almost directlyâ€”he brought the shilling to me; it was the same that I had had of the prisonerâ€”he took care of itâ€”my child was born on the 7th, and on the 19th, when I was up stairs with the nurse, sitting up in a chair, my husband brought the prisoner up stairs, and I recognised him as the person who was there on the 5thâ€”I said, "That is the man" the nurse interfered to prevent any
thing more passing, and he was taken down stairs.

Cross-examined. Q. What time of day was it? A. Between 12 and 1, I believeâ€”I had never seen him before the 5th, to my knowledgeâ€”I took particular notice of the other two shillings in the till, that I might know this, because I suspected it to be badâ€”I looked at it before I gave him the tea and sugar, but did not say anything aboutâ€”my husband came in in five minutes, and found itâ€”I do not recollect how long before the other two shillings had been takenâ€”I do not know whether I took themâ€”when I put the one in I did not take up the other two, but I remarked themâ€”looking at them in the till was enough; they were a different reignâ€”when my husband found the shilling on the 5th, he showed it to me, and I described the young manâ€”the prisoner was in the shop from five to ten minutes.
ALBERT BASTIN . On 5th October, I came home, went to the till and saw this Victoria shilling; its appearance attracted my attentionâ€”there wer

two other shillings in the till; neither of which was a Victoriaâ€”I took it out immediately, and showed it to my wife; who described the person of whom she had had itâ€”I put it in the central compartment of my cash box with another bad shillingâ€”on 19th October, about midday, the prisoner came and asked me for two ozs. of tea, two ozs. of coffee, and two ozs. of moist sugar; they came to a shilling and a halfpennyâ€”he gave me two shillings, one good and one badâ€”while I was looking at it, but before I had an opportunity of speaking, he said I can give you a halfpennyâ€”I said, "I do not want your halfpenny; this is a bad shilling"â€”he said that he did not know itâ€”I said that I rather suspected he did, and that he had been there beforeâ€”I took him up to my wife, and directly he put his foot on the top stair, she recognized himâ€”the nurse would not allow him to speak, and he went down with me and denied ever having been in the shop beforeâ€”I sent for a constable and handed him the three bad shillings.
Cross-examined. Q. Did you put the shilling he gave you into the till? A. No; I kept it in my handâ€”my wife described him as very much like a man who worked for her cousin.

ELIZABETH HAWKED , I keep a shop at Greenwich, and sell eggsâ€”on 25th September, at 8 in the morning, the prisoner came for two eggs; they came to 2d.â€”he put down a shillingâ€”I said this is a bad oneâ€”he said, "Oh, is it," took it up and gave me a good oneâ€”I bad never seen him before; he is the person.
Cross-examined. Q. You merely looked at it and objected to it? A. Yesâ€”I do not know what reign it was.

JOSHUA PARTRIDGE . I know the prisonerâ€”he has been to my shop several timesâ€”the last time was six or seven weeks agoâ€”he purchased butter, cheese, and other things, amounting to something less than a shillingâ€”he tendered me a bad shillingâ€”I bent it with my teeth, and returned it to him, and he gave me a good one.

WILLIAM WESLEY (Policeman, 95 R). On Saturday, 19th October, I was tent for to Mr. Bastin's, and received the prisoner in custody with these three bad shillings, and one good oneâ€”he was searched at the station, and a half-crown, two shillings, two sixpences, three threepenny pieces, four four-penny pieces, and 9 1/2 d. in copper, were found on himâ€”he had a basket in which I found a set of brass castors, half a quartern of flour, two ozs. of tea, two ozs, of coffee, and 1 lb. of brown sugar.
Cross-examined. Q. Did you find any bad money on him? A. No.
WILLIAM WEBSTER . These shillings are bad.

GUILTY.â€”
Four Years' Penal Servitude.

70.
MARY SHEEN (36)
, Stealing 1 shawl, the property of
Edward Charles Carpenter Marsh, she having been before convicted; to which she

PLEADED GUILTY .**â€”
Confined Nine Months.

71.
GEORGE INKPEN (20), was indicted
for the wilful murder of
Margaret Edwards.

STEPHEN ELLIS (Police-inspector, R). I am stationed at Greenwichâ€”on 11th December, I went to the prisoner's house 37, Amelia-terrace, Deptfordâ€”it was about a quarter to 11 in the evening when I arrivedâ€”I understood that he was in bed, but he dressed himself and came downâ€”I did not then tell him why I had come, but asked him to come outside, and we went out

together in company with several other persons, his friendsâ€”I believe I said, "Come thin way"â€”I said to him, as I understood that he had made a statement, "I suppose you can point out the spot whore it occurred?"â€”he turned round, looked me in the face, and said, "I will tell you all about it; I bad been to Hackney-wick, I got out at the station in High-street: I then went to Bennett's, the barbers, and from there to the Lord Duncan public-house. While I was there she came in for the supper beer; we went out together; she offered me some of the beer; I drank some, she drank some, and together we drank the whole of it; she then said,' It is no se living, my friends are always nagging at me; will you follow me?' I said, 'Yes; anywhere you like to go.' We then went down the Mornington-road to the Surrey Canal; she asked me if I had got a handkerchief I said, "Yes."She said, "That will not be long enough to go round us both;" she said, "I have a piece of tape, but I did not bring it for that purpose;" I said, "I have got some boot laces," she said, "They will do;" we then tied ourselves together"â€”he did not say howâ€”she said, "I do not think I shall sink; I said, "Why not?" she said, "Because the crinoline will keep me up."She then put her arms round my neck and we got into the canal. We rolled over together several times she soon drowned; but did not very soon sink. The string broke, and I got out on the opposite side. I tried to save her but could not. I hen got into the canal again, swam across, and went home"â€”I asked him what the young woman's name was; he said, "Margaret Edwards," and that he had been keeping company with her about three yearsâ€”I proceeded with him to wards the Surrey Canalâ€”I have omitted to say that he said at the tine they tied themselves together, "I was" very bad, and she had to hold me upâ€”when we got near the canal I asked him if he felt better, as he had previously complained of shivering and cold; he said, "Yes; I am all right now; if I had been as well a while ago, I should not have been in this situation," or words to that effectâ€”I sent for some drags; and at the spot which he pointed out in the Surrey Canal, we found the body of the. young womanâ€”he appeared anxious to see the body, and I allowed him to do soâ€”on its being landed he said, "It is not injured," or, "not damaged, is it?"â€”on obtaining a full view of the face he remarked, "It has made a great difference to her"â€”I then took him to the station-house, and charged him merely with attempting to commit suicide by throwing himself into the Surrey Canal in company with Margaret Edwards, who was drownedâ€”I said, "I have merely taken your own words;" he said, "Yes; that is the truthâ€”I assisted in taking the body of the girl to the dead-houseâ€”I found no handkerchief or boot-laceâ€”the prisoner said nothing to me about any tape.

Cross-examined by MR. SLEIGH. Q. When he looked at the body and made these observations, were they made in a tone of affection? A. Yes; rather so than otherwiseâ€”he might have been drinking, but I should consider him quite sober and rationalâ€”that was after being in the waterâ€”he said that he had been drinkingâ€”I omitted thatâ€”when he said that, if he had been as well a while ago it would not have occurred, I said, "Had you been drinking?"â€”he said, "Yes; rather freelyâ€”the information which caused me to go to where he was was from one of his own friends: Wright and another personâ€”I understand that he was in bedâ€”I saw a coat and hat down stairs which I was told belonged to himâ€”they were very wet.

MARY ANN COLLINS . I am the wife of John Collins, a carpenter of Deptfordâ€”the deceased Margaret Edwards was my sisterâ€”she was twenty
four

years old, and was singleâ€”I had last seen her on Sunday evening; the night before she was at my house from 6 to half-pastâ€”she was in very good spirits, as good as ever I saw herâ€”I know that she and the pri
soner have been together as suitors just upon three years.

SUSANNAH RUSSELL . I am the wife of Mr. Russell, of Deptfordâ€”he is in the Income-tax officeâ€”Margaret Edwards has been in my service a year and eight monthsâ€”I saw her about half-past 7 this eveningâ€”she appeared in good spiritsâ€”I gave her certain directions, and she had to leave the house for some beerâ€”I did not see what she took for itâ€”it was her duty to bring a pintâ€”that was partly for herself and partly for the familyâ€”I had two jugs of a particular kindâ€”one of them is missingâ€”it was similar to this one (produced).

WILLIAM HAY . I keep the Lord Duncan public-house, Broadway, Dept
fordâ€”I knew the deceased Margaret Edwards well for some years as a servantâ€”she was in the habit of coming to my house for beerâ€”I know the prisonerâ€”I saw him on that night first between 6 and 7 o'clockâ€”the girl came in a little after 7, or half-past 7â€”the prisoner was thereâ€”she brought a jug similar to thisâ€”I cannot say that it is the sameâ€”they recognized each other, and she left in about three or four minutesâ€”she appeared to be in good spirits at that timeâ€”she came in smiling as if she was pleased to see the prisonerâ€”she left first; and he left a few seconds after herâ€”he was perfectly sober.

Cross-examined. Q. Did she male some signal? A. In leaving she got to the door, and threw a glance towards him as much as to ask him to follow herâ€”he had been there, I should think, getting on for an hour before she came in with the beer-jugâ€”I cannot say what he bad been drinking; but very triflingâ€”he is a young man of very temperate habitsâ€”I know that for years he has been in the employ of the Steam Navigation Companyâ€”I have never seen him otherwise than as a quiet, well-conducted manâ€”I cannot say whether he was very fond of this girlâ€”I think he drank a pint of porter, or a glass of half-and-half, I know it was not spiritsâ€”he told me that he had been at Hackney-wick the previous part of the day to see a running matchâ€”the girl talked to him in a low tone of voiceâ€”I did not notice that she took the most part in the conversationâ€”they were speaking together in an under tone, and I had other business to attend toâ€”they were talking together about three or four minutes before she went out and beckoned him.

SOPHIA LEWIS . I live in Roll's-street, Deptford, under the North Kent Archesâ€”my husband built his cottage thereâ€”on 11th November, between 8 and 9 in the evening, I had occasion to go to the next cottage to see my daughter who was left in charge of two children; and as I reached the win
dow, I heard a fearful scream in the direction of the Surrey Canalâ€”it appeared to me more of a female voiceâ€”I was so alarmed that I turned backâ€”it was as nearly half-past 8 as possible.

Cross-examined. Q. Have you ever been examined about this matter before? A. Noâ€”I cannot tell you what distance our house is from the canal; bat it is right in a line with the canal, and the arches go over itâ€”I had only to go next door, from one door to anotherâ€”it was last Monday fortnightâ€”I mentioned it on the Tuesday to Mr. Lewins, a market-gardenerâ€”I live so secluded that I did not hear any talk about it till my son came home to dinner and told me that something had occurred the night beforeâ€”it was not till after that that I mentioned having heard anythingâ€”there is a public thoroughfare over the bridgeâ€”there is another cottage built on

the railway the same as our's isâ€”there were no trains running at this time; but we are so accustomed to them, living there nearly eight years, that I did not notice themâ€”I do not know the spot where the body was foundâ€”I have not been shown it sinceâ€”I understand that an inquest was held in our neighbourhoodâ€”I read it on Sunday in the newspaperâ€”I did not go to the inquestâ€”I read that the prisoner was taken before the Magistrateâ€”I heard screams; but did not go before the Coroner or Magistrateâ€”I did not con
sider it of any momentâ€”we often hear noises, though we live in a lonely partâ€”if I had not heard afterwards that something of this kind had occurred, I should have tried to avoid it, for I am a very nervous personâ€”I have known the prisoner's family for seven yearsâ€”he is a most respectable man.

COURT. Q. What is hit father? A. He is not living; his mother is livingâ€”I have seen her here this morningâ€”I only heard one scream, but I was so alarmed that I turned backâ€”it was very shrillâ€”it seemed to be a very fearful one of lengthâ€”I did not afterwards go to my daughter'sâ€”my neighbour, Mrs. Taunton, returned to her family, and afterwards came into my houseâ€”I did not say anything to her about the scream, or to anybody else that nightâ€”it was about half-past 4 that I saw Mr. Lewins after my son had come and told me what had happenedâ€”I did not mention the scream to my sonâ€”I did not think it properâ€”he is fourteen years oldâ€”I was so ill at the time that I did not know what to do.

ELIZA TAUNTON . I live at Roll's-street, Deptfordâ€”on the evening in question, about half-past 8 o'clock, my attention was attracted by screaming, in a female voice, in the direction of the Surrey Canal.

Cross-examined. When did you, after that night, make any mention of this matter to anybody? A. The next dayâ€”that was after I had heard what bad occurredâ€”the screaming was on 11th November, Mondayâ€”it was not till Tuesday afternoon, after I had heard what bad occurred, that I said anything to anybodyâ€”I saw Mrs. Lewis in the evening after I came home when I arrived at the door-way I went into her houseâ€”I mean at half-pastâ€”I live next door to herâ€”the railway trains run over our houseâ€”it was a continual screaming that I heardâ€”there were several screamsâ€”this was before I had seen Mrs. Lewisâ€”I saw her three or four minutes afterwardsâ€”I noticed it very much, thinking it might be my own children; and seeing Mrs. Lewis's door open, I thought the sound might come from there my two children are thereâ€”they scream like other people's children, but they were in bed and asleep thenâ€”at first I thought it might be some one in convulsions, screaming fits: big childrenâ€”I have only two children in my houseâ€”at the first moment my impression was that the screaming was from my houseâ€”I afterwards thought it was a female, or some big children screaming for help, or in convulsions, and I thought there might have been a fire in some cottageâ€”it did not strike me that it might be the railway whistle; it was not thatâ€”the trains run every quarter of an hour, but it was not the shrill railway whistleâ€”it was screaming from some individual.

COURT. Q. You say that it was continual screaming, and more screams than one; what interval was there between the screams I A. It was a con
tinual screaming; there was no spaceâ€”it was a continual screaming for two or three minutes, I cannot say exactlyâ€”when I got home I found my children in bed and asleep.
MR. SLEIGH. Q. How far is the pointsman's house from yours? A. A few arches off.
FREDERICK DAY . I am waiter at the Ship and Billet, East Greenwichâ€”I

have seen the prisonerâ€”I was in his company on 11th November, at Hackney Wickâ€”I afterwards went with him to King William-street, Cityâ€”it was half-past 5 when we got thereâ€”he bought a boot-lace thereâ€”he did not say that he wanted it for any reason whateverâ€”this (produced) resembles itâ€”it was a trifle longer than this, but very littleâ€”I left him at Deptford Railway-station, and he agreed to meet me at the Ship and Billetâ€”he said that he should be home at half-past 8.

Cross-examined. Q. Do you say that this is the lace he bought? A. It appears to be the oneâ€”we were not walking along the street when he bought itâ€”we were in a public-house in King William-street, and a man came in with boot-laces while we were drinking a pint of aleâ€”I bought one first, and then the prisoner bought oneâ€”it was a pair of boot-lacesâ€”he bought one and I bought the otherâ€”we bought them to get rid of the manâ€”I gave 2d for mineâ€”we had been to see a foot-raceâ€”we were not there with
out having something to drinkâ€”I had half a pint of brandy, neat brandyâ€”it was undilutedâ€”I also had two pints of ale in King William-streetâ€”we had one biscuit in King William-street, but I had the best part of itâ€”the prisoner only had a mouthful of the brandy; we shared it among three of us, and the two pints of ale we shared between two of us, a pint apieceâ€”the prisoner was really the worse for liquorâ€”he was very talkativeâ€”it was between 6 and 7 o'clock when I left himâ€”I left him in that excited stateâ€”extremely talkative and the worse for liquor.
MR. LEWIS Q. Did you see him after half-past 8? A. Yes; we came down in the train at half-past 6.

COURT. Q. How long did you stay at the public-house in King William-street? A. Till about a quarter to 6â€”we both went down by the train in the same carriage, from London Bridgeâ€”we left London Bridge at five minutes past 6â€”the last I saw of him was twenty-five minutes or half-past 6â€”I had known him some monthsâ€”he is a humane, well-conducted young-manâ€”he never told me that he was in love with this girl, but I had heard of it, and I knew the fact that he was keeping company with her.

JOHN ROSSITER . I am a painter, of Old King-street, Deptfordâ€”on the evening of 11th November, about a quarter to 9, or from that to 9 o'clock, I saw the prisoner at Penny Bundle-lane, which leads to the Surrey Canalâ€”I have been shown the spot from where the deceased was removedâ€”he was about five hundred yards from thereâ€”he was going from the canal in the direction of Amelia-streetâ€”I have not been shown the house where he livesâ€”he was running, and was we, as if he had been overboardâ€”it was a very dear nightâ€”I heard no screams.

Cross-examined. Q. If there had been any screams proceeding from the canal, were you in such a position as you must have heard them? A. I was at home at the timeâ€”my house is half a mile from the canalâ€”I left home at half-past 8, the half hour went as I came out at the doorâ€”it took about a quarter of an hour to walk there, but as the crow flies it is a much shorter distanceâ€”if there were cries at the canal, I certainly should not have heard them from my home, nor if I was coming in that direction, unless I was in the neighbourhood of the canalâ€”I cannot hear the railway whistle at my houseâ€”I have measured the depth of the canal, at the place where the body was found, there were five feet of water there, but on this night I should not think it was more than four feet six inchesâ€”the depth varies, owing to the locks.
JOHN SIMMONS . I live at 2, Somer's-street, Deptfordâ€”I found this jug in Florence-road, forty or fifty yards from Mrs. Russel's.
Cross-examined. Q. How far is that from the canal? A. I do not know; it is opposite New Cross-road.

JOSEPH HENDERSON . I am a member of the College of Physicians, re
siding in High-street, Deptfordâ€”I made an examination of the body of the deceased on the Tuesday, the day afterwardsâ€”after removing the clothes, I looked for any traces of external injury, and there were two marks: a bruise on the left side of the temple here, and an echymosed spot on the left side of the left arm, a dark spot or bruiseâ€”that might have arisen either from a blow or a fallâ€”I afterwards made a post-mortem examinationâ€”the body internally was perfectly healthyâ€”there was a good deal of frothy mucus from the mouth, and the lungs were gorged; the was drowned in factâ€”I after
wards attentively examined her clothesâ€”they did not present the least appearance of having any tie round themâ€”there was a depression on the bonnet, which was a black straw one, and the plaits were torn.

COURT. Q. I understand you to say that these marks might have arisen either from a blow or a fell? A. Yesâ€”they were both on the same side; they may have been caused by a bruise on the same substanceâ€”I think the bruise most have been from a flattened surfaceâ€”they may both be bruises at the same time from a flattened surface, or else there must have been an abra
sion of the skinâ€”the two marks were about in a straight line from one to the otherâ€”the bruise on the outside of the arm might have arisen from a graspâ€”the bruises were caused before death I think, because in bruising the dead body, we should not have that amount of discoloration under the skinâ€”there are barges going frequently backwards and forwards on the canalâ€”by before death I mean before the circulation had actually stoppedâ€”they might have been occasioned after apparent death.

p.hi: Inspector Ellis, by the direction of the Court, made a sketch of the locality, and pointed out the railway station, the bridge, and the switchman's-box.

div1.p: MR. SLEIGH to INSPECTOR ELLIS. Q. How far is the switchman's box from where the body was found? A. About three hundred yardsâ€”I should state that the distance from where the body was found, to the House of the witness who heard the screams, was not measured by me, but by police-constable Turner.

JOSIAH TURNER (Policeman, R 287, examined by the Court). There are two switchmen's boxes, one is almost directly over the canal, and the other fifty or sixty yards offâ€”I measured to where the two female witnesses live, that is 290 yardsâ€”there are forty-nine archesâ€”and to the other switchman's is fifty or sixty yards, that is immediately over the canalâ€”there are always switchmen in each box, night and day.

p.hi:
Joseph Beard more, superintendent of the General Steam Navigation Works, at Deptford; Richard William Temple, Master of the Dean Stanhope's School, Deptford; Thomas Cheeseman, a blacksmith, of 7, Garden-place, Deptford; John Wormley, a blacksmith, of Deptford; and Henry Tugwell, of 38, Amelia
terrace, Deptford, gave the prisoner a good character.

div1.p: GUILTY .â€”Strongly recommended to mercy by the jury, the woman being a consenting party. In reply to the Court, the jury stated that they believed the prisoner's statement to be honest and true, and that there was no spite, anger, malice, or deliberate intention to take the woman's life before they went to the canal.
DEATH .
SURREY CASES.

72.
JOHN HOWARD (23)
, Feloniously and knowingly uttering a forged 51. Bank of England note, with intent to defraud.

MARY ANN SPRAGUE . I am the wife of Thomas Sprague, a carman, of 93, Southwark-bridge-roadâ€”we take in lodgersâ€”I had a lodger named Mrs. Darkâ€”the prisoner used to visit her for four or five monthsâ€”Mrs. Dark has left usâ€”I saw the prisoner several times after she had leftâ€”on one occa
sion he asked me if I would allow him to have a letter directed for him at our house, from New Yorkâ€”he said he expected to receive a draft for some money; he did not say what amountâ€”a letter did arrive for him about the latter end of Augustâ€”I tried to find him in order to give him the letterâ€”I went to Kingsland after himâ€”tome days after, he called at my house and I gave him the betterâ€”he sat down and read itâ€”he took something from the inside of it and placed it in his breast-pocketâ€”it seemed like paperâ€”he said it was a draft from Americaâ€”I saw him again about a fortnight afterwardsâ€”it must have been Saturday, 21st Septemberâ€”he said he had had great difficulty in getting the draft changed, until a gentleman came forward and proved that he was John Howard; that they asked him if he knew anyone in town, and he said yes, he knew my husband; that they asked for how long, and he said three months, and they said that was not long enough, he must find some one else that had known him for years, and with that he went to Sheffield and got a gentleman, I can't say his name, but he was an agent in New York for Rodgers and Son, the cutlers to the Queen, to come forward and identify himâ€”he said the gentleman had come over from New York and was in Sheffield at that timeâ€”he said he had had the draft cashed in Bank of England notes, and he had as much difficulty in getting the notes cashed as he had the draft, being a strangerâ€”my husband came in, and the prisoner asked my husband if he Would change a note for himâ€”my husband said as soon as he had had his tea he would go and get it changed at Mr. Wright's the publican's near usâ€”they both went out together and came back together shortly afterwardsâ€”the prisoner thanked us for our kindness for taking the letter in and so forth, and said he should never repay us, and he gave my children half-a-crown to buy somethingâ€”we asked him to dinner the following day, Sundayâ€”he said he would come, but he did not.

THOMAS SPEAGUE . I am the husband of the last witnessâ€”I knew the prisoner when he used to call on Mrs. Darkâ€”on Saturday evening, 21st September, on coming home I found the prisoner in conversation with my wifeâ€”he asked me to change a 5l. note for himâ€”I asked him to wait until I had done my tea, and I would get it changed for him as I had not sufficient in the houseâ€”I went to Mr. Wright's, who keeps the Three Compasses in Guildford-streetâ€”the prisoner there produced a bank-note and gave it to me, and I handed it over to Mr. Wright, and asked him to be kind enough to give me change for a 5l. noteâ€”he said he would, and he took a pen to endorse my name on itâ€”I told him not to trouble himself, if he would hand me the pen I would endorse it myself, which I did in his presenceâ€”this is the note (produced)â€”here is my writing, "T. Sprague, 93, Southwark-bridge-road"â€”Mr. Wright gave me change, and the prisoner and I went back to my

houseâ€”he was asked to dinner next day, but did not comeâ€”I saw him in the evening about a quarter to 6 at I was going with a friend to hear Mr. Spurgeon at the Tabernacleâ€”I did not see nun till I was close to him, I merely nodded and ho did the same.
Prisoner. Q. Did I give you the note in the public-house? A. Yes.

EDWARD WRIGHT . I keep the Three Compasses in little Guildford-street, Southwarkâ€”I remember Mr. Sprague and the prisoner coming to my barâ€”Mr. Sprague produced a 5l. note and asked me to give him change for itâ€”he got it from the prisonerâ€”I gave him change and put the note away in my cash-boxâ€”Mr. sprague wrote his name on itâ€”this is the note.
Prisoner. Q. Did you see me give the note to Mr. Sprague A. Yes.

WILLIAM PEAT LOFTHOUSE . I am a clerk in the service of Rodgers and Son, cutlers of Sheffieldâ€”Mr. Crooks is their agent at New Yorkâ€”he was in England this year; I believe in the springâ€”I believe he went back in Julyâ€”Messrs. Redgers have no other agent in New York, I believeâ€”I am not aware that any other agent of theirs has been in England this year.

JOSEPH ANSON MEE . I am in the employment of the Kdin Vale Com
panyâ€”Mr. Septimus Crooks, the agent of Messrs. Rodgers, was, until recently the agent of that Companyâ€”he was in England in June lastâ€”he left about 15th June for New Yorkâ€”we have received communications from him sinceâ€”so far as I know he is in New York stillâ€”I have a letter from him dated in July.

JOHN FIRE (Police-inspector). I took the prisoner into custody on 14th October, at St Matthew's Square the Boroughâ€”I had received a descrip
tion of himâ€”he was with two other menâ€”I stopped him and said, "Is your name Howard!"â€”he said, "No, oh no, my name is not Howmrd"â€”I said, "You are the man that I want for uttering a forged 5l. Bank of England note to Mr. Sprague"â€”he said, "I am sure it is not; it must be somebody elseâ€”I took him to the station.
JOSEPH BUMSTEAD . I am inspector of notes to the Bank of Englandâ€”I have examined this note; it is forged in every respect.

Prisoner's Defence. My letters and papers have been taken from me; if they are produced I think you will find that I did receive this remittance from America, and I have a father-in-law in Ireland, who tent me tome money. I received this draft, and got it cashed, and got a 20l. note, and got it changed by one Richard Black for others.
