I got those parties to change the note, as I am a stranger here; I know nothing about notes; I have only been four months in this country. I told them I intended to go to Sheffield, for the purpose of having Mr. Crooks lo certify for me, as I had been employed by him in America; but it was not necessary for me to go, as I got the notes cashed hereâ€”if my letters are produced, it will explain things better than I canâ€”(Four letters were put in and read. Two were from Frankfort, signed Michael Mantrig, dated 18th and 23d June 1861, directed to J. P. Hatton, and purporting to enclose the halves of notes to the amount of 2 l.; the other two purported to be from Monkstown, Ireland, from the prisoner's mother-in-law, and were dated 14 and 17 July, 1861, but contained no allusion to money)â€”Those are not the letters; there are others which I expected to he produced. All that I have to say is that I got the 201. note changed by Richard Black, whom I knew in America seven or eight years agoâ€”I met him in the street; he invited me to his house, and he got the draft cashed for me and then the noteâ€”he gave me the note that I give to Mr. Sprague. I firmly believed the note to be good.
GUILTY .

p.hi: Recommended to mercy by the Jury, being a stranger in the Country.â€”

div1.p:
73.
THOMAS WARREN (29)
Stealing a pencil case and other articles the property of
Joseph Chapman Evans; 3 silver spoons and other articles, the property of
Joseph French, in his dwelling-house, and burglariously breaking out of the said dwelling-house; to which he

PLEADED GUILTY .â€”
Confined Twelve Months.

74.
HENRY MEW (23)
, Unlawfully having counterfeit coin in his pos
session with intent to utter the same.

JAMES BRANNAN . I was formerly inspector of the G division of police, and am now employed by the Mint authoritiesâ€”on 13th of this month, in consequence of information I received, I went to Friar-street with other officers; we concealed ourselves in premises opposite the Friar public-house, and after some time, in consequence of what I saw, I sent Serjeant Elliott in to seize the prisonerâ€”I had seen the prisoner go in there several times that dayâ€”I afterwards went in with Inspector Bryant and other officers, and Elliot said to me, "There it is; pick it up; he has just dropped it;" nodding hid head to a paper parcel which the prisoner was stamping onâ€”this is it (produced)â€”I picked it up, and opened it before the prisonerâ€”it contained six counterfeit shillings wrapped separately in paperâ€”he broke the paper while stamping upon themâ€”the prisoner said, "If my mother was to rise out of the grave, I never had them"â€”I then left him in the custody of Elliott, and saw the landlord of the public-house go into the privy at the backâ€”I there found this bag, containing nine half-crowns, two florins, and eight shillings (produced)â€”at the top part between the tiles and the raftersâ€”I then went back to where the prisoner was, and showed him what I had found, and told him where I had found themâ€”he said, "I hope I may be struck dead if I ever saw them."
Prisoner. I never saw them before Mr. Brannan showed them to me.

ARTHUR ELLIOTT (Police-sergeant, G 13). I was in company with Brannan on the night of 13th November, near the Friar public-house, and from what he said to me, I went inâ€”I there saw the prisoner in front of the barâ€”I laid hold of him; I caught him round both arms and the waist, so that he should not put his hands in his pocketsâ€”he then dropped a paper packet out of his right hand on the floor, and kicked about and tried to kick it awayâ€”Mr. Brannan and the other officers then came in, and I beckoned to Mr. Branuan with my head, and said, "There it is, Mr. Brannan, he has just dropped it; pick it upâ€”Brannan picked it upâ€”I could not see the packet in the prisoner's hand, but I saw it drop from his right hand; he had a fourpenny-piece, six
pence, and 1s. 2d. in coppers in his pocket.

Prisoner. Q. When you came in, did not you say, "What have you about you?" and I held up my hands for you to search me? A. No, you did not; I had no time. WILLIAM WEBSTER These six shillings are all bad, and five of them are from one mouldâ€”of those found in the privy there are eight shillings, and of those seven are from the same mould as the five; the two florins are from one mould, and the nine half-crowns are bad, and also from one mould.

Prisoner's Defence. I had been living as potman at the Friar, and had left about a fortnight. I never went outside the house only once all that day and that was to get my tea; I went to sleep in front of the tap-room fire, and afterwards went to the bar When Serjeant Elliott came in I offered to let him search me. I am quite innocent of it.
JAMES BRANNAN (re-examined). I did not see the packet droppedâ€”I saw

Elliott seize the prisonerâ€”we could see that before we arrived In the houseâ€”he did not hold up his hands; he was offering all the resistance he couldâ€”there was no one else at that end of the bar.

ARTHUR ELLIOTT (re-examined). I have not the least doubt whatever as to seeing him drop itâ€”I saw it drop from his handâ€”it was impossible for him to have lifted his arms, as I had them both down round the waistâ€”there was nobody else on that side of the bar.â€”
GUILTY .
Confined Fifteen Months.

p.hi: Brannan stated that he believed the prisoner got rid of pounds' weight of bad Coin in a week at the Friar public-house.

div1.p:
75.
JOHN THOMAS HUGO (22)
, Unlawfully uttering counterfeit coin.

JOHN HAYTER . I am barman at the Black Prince public-house in the Walworth-roadâ€”on the evening of 13th November, the prisoner came there for a pint of porter, and put down a bad florinâ€”I immediately detected it, and asked him if he knew what he had given meâ€”he said, "Yes; a two-shilling piece"â€”I said, "No, something in the shape of one"â€”I asked him where he got it fromâ€”he said he did not know, and walked outâ€”I went after him, but lost sight of himâ€”I broke the florin in two, and ultimately gave it to Edward Johnson, 65 Pâ€”the prisoner had some of the porter.
Prisoner. Q. Did I not have whiskers on my face? A. I did not notice that.

COURT. Q. Are you sure about his being the person? A. Yeaâ€”he did not stay in the house above a minute; I knew him againâ€”I had never seen him before, to my knowledgeâ€”I saw him again on the following Monday, in the police-cell with nine or ten others, and I picked him outâ€”I speak posi
tively to him.

THOMAS LEWIS . I am a general salesman, at 20, Cumberland-place, New
ington buttsâ€”on Saturday night, 16th November, about 10 o'clock, the prisoner came to my house and asked me the price of a pair of salt-cellars that were exposed for saleâ€”I said, "1s. 6d."â€”he said hi could not give 1s. 6d.; and said he supposed he should have andâ€”d row with his wife, as he had broken a pairâ€”I told him he might have them for 1s.; but he then went awayâ€”he afterwards came back and said, "I suppose I must have them"â€”he gave me in payment a bad lorinâ€”I took it in my hand and found it was a bad oneâ€”I kept him in conversation for some little time, till I saw a policeman come up, and I then gave him into custody, and gave the florin to the constableâ€”the prisoner said he bad just taken it from his masterâ€”he did not say who his master wasâ€”I did not notice whether the florin that be gave me was bent; I don't believe it was.
Prisoner. I did not know it was bad at the time.

CHARLES SMITH . I am a tobacconist, at 5, Surrey-place, Newington, about a hundred yards from last witnessâ€”on Saturday night, 16th of this month, about 9 o'clock, the prisoner came to my shop and asked for half an ounce of tobacco, which came to 2dâ€”he gave me in payment, a florinâ€”I tried it in the detector, and found it was a bad oneâ€”I told him it was bad, and returned it to himâ€”he said he had received it from his master for his wagesâ€”he did not say who his master wasâ€”I beat the florin.
Prisoner. I don't know where the shop is; I never saw the man to my knowledge.

COURT. Q. How soon afterwards did you see him again? A. Not till I saw him at the Police-court; that was on the following Mondayâ€”I saw him in a cell with three more prisoners, and I picked him out as being the person.

EDWARD JOHNSON , (Policeman, P 65). The prisoner was given into my custody on this Saturday night, for uttering a counterfeit florinâ€”I asked him where he got the money fromâ€”he said, in the first instance, his wife gave it to himâ€”I said, "Did jour wife give you the bad florin?"â€”he said, "No; I got it from a man in Spitalfields-market"â€”I said, "Do you know where the man lives?"â€”he said, "No; I never saw the man before"â€”I searched him, and found four shillings, six sixpences, three fourpenny pieces, two threepenny pieces, and fourpence, in copper, all good moneyâ€”I produce the florin that Mr. Lewis gave me, and also the one that John Hayter gave meâ€”I did not find any bent florin on the prisoner.
WILLIAM WEBSTER . These are bad, and from the same mould; one is broken, and it is also bent in one part of it.
Prisoner's Defence. I am innocent; I work in Spitalfields-market as a porter for a man; I took the two-shilling piece there. I don't know who the man is I took it of.

GUILTY â€”
Confined Nine Months.

76.
FREDERICK YOUNG (22)
, Burglariously breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
Emmanuel Shevier, and stealing therein 1 desk, value 30s., 7 shifts, 5 pairs of drawers, 4 bedgowns, 13 napkins, 3 gowns, 1 box of surgical instruments, and other articles, value 8l., his property. Second Count, feloniously receiving the same.

WILLIAM COLLINS (Police-sergeant, P 4). On the morning of 20th October, at 8 o'clock, I received information that a robbery had been com
mitted, and I went to Commercial-road, Peckhamâ€”I there saw the prisoner carrying a basket, going towards Londonâ€”I knew where he lived; he was about seven hundred yards from his own house, and about three hundred yards from the house which was broken intoâ€”I stopped him and asked him what he had in the basketâ€”he said, "I am not obliged to tell you"â€”I was in plain clothesâ€”I said, "I am a police-officer, and I wish to know what you have got in the basket"â€”he then put the basket down and said, "They are old clothes, If you want to know"â€”I saw the table cloth, and said, "It's good clothes; it is the produce of a robbery"â€”there was some straw on the top of the basket, and I lifted that upâ€”I found three petticoats, six shifts, a table cloth, and a number of other articles, some wearing apparel, &c.â€”this is the basket and things (produced)â€”the prisoner then said, "A rob
bery! I know nothing about a robbery; I found this in a field by the Duke of Sussex, when I was going to market"â€”I then took him to the station, left him in charge, and went and searched his house, at 4, Park-buildings, Park-road, Peckhamâ€”I there found three aprons, two pairs of stays, two pairs of drawers, six napkins, three shawls, a writing desk, a paint box, and a box of surgical instruments, all claimed by the lady of the house that was broken intoâ€”I took the articles to the station; showed them to the prisoner, find told him I had found them in his houseâ€”he said two men had brought them in at half-past 5 in the morningâ€”he said he did not think it was all right, and he packed them in a basket and was going to take them to the police-stationâ€”I told him he was going the wrong way to the police-stationâ€”he said he did not know where it was, and was going to try to find itâ€”he was going quite the contrary wayâ€”he was going from his house, towards Londonâ€”I then went to the house of Mr. Shevier, 37, Park-place, Peckhamâ€”that is about two hundred yards from the prisoner's house I believeâ€”there are gardens at the backs of the houses, so that a person could get across; but it was not so in this case, they have to go a round-about way to get into the main roadâ€”I found at Mr. Shevier's that the

grating of coal-cellar had been removed and left open; that would lead into the bottom part of the house; but the grating was too small to admit them; it was left outâ€”I found that the catch of the back parlour window had been forced back by some thin instrument; there was a mark upon the catchâ€”I found this knife (produced) at the prisoner's houseâ€”there is a notch in it; it was there before I tried itâ€”I opened the catch with it in the presence of Mr. Shevier.

Prisoner. Q. Did I not say I had a horse ia the Green-yard and I was going to it? A. I don't remember that; at the place where I took you there is a gate leading to the door of a house; but there is no thoroughfareâ€”I did not take you through that gate; I took you straight back again.

CHRISTIANA SHEVIER . I am the wife of Emmanuel Shevier, of 37, Park-place, Peckhamâ€”I was called by my servant on the morning of 20th October, about a quarter-past 7â€”when I came down I found the place in confusion, and goods strewed aboutâ€”these articles which have been produced are my property; and they were in the house on the previous nightâ€”I went to bed about 11, and the house was safe at that timeâ€”I saw it all fastened.

HARRIET COTTRELL . I am the wife of James Cottrell, of 3, Smithâ€™s buildings, Park-placeâ€”on the morning of 20th October, about a quarter-past 8, I saw the prisoner coming out of his doorâ€”he had a basket on his head, like the one hereâ€”it was filled with straw, and something in itâ€”three gentlemen, followed after him out of the house.
Prisoner. Q. Did you see anybody come out with me? A. Not with you; about a second afterwards.

ELLEN CONDEN . I am a widow, and live at 3, Welton
terrace, Peckhamâ€”I was asked by Mrs. Shevier to stay with her on the night of 19th Oc
toberâ€”she came to me and I stayed with her that night we went to bed about 11â€”the house was closed when I came at nightâ€”it was closed when I went to bedâ€”I got up in the morning at 6 or half-past, I cannot say, the clock was stopped in the kitchenâ€”I found the place in confusion.

Prisoner's Defence. The night the things were brought to my place I was in bed. My wife woke up, and saw the two young men who brought them; and they left them there. I got up on Sunday morning, packed them in a basket, and was going away to the station with them. There is Richard M'Carthy here, who will prove I was in bed.

RICHARD M'CARTHY . I live about three-quarters of a mile from the prisonerâ€”I was with him on the Saturday night till 10 o'clock, and then he left me and went homeâ€”I did not see him again till the Monday morning At the Lambeth police-courtâ€”I went to his house at 7 o'clock, and we went out at 9; and he left me and went homeâ€”I saw Ashmore and another young man, I suppose it was Turner, thereâ€”I do not know his nameâ€”they left before we didâ€”they went away at 8 o'clock, and then we went out with our music to the Crown, at Peckham, and Young left me there.

ELIZABETH BREWER . I live with a person named "Frenchy"â€”I lodge in the same house with the prisonerâ€”I remember Saturday, 19th Octoberâ€”I saw him that evening in bed between 10 and 11â€”I then went out along with his wife to get something for supper; and when we came hack he was still in bedâ€”that was about 12â€”I then went into my room to bedâ€”I went in on Sunday morning to get the milk-pot, and saw three young men stand
ing thereâ€”I know two of them, and should know the other if I saw himâ€”they were Ashmore and Turner.
(See next case.)

77.
JOSEPH ASHMORE (18), and
GEORGE TURNER (20), were indicted for
the same offence; to which.

TURNER
PLEADED GUILTY .â€”
Confined Eighteen Months.

WILLIAM COLLINS (Police-sergeant, P 4). About 8 o'clock on the morning of 20th October, I found Frederick Young in the Commercial-road, carrying a basket of things which I have producedâ€”after taking him to the station I went to the house where he lived, and there found a quantity of other property which I have also producedâ€”I then went to Mrs. Shevier's house, 37, Park-place, and found the grating of the coal-cellar removed, and also the back-parlour window open, and the mark I have described on the catch.

CHRISTIANA SHEVIER . On the morning of 20th October I found the house in confusion; and that it had been broken open during the nightâ€”it was safe over nightâ€”I went to bed about 11, and got up about a quarter to 8.

HARRIET COTTRELL . I saw Frederick Young on Sunday morning, 20th October, about quarter-past 8, coming out of his house with a basketâ€”shortly after, I saw three other men come out of the same houseâ€”it could not have been above a secondâ€”Ashmore was one of them, and Turner another; they were together with a thirdâ€”they followed Young up the placeâ€”it is a streetâ€”there is only one way to go outâ€”I only saw them follow to the end of the street.

RICHARD M'CARTHY . I live at 11, Little Stock well-street, Old Kent-roadâ€”on the night of 19th October, I went to Young's house about 7 in the eveningâ€”I saw Ashmore and Turner both thereâ€”they were there about an hourâ€”I stayed till a quarter to 9, and then Young and I went out together; and then he left meâ€”I did not see Ashmore and Turner again after thatâ€”I did not see any other man there at that time.
Ashmore. Q. Had I not been there before? A. I had seen you there three or four times getherâ€”you did not have tea there on Saturday with meâ€”I had a cup of tea thereâ€”I do not think you had any.

ELIZABETH BREWER . I live at 4, Smith's-buildings; Young lives in the same houseâ€”on Sunday, 20th October, about 8 o'clock in the morning, I saw Ashmore and Turner in Young's roomâ€”I did not see them doing any thingâ€”Young was not there at that timeâ€”he only had one roomâ€”there was a strange man there with them, whose name I do not knowâ€”I left them thereâ€”I did not see either of them on the previous eveningâ€”I have seen Ashmore and Turner there twice or three times.

ANN YOUNG . I am the wife of Frederick Youngâ€”on Saturday or Sunday morning, 20th October, I saw Ashmore and Turner in our houseâ€”on Satur
day night I saw them there about 8 o'clockâ€”they were there about an hour, and then went outâ€”I saw them again between 2 and 3 in the morning; I and my husband were in bed at that timeâ€”they brought these things in with themâ€”they were together with another manâ€”the things were there in the morning when I woke about 8 o'clockâ€”the men went out in the morn
ingâ€”I don't know how long they remained there, or what time they leftâ€”I went to sleep after they came inâ€”I saw them in the morning when I woke at 8 o'clock, and they went out thenâ€”my husband had gone out when I wokeâ€”I had seen them at the house two or three times that week togetherâ€”it was between 2 and 3 when they came in our house, and about 8 when they went away in the morningâ€”whether they remained there all that time or not I do not know.
CHARLES COX (Policeman, P 346). I took Ashmore in custody in Kent-street,
on Monday, 20th Octoberâ€”on telling him the charge, he laid I was mistaken in the man; he bad not been in Peckham for four years.

Ashmore's Defence. I left Turner at 8 o'clock on Saturday night, went to the Surrey Arms, and stopped there till 12. I then went to the Bricklayer's Arms coffee-house and slept there. In the morning I went down to Young's house, stopped there till ten minutes to 8, then went with him to the top of the street, and went straight home at 10 o'clock. I have only Turner as a witness.

GEORGE TURNER (the prisoner). I left Ashmore at 8 o'clock on the Satur
day evening, and saw him no more till 7 o'clock on the Sunday morning.

Cross-examined by MR. METCALFE. Q. Where did you see him? A. When he came round to Young's houseâ€”I was there with the other man; the one who is not in custodyâ€”I don't know his nameâ€”I knew him by seeing him aboutâ€”we both went together to the robberyâ€”I met him in the Kent-road at a public-houseâ€”I do not know the sign of itâ€”I know what name they call the man; they call him "Cainâ€”we call him that amongst ourselvesâ€”it was agreed upon between us that we should take the things to Young's houseâ€”Ashmore came round there to see Youngâ€”it was not talked over at all between me and Youngâ€”it was arranged the same day in the room at Young's house; Ashmore was in the other room at that timeâ€”he went away from the house with meâ€”I remember Young going out with a basket of things on Sunday morningâ€”I was then in his roomâ€”I followed him, and Ashmore went with me.

p.hi:
was further charged with having been before con
victed of felony on 1st February, 1859; to which he

div1.p:
PLEADED GUILTY,**â€”
Six Years' Penal Servitude.

78.
HENRY JACKSON (31), and
ELIZA JACKSON (28)
, Unlaw
fully obtaining goods by false pretences of
Henry Sowdon and another; also, for a conspiracy with others to defraud the said
Henry Sowdon and another.

ELIAS PHILLIPS . I am a salesman to Messrs. Sowdon and Woledge, of Commercial-place, Old kent-roadâ€”they are upholsterers, in a considerable way of businessâ€”in the month of July last the male prisoner called at the warehouseâ€”he wished us to send to 5, Grove-terrace, Hill-street, Peckham, to measure for carpetsâ€”he said he wanted them laid down at once, as he was about to get marriedâ€”I inquired of him whether he wanted any furni
ture, he said, "Yes; a little," and I showed him some drawing-room furni
ture, and he selected some chairs, &c.â€”I then inquired if there was anything moreâ€”he said, "Not to-day," but the lady would callâ€”I also showed him carpets for dining and drawing-roomsâ€”as he was about leaving I inquired his name and addressâ€”he said his name was Edward Low, at the address he had given, Grove-terrace, cattle salesman, banking at Hill and Son's, Smithfieldâ€”he then leftâ€”he did not say anything about the place of busi
ness of Mr. Low; no more than that he was a cattle salesman, and that the family had been cattle salesmen for a centuryâ€”he said they carried on their business at Bank-buildings, Cattle-marketâ€”I afterwards spoke to Mr. Sowdon about it, and, after making some inquiries to ascertain the truth of what the prisoner told me, Mr. Sowdon told me. to Supply the furnitureâ€”I waited until the lady cameâ€”she came either the same day or the nextâ€”she called with a person who represented herself to be the servantâ€”the female prisoner

was the lady who calledâ€”she inquired if Mr. Low had called at oar esta
blishmentâ€”I said that a gentleman representing himself as Mr. Low had called, and ordered some carpets and furniture, and said a lady would call; and they represented to me that this was to be the future Mrs. Lowâ€”she then asked to see some drapery goodsâ€”I showed them some, and they selected some furniture for a dining-roomâ€”after that, from time to time, we sent off goods which had been selected by both the prisonersâ€”the servant called afterwards, and, in consequence of what she said, I went to 5, Grove
terraceâ€”I there saw the female prisoner, and she said she wished to see me about the dining-room furnitureâ€”we had sent some at that time; being too small for the room, she thought it would suit the breakfast-room better, and she should like to have dining-tables, six chairs, a couch, and a sideboard for that roomâ€”I came back again, represented it to Mr. Sowdon, and he said, "Very well"â€”I inquired if Mr. Low was in, and she said, "No"; he was out of townâ€”I went there again several times, but I could see no one but the servantâ€”in consequence of what she said, I sent some chimney-glasses to the same place, and also some more carpet, and some fenders, and tire-irons for the breakfast roomâ€”the things were sent up from time to time as we got them ready, and they amounted altogether ultimately to 158l. 16s., and then I took the accountâ€”I saw the servant, and she said that Mr. Low had gone to be marriedâ€”I never saw Mr. Low againâ€”I went from time to time to the house, and ultimately, on Monday, 29th of July I think, I found it shut upâ€”that was two days after we had sent in the last goods I thinkâ€”we traced the van which had taken the goods awayâ€”we found one van loaded with the goods, and we took possession of it, and we traced a quantity of others to Mr. Best in Rochester-rowâ€”we ultimately recovered the greater part of themâ€”Mr. Best is a furniture dealer; he deals in second-hand furnitureâ€”on 16th October, we found the prisoners in custodyâ€”I recognised them as the man I had seen, and the intended Mrs. Lowâ€”I never up to that time knew of any other nameâ€”on that day I went with the police to 2, Elizabeth-place, Wyndbam-roadâ€”I saw the prisoners in custody at the stationâ€”I also saw there a pair of curtains, a curtain-holder, and some anti-macassars, which I had sold to the prisonersâ€”if I had not believed that the prisoner was Mr. Low, and that he had a banking account, I should not have parted with the goods.
Cross-examined by MR. BEST. Q. Did you part with the goods, in consequence of what the male prisoner told you? A. Yes; it appeared to be all right.

JAMES FOSTER . I am clerk to Messrs. Sowdon and Woledgeâ€”I saw the female prisoner in the shopâ€”I cannot say positively the dateâ€”I should say it was the day after the male prisoner had been thereâ€”that was in the early part of Julyâ€”I saw the back of the male prisonerâ€”the female selected some goods which were subsequently sent offâ€”on 29th July, in consequence of what I heard. I went to 5, Grove-terrace, and found the house shut upâ€”I then went to Charlotte-street, Old Kent-road, and there found a van loaded with our goods, which I took possession ofâ€”next morning I found some more of our furniture at Best's, in Rochester-rowâ€”that has also been returned.

GEORGE HULL (Police sergeant, P 32). On 16th October, I went to Eliza
beth-place, Wyndham-road, with Inspector Worelsâ€”I saw the male prisoner there in the yardâ€”I told him I should take him into custody for obtaining goods from Messrs. Sowdonâ€”he said, "I never had the goodsâ€”I cautioned him that anything he might say might be used in evidence against himâ€”I

then went into the house and saw the female prisoner thereâ€”the male prisoner then said, "Yes, I did have the goods, I got them at the dictation of a man of the name of Low"â€”the female was presentâ€”he said he had not had any money except 4l.â€”I made the reply that it had been stated that the mistress got more money for them from Bestâ€”he said that Johnson and be were present in the Vauxhall-bridge road on the day the goods were taken awayâ€”he also said that Best asked him if the goods were hired, and he replied, "No, they were not on hire, they were got otherwise;" and Best then said, "Then I will have themâ€”I round this pocket-book (produced)â€”there is nothing affecting this case in itâ€”I also found some curtains, table-covers, anti
macassars &c., which bare been identified by the prosecutorsâ€”these are they (produced)â€”I showed them to Mr. Phillips and be identified themâ€”I also found at the house the marriage cer
tificate of the prisoners in a box in the front parlour (This contained the names of Thomas Tapley and Elita Wahfdd, dated, October 15th, 1854).
Cross-examined. Q. When did you find that? A. After the prisoners were committed.

EDWARD WORILS (Police-inspector). I went with the last witnessâ€”when I first went into the room, Jackson turned round to his wife and said, "Here's a pretty go; they have come to take us about that affair of Sowdon's "â€”Mrs. Jackson said, "We have been the dupe of others, what we did we did innocentlyâ€”I found a great number of duplicates in the house, sixty altogether; none relating to this furnitureâ€”I found a list of goods, some referring to these goods, and on the back of it was "Mr. G. Best, 5, Rochester-terraceâ€”on the following morning the prisoner told me that his name was Thomas Henry Tapley, and that he was married to Elisa, October, 1853; and the reason he gave the name of Jackson, was that he had taken the house in Wyndham-road in that nameâ€”I do not know of my own knowledge whether any of the tickets relate to the property.

HENRY SOWDON . I carry on business in partnership with Air. Mr. Weledge, as upholsterersâ€”in July last, in consequence of what Mr. Phillips said to me, I looked in the directory and also made inquiries at Hills' the bankersâ€”in consequence of what I then ascertained, I authorised Phillips to execute the orderâ€”I should not have allowed the order to have been executed, if I had not believed that Mr. Low had a banking account at Hill's.
Cross-examined. Q. All these goods are credited to Mr. Low, are they? A. Yes.

WILLIAM AUSTEN . I am carman in the employment of Mrs. Cook, Curtain-roadâ€”she lets vansâ€”on Monday, 29th July, I removed some goods in a van from 5, Grove-terrace, Peckhamâ€”I drove one van, and there was a second van driven by another manâ€”I drove my Van away to Best's in Rochester-rowâ€”I left Peckham about half-part 7â€”we were ordered to commence loading at 5 in the morning, but we did not get there before 6â€”I did not see a gentleman named Jackson thereâ€”I saw two or three gentlemenâ€”they did not assist in loading the vanâ€”I only drove it awayâ€”I had nothing else to do with itâ€”I started with the first vanâ€”I did not afterwards see the other van loadedâ€”when I came back I saw a van opposite Mrs. Cook's doorâ€”the policeman took possession of that van and the goodsâ€”I saw the male prisoner at a public-house where I was stopping for the other van to come to meâ€”that was on the other side of Vauxhall-bridgeâ€”after I had got my load I was going to Rochester-rowâ€”I was stopping at a public-house, and I saw Jackson thereâ€”I do not know where he came
fromâ€”that was the first I saw of himâ€”I never saw him More in my lifeâ€”he did not say anything to meâ€”he took me in and gave me a pint of beer.
Cross-examined. Q. He did nothing to the van, and gave you no instructions about it? A. Noâ€”there were four or five of them together, and they gave me some beer, and Jackson was with them.
COURT. Q. Were they the same gentlemen you had seen at the house when you were removing the things? A. Yes, one of them I saw.

JAMES WATTS . I am clerk to Messrs. Hill and Son, bankers, of West Smithfieldâ€”Mr. Edward Low, cattle salesman, keeps an account there. I know nothing of either of the prisonersâ€”they have no account thereâ€”Mr. Low has been for some years in businessâ€”I know him well.

EDWARD LOW . I live at Myrtle-cottage, Islington, and am a cattle sales man in the cattle-ma, ket, and have been so for many yearsâ€”I have an Account at Messrs. Hillâ€”I know nothing at all of the prisoner and his wifeâ€”I never gave them authority to use my nameâ€”I do not know any other person of my name in the business.
WILLIAM DENT . I am a watermanâ€”I know the male prisoner under the name of Tapleyâ€”we used to call him "Tom"â€”I knew him when he was driving a cabâ€”I never knew him as Jackson or as Low.
Cross-examined. Q. How long ago is it since you saw him last? A. Two yearsâ€”he then told me he had token a house in France, and had come over to order some beer.

WILLIAM BUTCHER . I am assistant to Messrs. Adams, of Bermondsey-street, pawnbrokersâ€”I produce some goods that were pawned on 12th Julyâ€”I have the ticketâ€”it corresponds with the one that Sergeant Hull has pro
ducedâ€”this is the sheeting that was then pawnedâ€”it is not made up at allâ€”as far as I can recollect it was pawned by the female prisoner in the name of Eliza Austin.

Cross-examined. Q. Who do you say pawned those things? A. To the best of my recollection, the female prisonerâ€”I cannot swear to herâ€”it was on 12th Julyâ€”a great many persons have pawned there since then.
MR. METCALFE. Q. Was it a woman? A. Yea; and to that woman I gave the corresponding ticket, which has been produced.

H. JACKSONâ€”
GUILTY .

E. JACKSONâ€”
NOT GUILTY .

79.
HENRY JACKSON and
ELIZA JACKSON were again indicted for
obtaining goods by false pretences of
Harris Parr, and other persons, and for a conspiracy with others to defraud the said persons.

HARRIS PARR . I live at 42, Blackman-street, Boroughâ€”on 21st June last I was in partnership with my brother, carrying on the business of ironmongersâ€”on that day the male prisoner came into our shopâ€”he said he was about being married, and wanted his house furnishedâ€”he gave his name as Edmund or Edward Low, salesman, in the market, and had a banking account with Hill'sâ€”he requested that some party should be sent out, as he did not know much about that business, and he wanted one of us to come and see what he wanted; he said the house was 5, Grove-terrace, Peckhamâ€”I went to the house, and I there saw the male prisoner and a woman whom he represented as being his servantâ€”he ordered the furnishing of his house to the amount of 58l. 18s. 4d.,â€”he said he was about being marriedâ€”his intended wife was not there then, but about a week afterwards the servant that I saw there, called at my house, and introduced the female prisoner as the intended Mrs. Lowâ€”she then selected some things, and took some away with herâ€”there was a good deal of electro
plate which he said he thought beat to leave to herâ€”there was also a dressing

case, a razor strop, and a pair of razorsâ€”she said she wanted the dressing case for her intended husbandâ€”I fancy she said, "To make a present of it"â€”I, on that occasion, asked her when I should go for payment of the goods that had been seat beforeâ€”she said if we would send out a bill no doubt Mr. Low would like to look over itâ€”I went to the house that night, saw the female there, and requested her to hand it to Mr. Lowâ€”she said that Mr. Low was at that time at Romford, and he might go on to Leicesterâ€”I went again a day or two afterwards, and only saw the servantâ€”I did not see either of the prisoners again after thatâ€”I called several timesâ€”about four weeks after the goods were supplied I went to the house, and found it shut upâ€”this dressing case, razors and strop (produced) are the goods that the female prisoner took away with herâ€”what induced me to part with the goods in the first instance was the female prisoner's reference to the bankers, and in the next instance it was the male saying she was going to be married to Mr. Lowâ€”I made inquiry at Hill's, and parted with the goods.
Cross-examined by MR. BEST. Q. They were all put down to the husband? A. Yes; she told me to put them down to himâ€”she ordered some herselfâ€”this is my invoice (produced).
EDWARD WOBELS (Police-inspector), I found this invoice in October last in one of the boxes; I likewise found the dressing-case, razor-strop and razorsâ€”they have been identified and returned.

JOSEPH DEVONPORT . I am shopman to Mr. Bunce, a pawnbroker, at Gravesendâ€”I produce a cruet-frame, which was pawned at our place on 7th August last, by a girl of the name of Howardâ€”she was discharged at Lambeth police-court.
HARRIS PARE (re-examined). This cruet-frame is one of the articles that I parted with.

WILLIAM BUTCHER . I produce a butter-dish, some dessert-spoons, four table-spoons, and a gravy-spoon, all pawned at our house on 12th Julyâ€”I cannot speak positively to the person who pawned them, but to the best of my belief it was the female prisonerâ€”I gave this ticket (produced) to the person who pawned them.
JAMES WATTS . I am clerk to Messrs. Hill and Sonsâ€”Mr. Edward Low keeps an account with usâ€”I do not know anything of. the prisonersâ€”they do not keep an account with us.

GEORGE HULL (Police-sergeant P 32). I took the prisoners into custodyâ€”the male prisoner told me that the female was his wife, and that his name was Tapley, and that he was married in 1854â€”Inspector Worels found the duplicates.

WILLIAM JAMES BURDETT I live at New Cross, and am in partnership with William James Bacon, dealers in china and glassâ€”on 15th July last, the female prisoner came to our house, with a servantâ€”the servant said that the young lady with her was going to be married to her master, Mr. Low, a cow dealer, and had come to select a quantity of goods, and any they might select which Mr. Low, when he came the next day, might object to, be would select others instead of themâ€”they selected at the time more than 20l. worth of goods, among which were goods amounting to 2l. or 3l. which they stated they wanted at once as the house was emptyâ€”we sent those goods at onceâ€”on Thursday, I believe the male prisoner came and asked if his wife had not selected some goodsâ€”I told him that she had, and showed him what the things were that had been selected, and a few othersâ€”he spoke of her as being then his wifeâ€”I was induced to part with the things with which I parted that day, by knowing that the Lows were a very respectable family, and the goods would have been paid for when they were sent in.

p.hi: considered that there was not sufficient evidence again the female prisoner.

div1.p:
HENRY JACKSON.â€”
GUILTY â€”
Confined Twelve Months.

ELIZA JACKSON.â€”
NOT GUILTY .

80.
MOSES PINFOLD (33)
, Feloniously killing and slaying
Sarah Pin
fold. He was also charged on the Coroner's inquisition with the same offence.

ELIZA JONES . I am the wife of William Jones, and live at 3, York-place Pitt-street, Old Kent-roadâ€”the prisoner came and lodged with us last year, and his wife soon afterward came to himâ€”in June last his son and daughter also lived with himâ€”his son was three years old, and his daughter twelveâ€”on this Saturday morning about a quarter-past 8, I remember the deceased asking for the street-door keyâ€”I gave it to herâ€”she went out and re
turned in about two minutes, gave me back the key, and went upstairsâ€”after she had been some little time there, I heard loud words, and then I heard a scream and a fall to the groundâ€”in consequence of that I went upstairs, knocked at the door, and entered the roomâ€”their room is just over my back roomâ€”on entering the room I saw Mrs. Pinfold lying behind the door in a kind of squatting position, with her knees under herâ€”the prisoner was standing at the fire-place, and the daughter at the foot of the bed against her motherâ€”I asked the mother to get up; she said she could notâ€”the daughter then screamed, and asked Mrs. Leith, another lodger, to come in and help her upâ€”the came in and lifted her upâ€”Mrs. Pinfold said to me that she would tell me how the words occurredâ€”she said, "I went out and bought some bread and butter and two herrings for breakfast, gave three-farthings for one, and ahalfpenny (for the other, and because I did not account for the farthing, my husband served me so"â€”she said that her husband had out the children's bread and butter, put the breakfast things in the cupboard, and would not give her anyâ€”the prisoner said, "You pulled my hair," and she said, "You would not let me have any breakfast, and I went to the cup
board to get it"â€”he then went to strike her again, and I prevented himâ€”she told me that he had struck her before that, and knocked her down; she did not say whereâ€”I assisted her into the other room, and at 3 o'clock she diedâ€”I saw her at that timeâ€”I believe the prisoner gave some one some money to get her some brandyâ€”I do not knowâ€”I was not with her when she died.
Cross-examined by MR. BEST. Q. They were not a happy couple were they? A. Noâ€”she was a very inoffensive womanâ€”I believe he enraged her to pull his hair.

CAROLINE PINFOLD . I am the prisoner's daughterâ€”I lived with my father and mother in this roomâ€”we had one room where we all lived and sleptâ€”I remember the morning that this occurred, and father quarrelling about the herringsâ€”they quarrelled about the breakfastâ€”he wanted a far
thing to buy some milk to put in the coffee, and he asked where the farthing was, and mother said one was a halfpenny and one was three farthingsâ€”he out my breakfast off and Johnny's too, and told mother she should not have any breakfastâ€”he went to put the breakfast away, and she pulled his hair, and he hit her on the right sideâ€”when she received the blow she fell behind the doorâ€”she was afterwards taken up by Jane Lindo and Mrs. Leith, and put to bedâ€”I had gone to a shop for my father, when my mother diedâ€”after she died, my father told me if I told anything about it, that he hit her, he would beat meâ€”I had not been in the room quite all the morningâ€”I was in there till my mother fell downâ€”she had not any fall that morning before father hit her.

HANNAH SIMPSON . I am the mother of the deceased, the prisoner's wifeâ€”I remember the day of her deathâ€”the prisoner came to me at night, and told me of itâ€”my daughter's health was pretty good before this, so far as I knowâ€”I bad not seen her for a fortnightâ€”she appeared pretty well when I last saw herâ€”she was in St. Thomas's-hospital about two years agoâ€”that was from want, I believe.
Cross-examined. Q. You did not see her very often? A. No; I am always outâ€”I do not know whether she has suffered from abscesses in the wombâ€”she never complained to me of anything of the sort.

WILLIAM HENRY DRY . I live at 40, Salisbury-place, Looks-fields, and am a surgeonâ€”I was called in on this Saturday afternoon to the prisoner's wifeâ€”she was dead at that timeâ€”I was afterwards called in by the Coroner to make a post-mortem examination at the workhouseâ€”I found a discoloration on the left side, extending over the sixth, seventh, and eighth ribs, and on the thigh; the spleen is on the right-sideâ€”on opening the body I removed the peritonaeum, and presented to my view was the coagulated bloodâ€”I found the splenic artery rupturedâ€”I removed the spleen and found it rupturedâ€”I examined the other principal organs of life, and they were all healthy except the uterusâ€”there had been disease of the uterusâ€”rupture of the splenic artery was the cause of deathâ€”a violent blow inflicted on the right-side, and the body falling on the opposite side on any hard substance, would be likely to produce a rupture of that characterâ€”I afterwards ex
amined the roomâ€”I did not observe anything there which would produce a rupture of this kind, except from a person falling with violence; no project
ing surfaceâ€”a person being struck on the one side and falling on the other would produce this, or being struck on that side over the spleen.

Cross-examined. Q. Supposing a person got out of bed and fell on a chair, would that cause it? A. No; it wants a violent fell to cause it; it must have been a very heavy fallâ€”if I fell over this rail I should most likely fall very heavyâ€”if a woman stood up in a bed, and fell down over a chair, that would very likely cause it.
COURT. Q. Was this a high bed? A. It was a low bed; what they call a stump bedsteadâ€”I did not see any chair at allâ€”there was a table by the side of the bed.

MR. COOPER. Q. Having heard the evidence that you have in this case, is it your opinion that the blow given and the fall you have heard described would produce that injury? A. Certainly; persons who fall by themselves protect themselves with their hands when sober.

HENRY NUTTALL (Police sergeant, P 17). I went to 3, York-place, Pitt-street, Old Rent-road, on 13thâ€”I saw the prisoner and told him I should apprehend him on suspicion of causing the death of his wife, by assaulting herâ€”he did not say anything at that timeâ€”on the following morning he said she was in the act of getting out of bed, and she had fallen and hurt herself.

JANE LINDO . I live at 2, York-courtâ€”I was in this house where the poor woman died, about 8 or half-pastâ€”I heard a scream, and went to the door of the roomâ€”I there saw Mrs. Jones, the landlady standing at itâ€”we went in, and I saw the prisoner going to strike his wife, and Mrs. Jones prevented him with her armâ€”I got the deceased up with the assistance of Mrs. Leith, and got her into Mrs. Leith's roomâ€”she was bleeding a little, and she had a bruise on her left templeâ€”I left her in the room, and afterwards came back; she then complained of pain in her left sideâ€”that was about 9 o'clockâ€”I then undressed her, and helped to put her to bedâ€”she still complained of pain in her sideâ€”before I undressed her, about 11 o'clock, as near as I can

judge, she said she had fallen into the chair as she was getting out of bedâ€”about 3 o'clock on the same day she called me and Mrs. Leith to the bed
sideâ€”she then said, "It was not Mr. Pinfold that done it; it was her old complaint come back again"â€”that was just before she died; she died about 3 o'clock.
Cross-examined. Q. Did you see the prisoner there at that time? A. Yes; he was very kind to her then, and gave her some brandyâ€”I did not see any gin.

JANE LEITH (examined by MR. BEST). I remember going to this house on Saturday morning, about half-past 8, in which this poor woman diedâ€”she was on the floor behind the doorâ€”I asked her to get up, and she said she could notâ€”I got her up, took her into my room, and sat her on a chairâ€”while she was there the prisoner came inâ€”he was kind to her thenâ€”I went to his room and he gave me sixpence out of his pocket, and I sent the little girl to get some brandy to drinkâ€”she had the brandy in my roomâ€”she was led from there to her own room, and had some gin-and-water thereâ€”she complained of a pain in her sideâ€”she had said that she had been in the hospital, and had been illâ€”I know nothing of her falling on the chair.

MR. COOPER. Q. Did you say to the prisoner at any time that he had hit her on the side? A. I went into the room and asked him if he had hit her on the sideâ€”he said no; she was pulling his hair and he pushed her.
GUILTY .â€”Recommended to mercy by the Jury.

81.
MARY ANN HOLLES (33)
, Feloniously stabbing and wounding
Mary Stanley, with intent to do her some grievous bodily harm.

MARY STANLEY . I live at 42, Henry-street, Kent-street, and am the wife of John Stanleyâ€”on the evening of 26th October I took home a female who was drunk, to the prisoner's houseâ€”I saw the prisoner thereâ€”she lives up-stairs in the same houseâ€”the other woman lives in a different roomâ€”I saw her safe up-stairs into her own roomâ€”the prisoner, who was in the passage, asked me for some lucifersâ€”I gave her some, and she went up-stairs and upset something, and then came down and said I had been in her room and broken her lampâ€”I said it was false, I had not been in her roomâ€”she said she should get murdered for itâ€”I had a child in my armsâ€”Mr. Hunter, the man that she lives with, came homeâ€”she said she wished I had not got the child in my armsâ€”she kept on repeating in his presence about the breaking of the lampâ€”a little girl named Martha Crane took the child out of my armsâ€”she is no relation to me or the prisonerâ€”I did not give her the child; she took it from meâ€”the prisoner said, "If you had not got the child in your arms, I would give you something for yourself;" and then the girl took the child from meâ€”the prisoner then struck me across the top of the head, and I fellâ€”I did not see the instrument; I cannot say what it wasâ€”after I was down I was bleediug very much, and she hit me again, but I do not know whether it was with the same instrumentâ€”the second blow was at the back of my headâ€”I bled very muchâ€”I was under the surgeon's care for a fortnightâ€”two men picked me up in the passage and stood me against the door, and I was led to the doctor's.
Prisoner. She came up in my room and broke the lamp. Witness. I did not, I was never in your room in my life.
COURT. Q. Did you know where her room was? A. Yesâ€”the back room, second floorâ€”there is only one up-stairs room to the house; it is one

story highâ€”I have never been into her room in my lifeâ€”I did not go In on ibis night and break her lampâ€”she was not with me when I brought the drunken woman homeâ€”I brought the woman out of Kent-street; not out of a public-house, but out of the streetâ€”I only saw the prisoner coming down Henry-street while I was taking the woman homeâ€”she came in just after usâ€”I had not spoken to her before I got inâ€”this woman was no friend of hers, but only occupied another room in the houseâ€”the prisoner had not been drinking with me in the Black Horseâ€”I never drank with her in my life.
Prisoner. She accused me of stealing the drunken woman's shawl? Witness. No, I did not; nothing of the kind.

BETSEY NEUTCH . I live at 12, Henry-street, Kent-street, South warkâ€”on 26th October, in the evening, I heard a noise at Mr. Hunter's houseâ€”I saw the prisoner thereâ€”I heard a bit of a bother and went downâ€”I saw Mrs. Stanley thereâ€”Mrs. Hunter was inside the passage and Mrs. Stanley outside the doorâ€”Mr. Hunter had his arm across the door, smoking a pipeâ€”Mrs. Hunter said, "What would I give you if you had not that child in your arms," and then the little girl took the child from Mrs. Stanley's arms, and no sooner was the child out of her arms than the prisoner struck her on the headâ€”I saw this instrument (produced) in her bandâ€”Mrs. Stanley fell into the passageâ€”I did not see another blow struckâ€”the blood gushed into Mrs. Hunter's faceâ€”I went up the street for the two policemen, and when I came back Mrs. Stanley was outside the door bleeding very muchâ€”I am sure this is the weapon that the prisoner had in her hand.

DENNIS CLARK (Policeman, M 108). On the evening of 26th October, I was called to Henry-street, Kent-street, where I found the witness Stanley bleeding very much from the headâ€”I was in company with another con
stableâ€”I saw her bleeding from two wounds in the headâ€”I asked her who had done it, and the prisoner was pointed out to me as the personâ€”she was trying to get up stairs when I apprehended herâ€”I told her I took her for stabbing Mrs. Stanleyâ€”she made no replyâ€”I did not see this instrument.
COURT. Q. Could you tell whether tie prisoner was sober or drunk? A. Well, I should say she was not drunk: she had been drinking.

FREDERICK HOUGH (Policeman, M 112). I was called to 24, Henry-street, on the evening of 26th Octoberâ€”I saw the prisoner and prosecutrix thereâ€”the prosecutrix was bleeding from the head very muchâ€”the instrument was described to me as a steelâ€”I looked about, and that was given to me by Mrs. Stanley's husbandâ€”I do not know of my own knowledge that it belongs to the man the prisoner lives with.

JOHN KILWATER . I am a surgeon at 135, Dover-road, Walworthâ€”on 26th October, about 12 o'clock at night, the prosecutrix was brought to my shop bleeding from two wounds on the head, but not much; the bleeding had nearly ceased thenâ€”I dressed the woundsâ€”one was half an inch in extent, and the other an inchâ€”they were both lacerated woundsâ€”this in
strument is very likely to have caused themâ€”they must have been done with an amount of violenceâ€”it went to the bone, but it had not injured the boneâ€”the prosecutrix was under my charge a fortnight.

COURT. Q. Were they dangerous wounds? A. Not in themselvesâ€”they might have produced erysipelas or exfoliationâ€”the prosecutrix was not drunkâ€”it was what we call a penetrating lacerated wound, as if done with the point of a weapon.
Prisoner's Defence. I went out shopping with the woman from the front room, she has treated me twice; I went in to treat her, and in that public-house

I saw Mrs. Stanley in front of the bar; she came and drank with us and borrowed sixpence of the young woman I was with; we went home, I carried Mrs. Stanley's child home to the woman's door; she went into the young woman's room; I went upstairs, and soon afterwards she came up
stairs and told me I had stolen the young woman's shawl; she challenged me to fight; she said she would pay it to me, she owed it to me; a month before that she burst in my door and came in and kicked me; coming down
stairs in my passion, and having the drink, I don't know what I have done; I am very sorry for what I have done.

GUILTY .â€”
Confined Twelve Months.

82.
ALFRED SHEA (19)
, Unlawfully having implements of hoose
breaking in his possession; to which he
PLEADED GUILTY .

83.
ALFRED SHEA was again indicted
for burglariously breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
Henry Faulkner, and stealing therein 1 box, 5 spoons, 1 scoop, 1 case of drawing instruments, his property; and 1 shawl, the property of
Rachel Newton. Second Count, Feloniously receiving the same.

RACHEL NEWTON . I am servant to Henry Faulkner, of 7, Bedford-row, Claphain-riseâ€”that is his dwelling-houseâ€”on Sunday evening, 22d Septem
ber, I fastened the house upâ€”the back drawing-room window was quite fastâ€”I put the latch toâ€”I and the family went to bed about half-past 10 o'clockâ€”I left this shawl (produced) on a small table in the kitchenâ€”I came down next morning about half past 6â€”I had left a desk also standing on the tableâ€”I found it on the floor in the kitchenâ€”the things were turned outâ€”I missed my shawlâ€”I called up the familyâ€”the drawing-room window was half openâ€”the blind was half up at one end, pulled up untidily as if it had been hastily drawn up.

Cross-examined by MR. DICKIE. Q. Do you swear to that positively, as being your shawl? A. Yes, because there is a mark in one corner where the box was shut on it and went through itâ€”I have no mark by needle
workâ€”the shawl was put in the box and the bolt of the lock went through it.
COURT. Q. How long were you up before you came down? A. Not long, about a quarter of an hourâ€”I did not hear the clock strike 6â€”I was the first down.

EMILY LUCY FAULKNER . I am the wife of Henry Faulkner, of 7, Bed
ford-row, Claphamâ€”on the morning of the 23d September, about 7 o'clock, I was called up by my servantâ€”I found the drawing-room window wide open, a pane of glass cut out of it, and the latch put backâ€”I found the inside of the drawing-room door very much cutâ€”it had been locked securely on the outside on the night before, and it was forced and very much cut about and disfiguredâ€”they succeeded in opening itâ€”I missed a silver snuff
box, and a set of drawing instrumentsâ€”I have never heard anything more about themâ€”my house is only separated at the back, from the fields, by a low wall.
COURT. Q. What parish is it in? A. Lambeth, I believe.

GEORGE WATERS . I am shopman to Mr. Barnett, of Saville-place, Lam
beth, pawnbrokerâ€”on the morning of 23d September, this shawl was taken in by meâ€”I have the duplicateâ€”it was pledged by a female whom I do not know.

JOHN PHILLIPS (Policeman, P 64). On the night of 5th November, or the morning of the 6th, I was on duty in Cranmore-road, Brixton, about a quarter past 12 o'clockâ€”I saw the prisoner come over the gate of Mr.

Sangster's houseâ€”he could not see meâ€”he ran, and I ran after him, and sprang my rattle, calling out, "Stop thief"â€”he was stopped by two constables, of whom Parren was one, in the Foxley-roadâ€”when I got up to him, I said, "He has been over Mr. Sangster's gate, in his garden; I saw him come over the gate"â€”he said, "You are wrong; I was only standing under it"â€”constable 380 then said that he saw him throw something over the wallâ€”he made no answer to thatâ€”360 and 377 took him to the stationâ€”I went to the garden, and found there this screwdriver, wrapped up in paper, and a knifeâ€”on 6th November, the day the prisoner was remanded, I went to No. 1, Smith-street, Kenningtonâ€”he was apprehended on the 6th, and taken before the Magistrate on the 6thâ€”he gave his name, but refused his addressâ€”I ascertained where be lived, and them went to his houseâ€”I found a woman there, who represented herself as his motherâ€”I searched the house, and found four duplicates, one relating to a shawl that was pawned on 23d Septemberâ€”I found that in the spice-box, on the kitchen mantel-pieceâ€”the two duplicates that his mother gave me related to her own propertyâ€”I afterwards went to Mr. Faulkner's houseâ€”the place had been so damaged that they had been obliged to have the carpenter thereâ€”there was only one mark that I could bring to correspond with that screw-driver, and a bradawlâ€”that mark was on the cheffonier.

Cross-examined. Q. What sort of lane is this? A. It is road, with houses on both sides of the way, leading from Brixton-road to Foxley-roadâ€”I was about thirty or forty yards off when I saw himâ€”this is a common screwdriverâ€”I took the woman into custody also, after I had ascertained that the scarf was the proceeds of the robberyâ€”I found that some of these duplicates referred to property belonging either to the prisoner or the woman.

COURT. Q. Was it from something you heard from some one, in the pri
soner's absence, that you went to 1, Smith-street? A. Yesâ€”I found a dupli
cate there, amongst other things, which I produceâ€”the woman I found there was taken in custody on the 12th; six days afterwardsâ€”I took her at that very houseâ€”she and the prisoner were not brought together afterwardsâ€”I heard no conversation between themâ€”I never saw them together until the time I had them in custodyâ€”they were not in company thenâ€”I do not know that she was his motherâ€”my only reason for saying that it was his house was that somebody sent me there, and that somebody there stated that she was his mother.

JAMES PARREN (Policeman, P 377). On the morning of 6th November, about twenty minutes past 12,1 was on duty in Foxley-roadâ€”I heard a rattle spring, and saw the prisoner running, followed by Phillipsâ€”just before we took him into custody, he threw something wrapped in paper over a wallâ€”Phillips afterwards brought a screwdriver and a knifeâ€”I assisted in searching the prisoner at the station, and found on him nine skeleton keys, a centre-bit, a bradawl, three wax tapers, and a quantity of silent lucifer matchesâ€”I asked for his addressâ€”these boxes have been claimed.
Cross-examined. Q. Could thatcentre-bit have been worked without a handle? A. There was no stock to it.
JOHN HOWARD . I live at Rese Cottage, Smith-street, Kennington-parkâ€”I know Sarah She aâ€”she took my house at Smith-street, Kennington, and has had it for two yean or betterâ€”her son lives there.
COURT. Q. Do you know that Alfred She a is her son? A. I believe he isâ€”I know himâ€”he has lived with her ever since.
Cross-examined. Q. How fire off do you live? A. About 120 yardâ€”I
could not see the prisoner dailyâ€”I can state that he was not away a month at a time; I should most likely have made an inquiry if I had not seen him So long.
COURT to GEORGE WATERS. Q. Is this the duplicate you issued? A. Yes; "Ann Jones" is the name on it.

The prisoner's statement before the Magistrate was here read as follows: "My mother is quite innocent; the duplicates are mine; my mother knew nothing of my duplicates, because I always kept my things by themselves; I have a room to myself."

GUILTY .â€”
Four Years' Penal Servitude.

p.hi: There were other indictments against the prisoner.

div1.p:
84.
GEORGE PHILLIPS (17)
, Feloniously stabbing
Alfred Ray, with intent to do him some grievous bodily harm.

ALFRED RAY . I am a cook on board shipâ€”I know Jane Russelâ€”I was in her company on 22d October, at 6, Market-street, Borough-roadâ€”there was a bit of a quarrel between usâ€”I have every time I have been home, cohabited with herâ€”after the quarrelling the prisoner came to the houseâ€”he came up to me between 5 and 6 o'clock, and asked me if I did not know himâ€”I said, "No"â€”I had my foot on the cill of the door, and he was standing outsideâ€”he said; "You must know me"â€”I said, "I never saw you before; I am not acquainted with youâ€”he got mauling about my face, just shaving my nose, and hitting me on my waistcoat pocket with his handsâ€”I said, "Go away; you are not acquainted with me; I do not want to have anything to do with you"â€”he said, Alf, you knew me well on the Downs"â€”I said, "What Downs? I was never ashore on the Downs; I have passed it some scores of timesâ€”I asked him if he would go awayâ€”he insisted on not leaving me, and I shoved him awayâ€”he walked back to me on to the cell of the doorâ€”I said, "You had better go away," and shoved him right off the kerb, which was not above two yardsâ€”he came back to me again, but said nothingâ€”he then went away, and I followed him and asked him what he knew of meâ€”he had another pal with him waitingâ€”I had not seen anybody before that with himâ€”this other person was not present thenâ€”I went down the street and asked him what he knew of me, and while I was speaking to him another man came upâ€”I was still following him; holding him by his collarâ€”the other man struck me a violent blow on the jaw, and ran awayâ€”I then struck Phillips a blow or two at leastâ€”I struck at him; I do not know whether I hit him or not, and ran after the other, but could not catch himâ€”I came back to see if I could get hold of Phillips, but he was goneâ€”he went into No. 13â€”I did not see him go in, but I found him there shortly afterwardsâ€”there was some matting before the door, which kept it from closingâ€”I shoved it from the outside to open it, and my strength being greater than somebody's who was pushing inside, I forced it open, and saw the prisoner insideâ€”I heard a female say, "Chive himâ€”the door was then thrown open upon me, and I received a knife in my left breastâ€”I saw something glitter, but I was not aware I was stabbedâ€”I left the door and walked awayâ€”a female said, "You are stabbedâ€”I then put my hand to my left breast and found I was bleeding very fast, and was exhaustedâ€”I had then walked two or three yardsâ€”they took me away to the nearest doctor, and from there to the hospitalâ€”I did not see the prisoner as I was pushing the door openâ€”I believe he was behind itâ€”I saw the figure of a manâ€”ho could not get behind the door because it was thrown
completely backâ€”I believe it was the prisonerâ€”I swear it because there was no other man in the houseâ€”I had been drinking with two or three friends, but was not drunk.
Prisoner. You said at the police-court that we were fighting in the road, and that you struck me in the passage, Witness. I never said that I struck you in the passage.

COURT. Q. Did you never see the prisoner before? A. Never in my lifeâ€”I had been ashore about a week, and had been with Jane Russel all night and all dayâ€”I had the quarrel with her at a little after 4 o'clockâ€”I had not been drinking with herâ€”the quarrel was about an hour before Phillips came upâ€”I did not strike herâ€”I did not hit her as I am aware ofâ€”I do not believe I didâ€”I might have shoved herâ€”she has a room upstairs, and one downstairs, but the quarrel took place in the passageâ€”she was not there after the quarrel, she had left the houseâ€”I did not push her outâ€”I never saw the prisoner beforeâ€”he asked me if I knew Harry Raging; he is an ordinary seaman, and since that he has been on board one of the Naviga
tion Company's boats; he sailed with meâ€”when the prisoner walked from me at my repeated request, I followed him because he said he knew me in the Downs, and I went after him to ask him to explain himselfâ€”I went to No. 13, because another man had hit me, and I wished to ask the prisoner what that man hit me forâ€”I did not put that question to him, but I have asked him in private, and he made me no answer, but turned his beck to meâ€”I never took hold of him, I tapped him on his shoulderâ€”I never took hold of his collar, not as a prisonerâ€”I did not leave my hand on his shoulderâ€”I saw him the same evening after this assault at the police-stationâ€”I should judge him to be sober.

JANE RUSSEL . I live at 6, Market-street, Southwarkâ€”on 22d October Ray left me for three quarters of an hour, and came back intoxicated about ten minutes past 5â€”he was a little the worse for liquor, but not very muchâ€”we then had a few words, and he struck me onceâ€”I said, "To save any more words, I will go out," and he stopped inâ€”I went to Phillips's house, 13, Market-streetâ€”I afterwards went back to my house, we had a few more words, and I then went back to No. 13, and was in the same room as the prisoner's sisterâ€”the prisoner said, "What is his name, is not his name Jack?" I said, "No,"â€”my sister said, "You had better stop here a few minutes, perhaps he will be cooler"â€”I understood "him" to mean Rayâ€”the prisoner said, "What is his name?"I said, "Alf"â€”he said, "I know him, I knew him in the Downs; I will go up to him, and perhaps we shall get a glass of something to drink out of him, I will see if I can quiet him a bit"â€”I went out and saw the prisoner standing by the door of No. 6, pushing Ray by the shouldersâ€”that was about three minutes to 5â€”after that another person stopped Ray with the prisoner, and hit Ray on the side of the headâ€”he went away, came back with the prisoner, and asked him why he struck him, he told him to ax * *â€”the prisoner then went and stood at the door of his house, and the prosecutor was standing close to the doorâ€”I do not know whether Ray attempted to get into the house, but they went into the road, and had a tustle together, and the prisoner left him and re
turned to No. 13â€”Ray followed him, he stood by the door, and said if be caught him there he would lock him upâ€”he was immediately inside the doorâ€”my sister came out and said, "If you strike him, I will strike you with the poker;" and the poker was thrown out at the windowâ€”the prisoner came out again, they had a few more words, and another tustle in the roadâ€”the prisoner then went buck to the house, to the parlour door, and I went

into the kitchenâ€”the door would not dose because of the mat, and I heard somebody pushing itâ€”I went towards the door, and saw the prisoner and his sisterâ€”the prisoner had a knife in his handâ€”I saw him rush out, and when he returned he said, "Now I have chiv'd him"â€”I saw the door opened about quarter or half a yardâ€”I did not see who pushed it, but I beard Ray say, "If I catch him, I will lock him up"â€”it was then that the prisoner went towards the door with a knife in his handâ€”he still had the knife in his hand when he returned and said, "Now I have chiv'd him"â€”I did not see any blood on itâ€”I saw him put it in his pocket, but what sort of a knife it was I cannot sayâ€”the prisoner's sister said, "It serves him right."

COURT. Q. Was Ray violent? was he making a great effort to strike you? A. Not a very great effortâ€”he pushed the door, and tried to get at the prisonerâ€”it is the prisoner's sister's houseâ€”I never saw the prisoner but twice in my lifeâ€”I am only friends with his sister as far as seeing her at the door, and saying good morning.

JOHN FREEMAN (Policeman, M 122). I took the prisoner on 1st Novemberâ€”I ran about a mile after him, and said, "Do you know what I am taking you for?" he stood a momentâ€”I said, "If you do not know I shall tell you, for stabbing that man in Market-street, Borough road;" he said that he would do it again to any party who would strike his sister.

HENEY JAMES O'DONNELL . I am a surgeon of Albert-terrace, London-roadâ€”on 22d October, Ray was brought to my surgery, very much exhausted from loss of bloodâ€”he had a wound in the neighbourhood of the collar
boneâ€”I dressed it, bubbles of air were issuing from it, showing that the lungs were puncturedâ€”he fainted frequently from lost of bloodâ€”it was a clean punctured wound, done with a sharp-edged tool, through his coat, waistcoat, and under-shirt, and puncturing the lungsâ€”his drawers were saturated with bloodâ€”it was about an inch deep, ft was a funnel-shaped wound, more deep at the base than the terminationâ€”it was inflicted by a knife, or most likely a daggerâ€”it was a stabâ€”I sent him to the hospitalâ€”the blow must have been given with very great force to cat through a thick pilot coat, and through his clothesâ€”I considered his life in great dangerâ€”I was obliged to have him removed is a recumbent position, as I thought he would have diedâ€”he is getting well now.
The prisoner's statement before the Magistrate was here read as follows: He said he would fight the whole of the street, and would have my liver out, before I struck him with the knife.

COURT to ALFRED RAY. Q. Did you offer to fight? A. Not at allâ€”I did not say that I would fight the whole of the the street, or that I would have his liver outâ€”I did not threaten him a wordâ€”there were no angry wordsâ€”he struck me in the jaw, and ran awayâ€”I did not threaten his sister at allâ€”the people told me something about being struck with a poker, and they picked up the poker and said, "You shall not do it, you shall not knock out his brains"â€”the poker had been thrown out at the windowâ€”the man who ran away struck me the blow, and knocked me in the back.

COURT to JANE RUSSEL. Q. Did you hear him threaten the prisoner's sister? A. I did not; she said that if anybody struck her or her brother she would hit them with the pokerâ€”she was outside the doorâ€”I saw no mark on her of her having been struckâ€”Ray was outsideâ€”he was not violentâ€”he was standing by the palingsâ€”I did not see him strike or push her.
Prisoner's Defence. I went to see my sister, and Jane Reynolds came down for protection; I said, "Perhaps I can go and quiet him for you;"

I want up to the door and said "Holloa, Alf, how are you?" and he struck me and knocked me down on the pavement; he caught told of me again felled me to the ground; I got away from him and ran in doors, and two men came and stopped him, and laid that he ought to be ashamed of himself; he said "I do not care a b----for all the men in the street, I will tear the b----y liver out of him; my after said, a You shall not hit him;" he came into the passage and I could not get any farther back, and I stabbed him with the knife, if I had not, he would have come near and might have choked me; he was intoxicated.

MARTHA PITTS . I was at my house on this nightâ€”I went up to Jane Russel's, and heard screams of murderâ€”she afterwards came down to my house, my brother was thereâ€”she asked lam to go up and get his clothes and speak to Alf, and he went up and Ray challenged him to fightâ€”I was not there thenâ€”I next saw him when he was fighting in the roadâ€”I saw Ray about to strike my brotherâ€”I rushed between them and got my brother into No, 13, and when I went to shut the street door Alfred Ray struck at me and hit me on the mouthâ€”he said to my brother "I will have your liter out"â€”he got into the passage, they were fighting, and my brother stabbed himâ€”I did not see anybody step Ray and speak to himâ€”I was inside my houseâ€”I did not go out till I saw that he was about to strike my brotherâ€”I dragged him into my own house, and then Alfred Ray struck at me.

Cross-examined by MR. BESLEY. Q. At the time your brother struck at him with the knife, was there any one in the passage? A. Russel was just inside the passage the parlour door is not half a yard from the other door; they are close togetherâ€”beyond that door there are the stairs and the back roomâ€”the stairs are about four yards from the front door, and by the side of the stairs you get into the back roomâ€”there was no furniture between the entrance to the house and the hack roomâ€”nothing to prevent me or my brother going into the back room.

p.hi:
Recommended to mercy by the Jury on account of the serious provocation he receivedâ€”
Confined Six Months.

div1.p:
85.
HENRY BUDD (31)
, Feloniously killing and slaying
George Allen; he was also charged on the Coroner's inquisition with the like offience.

THOMAS ALEXANDER ODEDL . I reside at Peckham-ryeâ€”on 21st October, about 3 o'clock, I was on my way homeâ€”I had reached the corner of Rye-lane which conducts you into the Ryeâ€”I observed the omnibus time-keeper, George Allen, seated in a chair opposite a shop at the corner of the lane, reading what I took to be a newspaperâ€”he appeared to be between forty and fifty years of age, and had dark hairâ€”I saw the prisoner and two other men approach himâ€”I had observed them before, as the prisoner had run against meâ€”the prisoner struck the paper out of the deceased's hand, put his right hand to the hair of his bead, knocked it back, and pulled him by his whiskersâ€”the time-keeper rose from his seat and pushed him away with his open hand, saying, "Go away, you foolish fellow, what do you Mean?" or words to that effectâ€”the prisoner then made use of some words, and struck him in the face a straightforward blowâ€”a scuffle then ensued sad they closed, during which I saw the prisoner seize him by the back part of his head with his left hand, and strike him; he then tripped him, by putting

one foot between his, having a purchase by the hair of his head, and threw him on to the pavement, the back of his head came in contact either with the kerb or the pavementâ€”the blow was on the stoneâ€”it was a most fearful blowâ€”it resounded most fearfullyâ€”he laid in a perfectly insensible state, with blood flowing from his ears, and I rather think from his nose as wellâ€”he was taken up and conveyed to a neighbouring druggist's shopâ€”I left my name and addressâ€”no one else struck the deceased.

Cross-examined by MR. SLEIGH. Q. Were there a great many people present looking at this quarrel? A. There were several people roundâ€”I saw the deceased get up from his chairâ€”he did not strike the prisoner a violent blow on the face before the prisoner did anything further than the preliminary part of itâ€”he may have struck him in the scuffle, but certainly not at the time you mentionâ€”I saw blows exchanged during the scuffleâ€”it is quite possible that blood was flowing from the prisoner's face, but I did not observe itâ€”the deceased did not fall to the groundâ€”I saw him on his knees, but he recovered himselfâ€”the prisoner was not thrown to the ground immediately after the struggleâ€”I think the two men were on the ground at one timeâ€”to the best of my knowledge, the prisoner was not on the ground, and the deceased over himâ€”I never saw itâ€”the deceased was a much smaller man than the prisonerâ€”I did not see the prisoner on the ground while the deceased was standing upâ€”I saw the deceased on his knees, but not the prisonerâ€”after the first struggle the prisoner got hold of Allen, and blows were exchanged between themâ€”I should say that there were blows struck by the deceased as well as the prisonerâ€”at the time they came to the ground I was not quite so far from them as I am from youâ€”there was a mob round themâ€”I should say that severe blows were exchanged.

MR. LILLEY. Q. Had you a sufficient opportunity to see whether the deceased was on the ground or not? A. Quite; he was on the ground on his knees, but it did not occupy a minute and a half altogetherâ€”they both went down at the same timeâ€”the prisoner tripped the deceased, and by the purchase he had by his hair, he threw him on the pavementâ€”I should say that the prisoner's blow was not sufficient to knock the deceased down, but he came to the ground in the scuffle.

COURT. Q. Were they both strangers to you? A. Except the time-keeper, who I had occasionally to ask a question ofâ€”the deceased had not given the prisoner the slightest provocation, at the time the prisoner struck the paper out of his hand, and put his hand to his hair, and pulled his whiskers.

SAMUEL WELLS . I am a labourer living at Peckhamâ€”on 21st October, about a quarter before three in the afternoon, I was at the corner of Rye-lane and saw Allen the timekeeper sitting in a chair reading a paperâ€”the prisoner went and made water up against a cabâ€”he came back, got up on the pavement, walked up to Allen and struck him open-handed on each side of his faceâ€”Allen said "You go away, you stupid fool, what did you do that for?"â€”after he got away Allen got against Mr. Coggin's window, and his shoulder took the sash frameâ€”the prisoner got hold of him and said, "You b----I have got you now, I will give you a cross buttock" and he took him by the hair and tripped him up with his legs, he fell on the pavement, and was taken to a doctor's shop five or ten minutes afterwardsâ€”the prisoner said, "You b----, come out again and I will give you a worserâ€”the fall was enough to kill anybody.
Cross-examined. Q. Did you see the deceased strike the prisoner? A. No; only by pushing him awayâ€”I saw the whole of the matter,

the deceased did not strike the prisoner at allâ€”he did not see him comingâ€”he never offered to lift his hand to himâ€”he was not powerful enough to strike the prisonerâ€”there was no exchange of blows at allâ€”I bare been in Court and heard the last witness's evidenceâ€”the prisoner fell on his left knee when Allen pushed himâ€”the prisoner's face was not bleedingâ€”his lip was bleeding inside by his knuckle pushing him, but not by a blow.

COURT. Q. Had the deceased done anything, or given any provocation whatever, up to the time of the prisoner assaulting him? A. Noâ€”he sat in hit chair reading his newspaper, and had not done anything.

ALFRED COCKINGS . I am a professor of music, living at Camberwellâ€”on the afternoon of 31st October, just before 3 o'clock, I was getting off an omnibus at the corner of Rye-lane, and saw the deceased standing with his back against the shoe shop, and the prisoner sparring at him, and pressing him against the windowâ€”the prisoner's back was turned towards me, and partially hid Allen, so that I could not see everything; but I saw blows exchanged, and they went against a windowâ€”the prisoner took hold of the deceased's hair, held it upright, and cast him down on the groundâ€”the deceased was then retreating, and the prisoner pushing him against the window, he went down like a stickâ€”the prisoner threw him down by holding his hair; and putting his legs between the deceased's, they came down to the ground together; but the prisoner somehow escaped a fall; and the moment the deceased's head touched the ground he let go of himâ€”the deceased was as rigid as a poker, perfectly stillâ€”the blow might be heard across the road.
Cross-examined. Q. Did you see the beginning of it? A. Noâ€”I do not know who struck the first blow.

WILLIAM CAUDILL . I am a mariner, and live in George-street, Commercial-road, Peckhamâ€”I was with Wells, and saw the prisoner go up to a cab for a necessary purposeâ€”he then went up to Allen, who was sitting in his chair, reading a newspaper, and made a snatch at the paperâ€”Allen pulled it away, seeing that the prisoner had a little drop of grog in himâ€”the prisoner snapped at it again, and smacked Allen in the face twiceâ€”no provocation of any sort or kind was offered by the deceased before the prisoner went up to him.

Crost-examined. Q. Do I understand you to say that the prisoner was not struck by the time-keeper, before any struggle took place between them? A. Noâ€”I swear thatâ€”there were not violent blows dealt by the time-keeper on the prisonerâ€”they bad a struggle, but I did not see a below struck.

CHARLES NIND . I am a surgeon at Peckhamâ€”on 21st October, about 4 o'clock, I was called to see the deceased at his houseâ€”I found him partially unconsciousâ€”I found a bruised swelling behind the right earâ€”he was bleeding from both earsâ€”I afterward attended himâ€”he died next day about 12 o'clockâ€”I was not with him when he diedâ€”I made a post-mortem examinationâ€”I found a bruised swelling on the right side, behind the ear, and a little above it, on cutting through the scalp, I found blood pour out between the scalp and the skullâ€”he had ruptured a blood-vesselâ€”there was a fracture of the skull, which crossed the direction of one of the arteries of the dura matterâ€”that wan the cause of deathâ€”a fall on the pavement would be calculated to produce the appearances I saw.
