JOHN HOWARD . I am a builder, of Shard's place, Peckhamâ€”on 21st October, when this matter took place, I was opposite, about thirty yards off

â€”I saw Henry Budd spring on the foot pavement, close by Mr. Rabbit's, the boot maker's shopâ€”Allen was sitting in a chair, reading a newspaperâ€”he rose up and caught the prisoner a violent blow on his lips or teethâ€”Budd was sparring at a distance from him when Allen roseâ€”I do not think the prisoner could have struck the deceased a blow first without my seeing itâ€”Allen then struck him a blow on the mouthâ€”they both struggled together and fell on their kneesâ€”they got up again, struggled, and fell again against a shop windowâ€”they slipped partly down again, and Allen made a blow with his right arm, and missed the prisonerâ€”they then struggled together and fell together, Allen underneath, and Budd holding his head, which came in contact with the foot pavementâ€”I saw the prisoner on the ground the last timeâ€”the deceased was underneath himâ€”they never fell till the last timeâ€”Allen struck firstâ€”I cannot say whether the prisoner was acting in self
defenceâ€”I knew them both by sight but had never spoken to them.

Cross-examined by MR. LILLEY. Q. Were you on the same side of the road? A. No; on the opposite sideâ€”there were a few people round themâ€”they began to draw round as soon as Budd began sparringâ€”Allen was seated in the chair with the newspaper in his hand at the time that Budd was sparring before himâ€”Budd was the tallest.

WALTER SALTMARSH . I am a butcher, at Camberwellâ€”I saw this matter on 21st Octoberâ€”I was about eight yards from themâ€”the time-keeper was sitting in a chair, and Budd and two other men coming from New-cross way, Budd went up to Allen, had a few words with him, and stroked him in the faceâ€”Allen got up and shoved him downâ€”he came up again and Allen rose from his chair, hit him in his face, and knocked him downâ€”he came up again and they had a struggle for three or four minutes, and fell against Mr. Coggen's window, a plumberâ€”I cannot say how often the prisoner was struck by the deceasedâ€”I saw him struck onceâ€”that was after he knocked him down the first time.

Cross-examined. Q. You said just now that he pushed him down? A. Yesâ€”Budd was not soberâ€”I did not notice that Allen had a newspaperâ€”people gathered round very soonâ€”I stood against the horse-trough at the Drover's on the same side of the wayâ€”they both hit one another as well as they couldâ€”when Budd stroked him in the face the time-keeper was seated in the chairâ€”I know Budd, I live next door but one to him.

JAMES TUFFNELL . I am a wheelwright, of Peckhamâ€”I stood against the drover's horse trough and saw Budd come up to Allen and square at him in the attitude of fightingâ€”Allen rose from his chair, walked a little way towards the Drover's against Mr. Coggen's plate glass windowâ€”Allen hit Budd in the mouth and knocked him downâ€”he rose againâ€”they got into a scrimmageâ€”they both fell togetherâ€”the first blow was struck by Allen.

Cross-examined. Q. Did you see Budd come up? A. He came out of Mr. Wright's, the grocer'sâ€”I saw him very plainly as I stood by the horse-troughâ€”there is not an angle to hinder me from seeing himâ€”I could see right to Mr. Wright's doorâ€”I have seen Budd before, but not to be in any way acquainted with himâ€”I had nothing to doâ€”I did not speak to Budd as he went byâ€”I was not in conversation with anyone in front of the drover'sâ€”people were standing across the roadâ€”I did not hear a word pass between Allen and the prisoner.

Prisoner. Q. How far were you off? A. Thirty-five feetâ€”I measured it with my rule the night before last, as I thought I would be perfectâ€”Budd was two or three yards, or a yard or two from Allen, when he sparred at him;â€”I cannot say to a footâ€”he got close to him, or else he could not have struck him.

PETER REYNOLDS . lam a gardener, at Peckham-ryeâ€”on 21st October I saw Budd come out of the road and step on to the foot pathâ€”he went up to Allen and put his hands in his face in this way (Drawing them across)â€”it did not seem hard to me, but I was some distance offâ€”Allen rose from his chair and pushed Budd, who was sparring in front of himâ€”Allen struck him a blow in the face, and they fell together.

JOSEPH EAGLE . I live at Peckhamâ€”I did not see all this matterâ€”I did not see what Budd did previous to Allen getting out of the chairâ€”I am an omnibus driver, and when I got off my omnibus, Allen was sitting in a chair reading a newspaperâ€”I got down to alter my bearing reins, went round and saw Allen rise from his chair and make a push at the prisoner, who came up towards him in a fighting attitudeâ€”Allen struck himâ€”several blows passed, and in the scuffle they both were nearly down, and the prisoner was under
neathâ€”the blow the deceased struck the prisoner, was in real earnest.

p.hi: The prisoner received a good character.

div1.p:
GUILTY .â€”
Confined Twelve Months.
ADJOURNED TO MONDAY, DECEMBER 16, 1861.

HENRY WILLIAMS (26)
, Feloniously uttering a forged 5l. Bank of England note, with intent to defraud; to which he

PLEADED GUILTY .â€”
Four Years Penal Servitude.

p.hi: Than were two other indictments against the prisoner.
